Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed this book for you, O Sons, which is the last of medical science with its completion and I have finished it in its entirety, after its expositions and its declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Tractate which is part of the operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Because surgery with the hand is in our region and time completely absent, until perhaps the knowledge of it perished, and its trace was cut off: and there remained from it, except for small descriptions in books of ancients, which were altered by hands: and errors and hesitation happened to them, until their intentions were closed, and the power of him was extended: It seemed to me, that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise in it according to the way of exposition, and declaration, and abbreviation: and that I should come with the forms of instruments cautery, and the rest of the instruments of work: when it is done from the addition of declaration, and from the preparation of it which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The cause why a good artificer is not found in our time with his own hand is: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to exercise himself before that in the knowledge of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the attachments of the members, and their forms, and their conjunctions, and separations, and has knowledge of bones, and nerves, and tendons, and their number, and their exits, and the pulsations of veins, both quiet and moving, and the places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of this Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work little, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have now spoken of that at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For whoever is not learned in what we have said about anatomy, he will not be able to purge himself, but rather fall into error, by which men are slain: just as I have seen many of those who form themselves from this knowledge, and boast of it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That is, because I saw a foolish physician follow an abscess on the neck of a woman, and he cut into some arteries in her neck; therefore, blood flowed from the woman until she died between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who dared to extract a stone from a man who had advanced in age, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore it came to him, and he extracted it with the fragment of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I indeed had been called to remove it; and I saw from the size of the stone, and the disposition of the patient, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who was receiving a stipend from a certain Duke in our land for medicine: and it happened to an eunuch, black, who was with him, a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the physician hastened with his ignorance, and bound the fracture above the wound with splints, and nails, with a strong bandage, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he completed it according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he dismissed him for some days, and ordered him not to loosen the ligature. And he stood thus until the abscess came to his leg, and his foot, and it came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore summoned to him: and I hurried to loosen the ligament: and tranquility followed, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Nevertheless, corruption was already confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore when corruption has ceased to wander through the limb until it has perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who lanced a cancerous abscess: and it was ulcerated after days, until the malignancy of it had increased with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, because when it is a pure cancer from the humor of melancholy, then it is not necessary that it come to it with iron at all, unless it is in a limb which can bear to have the whole thing cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, sons, it is necessary for you to know that surgery with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, surgery which is accompanied by health; and surgery, with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have now aroused in every place of this book, where there is an operation, a terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you, that you avoid it, and halve it: that they may not find a foolish way to speak, and to dishonor.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take the measure with care and protection, and your patients with ease and firmness, and use the best way leading by the grace of God to salvation and a praiseworthy succession: and dismiss terrible illnesses difficult to heal: and remove your souls from that which makes you fear, so that hesitation may enter upon you in your faith and your well-being.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more enduring for your glory, and more sublime in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen indeed said in some of his precepts.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat a bad ailment: so that you are not called a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now however this treatise is divided into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of cautery with fire, and cautery with sharp medicine, a chapter, and ordered from the head to the feet, and the shapes of instruments, and cautery tools: and all that is necessary in the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Of incision and piercing, bloodletting and punction, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and similar things to these: and the whole chapter, arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and healing of torsion, and similar things:  a chapter arranged from head to foot, and the shapes of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the utility and harm of cautery: and what constitutions it is suitable for, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Head I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before we remember the operation with him, it is necessary that I say the quality of his aids, and his harms: and in what complexion he is shown.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	Therefore I say that discourse on the quality of cautery and its use is a lengthy and subtle science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Even many wise men spoke on this subject and disagreed about it; and for my part, I find it enough from their words, fearing an extension.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	Therefore, I say that cauterization is effective universally for every condition, which is with matter and without matter, except for two conditions, which are hot condition without matter and dry condition without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	When the complexion was warm and moist they separated with the material.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that a cautery is helpful in this.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of this, namely that cauterization is not suitable in illness which is from heat and dryness; because nature is heat, and it is unsuitable that it be healed from hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of this said: that by cauterization healing is done in every ailment hot and dry that happens in the bodies of humans: because when you compare the body of a human and its humidities to the complexion of fire, you find the body of a human cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say by his saying: because from experience already it has shown itself to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Nevertheless, it ought not to come to pass that one should undertake this, unless he has already been tested and trained in the last exercise of the chapter on Cauterization, and has recognized the diversity of human complexions, and the disposition of illnesses in themselves, and their causes, and accidents, and the space of time for them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Of the remaining complexions there is no fear: and especially in cold and moist ailments.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For now all physicians have come together on these matters; and they did not disagree concerning the help of cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that from the secret of healing by cautery with fire, and its goodness over cautery with burning medicine is this: because fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member that is cauterized; and it does not harm another member joined with it, except with little harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning in medicine comes to that which lengthens from the limbs; and perhaps it causes pain in the limb to occur that is difficult to heal, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and goodness of substance, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now indeed it has been made known to us by experience, because of the length of service and study with the art, and standing over the truth of things: and for this I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not so, because it is not permitted to me in this book of mine, to bring to you the hidden secret by fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies of its expulsion, which expels diseases with a philosophical demonstrative discourse, that would agree with your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they disagree about the time in which cautery should be done, and put forward a better time for truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is fitting at all times; for the harm arising from time is submerged in the benefit which is drawn with cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is for pains from necessary pains, strong and urgent, which do not tolerate delay; because it is feared from them that an evil may happen which is greater than a small harm caused by the time passing.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let it enter your minds, O sons, that which is not feared by the vulgar and foolish physicians, namely that in illnesses that are healed by cauterization, there is not always a return; and they put forth this as a consequence, and the matter is not as they think: because cauterization is not otherwise than medicine, which alters complexion, and dries up the humidities which are the causes, wherefore pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization is superfluous over medicine because of the speed of its health and the power of its operation, and the intensity of its dominion: and it is possible that illness may return after some time according to the constitution of the sick person, and the location of his illness, and the virtue of him, and what is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superfluities in him, and what comes to him in its acquisition from foods, and similar things from causes, unless illness occurs in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Pain that is slight in a limb due to few excesses and moistures, such as the pain of a tooth, because of the pain, and similar to it, for it is possible that the pain does not return there.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that is done in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the common saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is a true saying: not for what they intend by it; because they believe that it is not a cure that compares with medicine, nor with anything else after the occasion of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The matter is contrary to this, and the intention, that cautery is the last of medicine, is not so, except when we administer modes of treatment in some illnesses, and those medicines do not help; then, at the end of the matter, we administer cautery, and it helps: therefore, it falls that cautery is the last of medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that a cautery with gold is better than a cautery with iron: and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold, and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that it does not make pus the place of cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not absolutely true; for I have already proven it, and found that it does not do that in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And a cautery with itself is good, and better than with iron, as they have said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat the cautery with fire from gold, it is not clear to you when it is heating according to the quantity that you want, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches to it coldness, and if you add fire above it, it melts in the fire, and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore the artificer comes from that into employment: and for this reason cautery is made with iron among us more quickly and nearer, from rightness to operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I indeed have arranged this Chapter on Cauterization, according to chapters; and I have arranged them from head to foot: so that they may help the one who seeks what he wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	On the mode of cauterization of the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This applies cauterization to the domain of moisture and coldness over the brain: which two are causes of inflammation, and multiplicity of flow of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and multiplicity of sleep, and toothache, and sore throat: and universally all illness, which happens from coldness, such as paralysis, and inflammation, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that you should instruct the sick person: that first it be evacuated with a medicinal solution cleansing the head for three nights, or four, according to what the strength of the infirm and his age and his habit require.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to make his head shave with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands square, so that he has now placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever therefore your middle finger shall have passed over it, mark that place with an unbleached one.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then cautery with olive oil fire: this is its form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with the unfastened, descending part so that your hand may be gradually tightened, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see already exposed from the bone the quantity of alkiel, or the quantity of zeuherbi, then elevate your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with another from itself if it becomes cold: until the bones which I told you appear.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt, and dissolve it in water, and drink it into the wound, and put it over the place: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place upon it a cloth soaked in butter, and let it remain over the site until the fire's scurf is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment of four drugs, until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the more a wound remains open, the more it emits pus, and therefore it is better and more helpful.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone; and the cautery should be held until something of the thickness of bone is burned away.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is scraped after that which has been burned from bone, then it is cared for.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary that with the cauterizing iron one should arrive at the utmost, until it impresses into the bone a form, so that the bone falls off, which happens as in the shape of a chisel; or an instrument which women put on the small alphabet infusion; and they believe that vapors of the head are exhaled from this place, and the wound be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is cared for until it consolidates.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	To me, these two kinds of cautery do not appear at all except in certain people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to dismiss him, in my opinion, is better for his health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head is weakened by the disruption of its natural continuity, as we have demonstrated in the other limbs: and especially when the body of a weak patient is naturally debilitated. And indeed the first kind of cauterization is safer and better for me, and I use it; therefore operate with it in safety.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On the method of cauterizing the head in pain throughout the head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a chronic pain occurs throughout the whole head: and it continues in the sick person, and he uses pig fat, and ointments, and head purges, and oils, and emplastrum.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cautery, which we have described, and it does not help anything from those: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	If the head of the sick person is strong by nature's creation and not weak, and it finds intense cold, then cauterize with a cautery beneath it a little.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it on every horn of his head with a cautery, so that it does not penetrate the skin, and uncover from bone the quantity which we have narrated.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize him with one cautery on the back of his head, in the place which is called "was": and it is a place where a ventouse is placed; and elevate your mattress here, and do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For he found himself in pain because of this, and it was different from the pain of other cautery burns on all parts of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I shall say this regarding the cautery: and it ought to be a cautery for cauterizing the horns of the head, and the nape of its neck with a finer cautery than that used for cauterizing the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the manner of cauterization in headache, both with a medicinal fire, and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When there is pain and swelling in the head, or pain extends to the eye, and the head is cleansed with purifying medicines, and the rest of the treatment, which I have said in the divisions of diseases, is administered, and this does not benefit at all; then cauterization is done in it according to two modes: either cauterization with a burning sharp medicine; or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	A cautery with a sharp and burning medicine is, to take one tooth of another, and to scrape it, and to cut off the extremities of it from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut a place of pain in time with a wide lancet, until a place is made under the skin, in which the tooth is caught.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore introduce it into the very skin, until it is covered; then bind over it with a little poultice of a decent constriction, and let it be for fifteen hours; then unbind it, and remove the one, and leave the wound for two or three days: afterwards put upon it a pad immersed in butter, until a place produces pus; then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain medicines that burn, which I have written about in the twelfth treatise, on Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron, is according to this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Burning cautery, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Claulis: because the shape of its head is like the shape of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it over the spot and hold your hand: and you revolve the iron gradually with speed: and let the quantity which is burned be as the thickness of the skin.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift up your hand so that the artery below is not burned and blood does not flow.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak a cloth in salt water, and place it over the location, and leave it for three days; then put the cloth with butter on top: afterwards, care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this headache with the second end of the cutting instrument of the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And be cautious about an incision of the artery in this headache, not one that is old properly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in ancient headache.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a headache, with that which we said from the previous treatment, and that which we said in the divisions of illnesses, and it does not matter for treatment: and you see from the illness that what we said from the first cauterization with medicine, or with cauterization with fire, is not enough, then it is necessary to use a knife cauterization until it whitens. After which mark signs on the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or almost that: and put your hand in one vice, and squeeze it until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to avoid the continuation of the mandible, which moves during chewing, lest it be burned on one side or the nerve that moves it, whereby spasms occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And let there be care and watchfulness of the flow of blood from the artery that has been severed.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its cutting there is fear, and especially to he who does not know what he does, and is not studious nor experienced: and abandons the operation with him first of all.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I shall come with a remembrance of the regimen of the flow of blood from an artery according to its mode, and in the place of this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see that from illness, the cautery does not suffice for him, and you see the body of the infirm enduring the cautery in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, care for the wound until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer a cautery, which we said in the chapter on extracting an artery with a cautery having two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For indeed cauterization is better this way and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the mode of cauterization for ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold, and it is treated with decoctions and the rest of the cure that we have said in the division, and the pain does not go away, then cauterize with fire; and this is called a Point, whose shape is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the points with it after its ignition on the circumference of the whole ear, as it rotates: or on the circumference of both, if pain is simultaneously in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And elongate yourself with a cautery from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the places with encaustic; and let the quantity of cautery be ten punctures in every ear, and so forth.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the wounds until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the manner of cauterization in a torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	A torture which is cured with cauterization, is nothing but from kinds which happen from phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cauterization of the kind that comes from drying and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of earache with leeches and head washes and gargles, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the diseased person with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and a second a little lower from its time, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite part of the weak.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur unless in a part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize it with the cautery in the direct extremity of the upper earlobe below the corner of the head slightly: and at another time: whose length should be according to the length of the finger.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery until half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a kind from the knife, whose shape is preceded: however, it is not too refined, as you see: and it ought to be a knife in it of superfluous thickness little.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place, with that which preceded it: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the mode of cauterization in old apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy has aged, and you have treated it with what we said, and your treatment is not effective, and the sick person does not have fever, then cauterize him with four cautery burns on top of every horn of his head, and with a cautery in the middle of the head, as we said before, and with a cautery on the back of the head, according to what preceded: and the manner of the cautery let it be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also cauterized with a cautery over the opening of the stomach: and this is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is cared for, with that which preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the manner of cauterizing in obliquity.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in a drink are given first to the infirm large amounts of hyer and purifying pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the sick person entirely, and place on the back of his head a plaster of synan described in the treatise on plasters: and place it repeatedly.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This, indeed, is the manner of cautery, and do it according to the same order which I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore it is healed through that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not, then make three cauteries on the back of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and place between each cautery the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for cautery, as that which preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If, however, you wish an addition, and the patient is weak and enduring it, then make a cautery in the middle for him.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you want an addition: then cauterize it over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for him until he heals: let the cautery be olive oil according to the form which has been previously stated.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterization in Paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You must proceed with the purification of the head with shears, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then scrape the head of the sick person; afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over every horn of the head, and with a cautery over the back of it, and with three over the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you need to soften the body in illness with many of these things, and he is weak and enduring, and the illness is strong: then burn him with four cauteries on the vertebrae of the back, and the last one with a cautery, until it burns from the skin most of it, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it heals; and so apply the cautery of Albucasis.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterization in Epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized, unless his epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore it is necessary that you cleanse the brain of him first with a pigskin, and with the rest of the care which we have said in the division: when he is greatly ill, or is enduring in the acceptance of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If it is a boy who does not tolerate medicines, then a gargle and cleansing chewing are administered to the brain, before that many days with improvement of foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize it with one cautery in the middle of the head, according to what preceded in manner: and with another cautery in the back of his head, and over every horn of his head with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient be strong but enduring, then cauterize him with cautery as I said in treating paralysis and softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and vertebrae of the back: and let the cauterizing oil be according to the measure which preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If however the boy is weak, then place a fine cautery, according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the manner of cauterizing in Melancholia.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with cauteries which we said are used for those having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of descending humors, and the body of the sick person is humid, then give him in a drink that will purify his brain, according to what preceded in the division; then shave the head of the sick person, and afterwards make a poultice properly made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the weak one sitting square shall be held from every part.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply this ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	It is better from old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat him over a fire with temperate measure of heating which the finger can tolerate when it is introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let it go until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the sick person once a week, with the rest of his good regimen, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small punctures in it most of all, besides which hold your hand with the cautery; indeed let it smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place upon it a cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the way of cauterizing in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you are told the beginning of water in the eye by the signs which I have said in the division, then begin and wash the sick person's head with it so that it may cleanse him.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard him from all moisture, and make him sit in a bath, fasting for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to shave his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over the two temples with two cauteries, if there is a beginning of water flow into both eyes at once; or from one side, if there is a beginning of water flow in one eye; and cut off with a cautery all the veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in the width of the temples; and beware of the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see something from that, then immediately cut it away with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with the wisdom which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and care from the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two last produced cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterization in ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient and continuous, and they are above the veins and arteries that are on the head outside, it is verified that this is from the superfluities cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the cautery same as I narrated in the beginning of the descending water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries above the two temples, and two cauteries in the neck under the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need to add something, then cauterize it on all sides of the eye carefully, above the eyebrow tip with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing in a fistula of the nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat this, with that which we said in the division, and the treatment does not help: then hasten, and give to drink three nights of a decoction of rue; then shave his head, and cauterize it with a medium cautery, with an olive cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with a two-pronged burning iron, above two eyebrows under little hairs.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the cautery of Claudius.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterization in softening the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by pain or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries in every part: and let them be lengthened from the two temples: and let the length of every cautery be according to the lengths of the eyebrow: and do not bring your hand with the cautery to the end, but according to the quantity which is burned the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cautery according to this mode of lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the manner of cauterizing the eyelid when hairs are inverted and piercing the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	Cauterization is done in two ways: either with fire cautery or with a burning medicine cautery.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	When using cauterization with fire, command the infirm person before it to shave his hair if he is of those who have it trimmed, until they are lengthened and made equal.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If they pierce him at his birth place: then bind his eyes with a piece of cloth, that they may not move until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore they are born and made equal, then put the head of the sick person in your bosom: then mark above the eyelid of his eyes with a cautery, a mark which is according to the figure of a myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a soaked sponge in the albumen of an egg: or in flaxseed mucilage over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then a fire cautery, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the figure which you marked out in many lines until the skin surface is burned, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, altogether apparent properly.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the health of your work is: that if you see the eyelid already contracting, and hairs being removed at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore raise your hand then: and let him go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then put on top of it a compress with butter until the scab is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If something returns of the hairs after an hour, and the eyelid softens: then repeat the cautery over that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize it until it is raised to its natural place: and it should be equal so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the way of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as if you should instruct the sick person to shave off hair until they grow long and equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from cloth a form of myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and from unsoaked lime, one ounce each; then rub them together well, and make it with haste so that it does not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then from the paned out of it onto the parchment which you made like the form of a myrtle leaf, and place it over the eyelid of one eye, or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a poultice soaked in egg white: and the head of the sick person be in your bosom.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger upon the medicine, and press it for a short while.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you shall move it whenever the sick man feels the bite of the medicine; because he finds its bite like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore he persevered in this which he himself invented biting, then dismiss medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the biting has quieted, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid elevate, as it elevates with contraction with fire, or with incision, it is well: and if not, then repeat over it from medicine on the place where the medicine does not imprint, and does not darken, until your operation is equal, and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it a cot with butter until the burned skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with diaphanic ointment, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you in surgery, that you guard carefully, lest anything from the medicine fall into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid softens after days, and something fights from the hair in the eye, then again apply medicine to that place which softens from the eyelid properly, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of humans differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to that, let your consideration be this: and the way of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a study of this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing in a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, as we have said in the divisions of illnesses, and your treatment is not effective: then, it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Tell the sick person to place their head in your bosom and have a servant hold his head between his hands so that it may not be moved or shaken.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a poultice of infusion in the albuginea of the eye, or in the mucilage of psyllium over its eye; then apply fire cautery, whose form is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the form of a goose feather quill from one end, with which cautery is made; and if you wish, let it be penetrating to the other end, and if you wish, let it be bent upwards.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express a fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it up; and if it is not open, then open it, and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place a cautery heated very hot on it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand with it for a little while near the cautery from the eye to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not stray or disturb the sick one: and put the cautery in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you come in the beginning of your cautery up to the bone, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cautery once, or twice, if it needs it: and let it alone for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a poultice with butter and take care of it with an ointment that dries until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If he has passed forty days and it is not healed: then put on top of it a sharp corrosive medicine, until the bone is uncovered; and scrape it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Pay attention to the location of the fistula, and find it; then put into its fissure a fine bed, that is, a fine cannula, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachma of lead melted, and hold your hand with a good retention cane, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run, or the melted lead comes to his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place over the eye of the infirm a poultice infused in albumen of egg, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead, indeed, burns the place of a fistula, and heals it with miraculous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, as we have said from cautery and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a hole in the nose, and to reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what will come in its proper place for itself.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the manner of cauterizing in fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Very often fissures occur in the lip, which are called pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you care for these fissures, as we said in the division of ailments, and the cure does not help, then with a small knife-shaped cautery, according to this form, fire.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concavity be according to the sharpness of a knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it burning quickly into the very fissures until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with a poultice until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the mode of cauterizing in a mouth fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it makes pus, and it breaks; afterwards it matures, and pus runs, and a fistula is formed: then cure it, and the treatment does not help in it, then it is necessary that fires cauterize according to the quantity which takes into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce it burning into the fistula's opening, and hold your hand until the burning iron reaches its depth and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then take care of him after that, as we have said about the cure up to when he should be cared for.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is cut away and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place, and remove the corrupted bone according to what comes in its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cauterizing in gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums soften because of moisture and the teeth move, and you treat it with medicines, and it does not help: then place the head of the sick person in your bosom.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply the burning cautery, which will come in the shape following this, so that you place the tube over the tooth: and quickly insert the ignited cautery into it: and hold your hand for a short time until the one suffering feels the heat of fire has already reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand: then repeat cautery several times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the sick person shall fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour; and he shall spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For when a tooth is moved, it is set firmly, and the gums are softened and tightened, and the corrupted humidity is dried.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the mode of cauterization in toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When pain in the tooth is caused by cold or there is cold within it, or a worm, and healing does not help with medicines; then cauterization is done in the tooth in two ways: either cauterization with butter or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is thus made, take clarified butter and melt it in an iron ladle or pan.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a swab and wrap it around the end of the limb.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in boiled butter: and place it on the aching tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools: then repeat it several times, until the virtue of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, submerge wool or a cloth in cold butter, and place it over the aching tooth: and place on top of it burning iron until the fire reaches the bottom of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization of it with fire is, that you may apply to a tube of air, or a tube of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something of thickness in his body, so that the sharpness of fire does not reach the bone of the infirm.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then set the cautery to fire, whose form will come: and place it upon that tooth: and hold your hand, until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed, either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary in the cautery's application, that the sick person fill his mouth with good broth and hold it for one hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you wish according to what is possible: and this is the form of the Cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the manner of cauterization in strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the strophulae are from phlegm and from cold humidities, and they are not obedient to digestion by medicines, and you wish to hasten their digestion, then a concave cautery fire whose form is this:
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends so that smoke may exit at one end when cauterizing from the other end: and place it lit upon the abscess once, and again, if needed, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then place cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then dismiss him for three days and place over it a poultice infused in butter until that which was burned by fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with toothpaste ointment until the shape of the tube heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterization for hoarseness of voice and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When humidity accumulates above the lung canal, and especially when it is with a cold constitution, then it is necessary that the sick person be evacuated first with medicines of solutions.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at the root of the throat, in a depressed place: and beware, lest you come with the cautery to the throat, nor into the skin, unless something of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize him with another cautery at the junction of the neck at its last vertebra; and let the cautery be clamped according to the manner which preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him as before, until he is healed.
