¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the mode of cauterization in illnesses of the lungs and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When a cough and lung ailment are due to cold humors, and the patient does not have fever or consumption, and the ailment is old: then cauterize him with two cauteries above the fork in low, soft, hollow places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery be a tube according to the form which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to cauterize your wound by pricking with a cautery called 'Punctum', whose form precedes in the pricking of ear pains: and let there be points from thirty points up to almost others.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him with that which preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let there be a cautery having three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore it should be relieved with it cauterization, when you make with it once three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterization in the shoulder joint, in a dislocated humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head is dislocated because of humidity and it does not return to its place within an hour after its dislocation, until it has become accustomed to returning, then it is dislocated with a slight movement, which happens as we have already testified, then it must be reduced back into place.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the sick person is laid on their back, or on their sound side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then raise the skin that is in the inner Tilici to the upper parts with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated inwards.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then with a cauterizing fire he has two instruments.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of cauterization will come with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes cauterization is done with a cautery having three cords, therefore the figure of cauterization then becomes six cauteries: and the cords are according to the subtlety of the thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of a cautery having three handles.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added above this mode, wherefore there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put on top of the cautery crushed leeks with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the injured person lie still so that the limb is not moved for a while until it has strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a single cautery, or with many cauteries by puncturing.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened and humidity is removed: and the infirm is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the manner of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture occur in the stomach until it is drawn out of its composition, and phlegm multiplies to it, and continuous treatments are applied, and it does not help: then it is necessary that the sick person be laid on his back, and stretch out his legs, and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, a cautery under the ear of the breast the size of one finger with a clauili cautery, and two cauteries below from both sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And make it extend between the two so that they may not join when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be the quantity of two thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the shape of the cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cautery which does this cautery be one according to the figure of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it for him who fears this cauterization; and it is, as signs on the stomach point according to the quantity which you wish with encaustration; then cauterize it with a cauterizing point; then cure it with the cure which preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the manner of cauterizing a cold abscess.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When pain occurs in the liver from cold and moisture, or from thick wind, until it leaves its composition by natural discharge of superfluity, and the patient is healed with what we have said, and does not improve: then it is necessary that the patient be laid on his back on his neck, and three cauteries with encaustic signs according to this figure and this same quantity below the epigastrium from the hypogastrium, where the elbow of man reaches. And let the space between every cautery be according to the thickness of the finger: and let the cautery be according to the length of the body straight: and do not press your hand with the cautery too much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	Let the quantity that is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, the quantity of half of it not added: and let the sick person stand upon his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, who has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of a cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you, that you may cauterize these wounds with a knife cautery, when there is subtlety and prudence in the art with you.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself that you do not proceed too far in cauterization, and the thickness of the skin of the whole is burned, therefore the whole body is burned, and it comes to the intestines: because the skin there is thin, know this thing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing abscesses of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an abscess occurs and you wish to know if it is in the flesh of the liver or in its tunic; then if it is in the flesh of the liver, a pain invades the weak patient, and heaviness without sharpness: and if it is in the tunic of the liver, there is a pain with very vehement sharpness: and you see now, because it has fatigued his doctors with treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, it is necessary that the sick person lie on his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of an abscess with cautery; then fires of cauterium which is assimilated to a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it one cautery until the whole skin is burned and it reaches the flesh, until all pus comes out; then care for it with treatment of wounds until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And one should not use this cautery unless the study of medicine is prolonged, and by whose hands these ailments occur with experience many times; then indeed let him dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But in my opinion, it is better to dismiss her.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterization in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that a cautery with the roots of asarabacca is used for cold pleurisy in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is, that you receive from the roots of dried long birthwort, one root longer, which is found in it, and let it be like the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil and set it aflame.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then burn with one cautery in that which is between the continuation of the fork and the neck, and with two small cauteries under a slight slant towards the part which is below the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth rib sloping to the rear a little: and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries from behind: one where it is between two spatulas: and two cauteries from the two sides of the chest, lower cautery which is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you must not grasp your hand with the cautery, but rather it should be on manifest skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancients said that there are men who use a cauterio from iron similar to a rod: and they ignite it, and put it inside where is between the ribs, until it comes with it to the abscess itself, and pus emerges: as we said in the case of an abscess of the Liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with a cautery there is fear, that either the weak man dies immediately, or a fistula occurs in its place, which has no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Of the mode of cauterizing the spleen. Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we have said from the treatment in the division of illnesses, and your treatment is not effective, then cautery in it is according to three ways, which are all right.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of these is to make three cauteries, or four, lining them according to the length of the spleen according to the figure of the liver cauteries, which preceded.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between every cautery a quantity of thickness of a finger, or a little more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of cauterization be as we said in the cauterization of the liver, equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the weak one lie on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another way of cauterization is: as having a cautery with two handles, which we said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder: and elevate the skin, which is on the direct spleen, where the elbow of the left arm reaches: and let your elevation be such that you elevate the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two burned cords far into it, until you penetrate the skin from the other side; then withdraw the cautery: thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a cautery having three handles.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after you have allowed it to discharge pus for many days, for it is more effective than anything that has preceded from the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the manner of cauterization in dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	Cautery does not fall in dropsy, unless it is applied properly.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat Hydropsy with the methods of treatment which we have said in the division, and the cure does not avail, then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, and one cautery over the stomach, and another over the liver, and one over the spleen, and two cauteries behind the back between the vertebrae, and one on the direct chest, and another on the direct stomach: and let the quantity of depth of the cautery be near to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then release the open cautery so that it may discharge pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the weak patient from treatment after cauterization with him: because it is necessary that two intentions be gathered together with him: and he will hasten to him healing with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery with which the belly is cauterized should be a clamp: according to what preceded, its shape. And that with which the back is cauterized, should be an olive according to what preceded its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the manner of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When abscesses are treated in a Hydropericardium, and are filled with yellow water: it is necessary that you cauterize on the back of the foot between the auricular and annular; and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The water of citron will then boil, and let the cautery be according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on each of the two legs two cauteries in every leg, and let the cautery be made with the edge of a knife cautery: and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one under the knee, and the other lower than that, about the middle of the leg: and on each hip two cauteries: and dismiss the open cautery without treatment for a long time: so that it will subside from it some water: then cure it with the rest which we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the manner of cauterization in the treatment of a rupture.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the belly is from cold and humidity until it weakens the retentive and digestive virtues which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with modes of cure, and it does not heal: and you see the weak one enduring cautery of exuberant virtue, then cauterize him with a great cautery over his stomach, according to what preceded in the cautery of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries in the circumference of the navel, with a subtle cautery. And with a cautery above the alcatin above the alhosos large, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive humidities and the weak tolerating it, then cauterize it with a cautery on the comb, and a cautery on all of that; and perhaps you add two small cauteries near the large stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a healing treatment, whose benefit does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the manner of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When hemorrhoids in the anus are old, many, or one, and they are from thick, cold humors, or corrupted humidities, and they are cured with that which we said in the division, and treatment does not help: then cauterize with three cauterizations on the lower spinal bone of the back under the armpit a little triangularly, and the cauterization under the navel as if it were two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cold, and his food is not digested, and you see his face festering, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cauterizer, according to what preceded: and with a cauterizer over his spleen, and another over his Spleen, with a caulking cauterizer: and let the open cauterium go for some time: then care for him until he heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing the testicles after their excision.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut the artery, then apply the cautery which is similar to a ray of fire.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning (instrument) into the cut wound; and your last hand, until the cauterizing reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore the abscesses are many, then cauterize each one with a cautery according to what we have narrated.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for that, when it is applied with ointment until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery over linen, it is more ultimate in aid.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the manner of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the cutting and operation which we have narrated in its place, and is terrified by it, perhaps he is healed with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore it happens to someone that he has a fistula, and it becomes old, pus runs out of it, and corrupt humidities.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is right that you examine her with a subtle probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then learn the quantity of its depth with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then use fire cautery, which is like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself ignited into the fistula itself and the quantity in which it entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat over it the cautery, until all those corrupted bodies are burned, once, or twice, or thrice, according to the quantity of your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself against burning the nerve, if it is there, or the large vein: or if a fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then guard yourself from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this, unless there is an opening in a fleshy place: and you consider, because it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and the materials are cut away from it, and it remains so for a long time: then you know that it is now completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not cut away the material from it, then know that it is penetrating, or there is a decayed opening in its depths, or like one of those: whose recollection will come at its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys from cold or from a thick wind, and it is lessened because of this which weakens the patient, then it is necessary to cauterize it over almethen on the kidneys, with a cauterizer over the whole kidney with a cauterio clauili, whose previous description has preceded.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it a second time in the very wound.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore will come three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore they will be more useful in healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the manner of cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to cold and humidity, until it can no longer retain weak urine, then cauterize its lower part above the bladder, where the hairs of the pubis begin, and with one cautery from the right side and another from the left; and let the length of this cauterization be according to the quantity of a knuckle; and cauterize it with a lower back cautery, or with two cauteries if you need it; and let the cauterium be closed as before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and humidity occur in the womb and pregnancy is prevented thereby, and her menstrual flow becomes corrupted and delayed, and pain occurs to her at its arrival, then it is necessary that she be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we have said in the cauterization of the bladder, and with a cautery on the lower part of the back above the loincloth, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be clamp-shaped.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the method of cauterizing an ache in a dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humors flow to the Anchae abscess and become the cause of its exit from its place; and the sign of this is that one leg lengthens over the other when they are compared against each other; and the place of dislocation is found empty there.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary that you cauterize the diseased part above the wax of its own cautery with a similar circle; after you have marked it with encaustic around the wax, just as it turns around; and so that the wax itself falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery whose form preceded be used in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If you do not have this cautery at hand, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive-shaped cautery. And let the depth of the cauterization be according to the quantity of the thickness of all the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the manner of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the groin and the cause is cold and humidity, and the patient is treated with what has been said in the division, and the treatment does not help, and it becomes old: then it is necessary to cleanse the patient from gross humors with foul pills, or with artificial pills, and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cauterization in it is according to two modes: either cauterization with medicines that burn, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	A cautery with fire is according to many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of these is to cauterize over the skin of the anus with three triangular cauteries, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make for them a good depth, or a bad one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let there be a space that is between every cautery of the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be oiled.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes a cauterization is done in the middle above the head of the fossa itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization of the dislocation of the hip joint, one: so that it contains the whole hip.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cautery for sciatica, when the pain adheres to the buttock itself and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cautery irons above the hip, above the place indicated by the sick man where there is pain, and with your cautery on the tail four fingers' width to the left side a little: and let the cautery be a knife.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient says that the pain extends nearly to the toes of the foot, then cauterize him there where he indicates with a cautery point, three, or four, or more if needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates pain being under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize it there with a one-bladed knife cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And be careful in all your cauterizations, that you do not go too far with the cautery so that you burn the nerves, or a large artery, and thus draw through it over the weak ailment evil, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have indeed seen one and another of those who cauterized above the ankle, and lingered in the cauterization, and the leg was swollen until a tumor followed all the way to the foot, and the whole foot was perforated and corrupted; then there occurred a solution of the abdomen, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain is in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men said in cauterization of the anus, whose cautery this is the mode.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a probe like a awl from iron, whose diameter is the middle of a palm: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a fingernail, or a little less: and inside that probe let there be a third probe.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	Let there be a space between every stitch the width of a finger's knuckle; and let the stitches be open from two parts; and let their height be like a knot, or two knots; and make for them a handle out of iron fitted centrally into the stitches.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is set on fire until it glows red and throws off sparks; then it is placed over the ulcer of the limb of the sick man lying on his healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore cauterize him with three round cautery instruments in one vice.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him be dismissed after three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterward apply plasters with butter: and leave the open wound for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, "This kind of cautery, my sons, we have used little because of the terror of its appearance; and therefore, because we have found few who wait upon it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless it is good for those who suffer, and find with it a place for it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cauterium, however, with medicines burning, is so that you make two pouches having a perforated arm, into which descends the hinge of its gate from brass or iron, the length of the wall:  of which the height shall be two knots, or like themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be a space which is between the two quantities the thickness of a finger, and let them be open below and above: and let them contain themselves against each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it upon the padding of the bed, the patient lying on his healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand upon the patch of flesh much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour water heated with a little fire between two circles and keep it for the amount of an hour's time: and let the sick person endure its biting and burning, for he himself has found that the biting is like fire until the biting ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then elevate your hand with an instrument, and wipe away hot water from the whole wound with sweet water; then let it be left alone for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place over this butter until the blackness of burning is removed; and let it stand for several days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is indeed the last resort in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If pain extends as far as the hip or leg: make for him a statue in that which contains water, according to what you did in ancha equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unquenched quicklime, each a part, grind them both, and place them in a new pot, whose lower part has a small hole according to the amount that will enter it; and place another pot inside the bottom of the pot; and pour over the alkali and quicklime from sweet water, so that both are submerged by a finger; after which you compress them with your hand good compression, and set aside the pot until the sharp water descends into the lower part of the smaller pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather all that water and throw it over another lime stone: and stir until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be strong and very sharp, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in cauterization of the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it produces an operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And of medicines there are those with which  large wounds are cauterized, just as with the powder of almond and lime mixed with soap, so that both are well mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed narrating retold, of a certain man from antiquity the cure, with which he was cured pain of the hip and sciatic vein: and magnified it to be greatly.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it did not need further treatment, and that it was healed from the one wound, until it returned, because perhaps he himself had entered the bath, brought there, and went out from it already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is, as it should be taken from the green sitaragi: and if it is not found green, take it dry, fresh: and it is to be ordered much with a little fat, and placed over the ache, where pain is, whether in the leg, or in the hip: and let it be applied, and removed after three hours, or for the quantity that the sick man feels sedation of burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore the body becomes moist, introduce it into the bed.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For pain departs, and healing comes.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that it is not right for anyone to use a cautery with these medicines unless after evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that goat dung, when it is cauterized with the vein of Sciatica, helps: and the cautery is made according to this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and soak it in old oil, and place it over the deep spot which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the ankle bone, and is nearer to the ankle bone.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and ignite it in a fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place him upon wool, and let him be, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then again that.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Therefore, do not cease doing this until sensation returns through touch up to the end and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this mode of cauterization is called cautery Vaccinum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	On the cauterization of back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back from many causes, either from a fall, or from a blow, or from the evacuation of superfluity, and things similar to these, from the infusion of cold and moist material: and cauterization indeed does not apply except in this single kind, which is made from the infusion of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after evacuation of the patient, with foul pills and similar ones, three lines should be made across the back, where there is pain, according to the width of the affected area, after marking the lines with encaustic, on every line five cauteries, or more according to the quantity that comes from the endurance of the patient and his strength: and cauterization shall be done with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three cauteries, or four, with a medial clamp cautery, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	On the manner of cauterizing an incision in gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLIV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often happens to young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in boys is: that which happens upon him constriction in breathing at elevation, and movement: and you find it in the last vertebra of the back and its knots, which has already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see that and wish to make it, then cauterize it with a cautery which is circular according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let him take the cautery over all part of the vertebra equally: and if you wish, cauterize in the circumference of the vertebra with the cautery points two lines, or three: and let the points be near to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it heals with what we said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you administer a cautery in the hump, which is formed in the spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterization for gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When pains of the joints are from cold moisture, which is poured into any limb of the body, then when pains occur in the feet, it is customary for physicians to call that properly Podagra.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore gout is treated for its cold cause with modes of treatment, and the pains are not removed, then cautery will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, as you cauterize him after evacuation at the juncture of the feet, with many cauteries: and let the cautery be Olivare.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to put points on the face of the foot, then make with a cautery points.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize the area above every knee with three or four cauterizations from all sides, with the same cautery as Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If more are necessary for you with this cautery, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be about the thickness of the skin only.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, pains ascend to the knees and back: then administer what we said from cauterization in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If there are pains only in the hands, then prick at points around the focus of pain, such as two lines revolving.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If there remain pains in the fingers, then prick them, above every knot, and above the comb of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pains ascend after days to the elbows, or to the shoulders, then cauterize both sides from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not discharge a sick person from good regimen, from the taking of medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is followed and phlegm is evacuated, he will be healed with the help of God with this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the method of cauterization in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When rupture occurs in the groin and intestine or spermatic cord descends to the testicle, and this is beginning to be near, then it is necessary that you order the sick person to abstain from eating on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use emollient substances so that stool descends from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and command him to hold his breath until it comes out, or appears the spleen or intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with a cautery under the rupture over the bone of the breast, with a sign whose extremity is similar to half a circle toward the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then a fire cauterizing, whose this is the form, until it comes white and throws sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine, or the rectum to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then the assistant places his hand over the place so that the intestine does not protrude; and you have already opened between the legs of the sick person, and placed a board under him, and one serving over his legs, and another over his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery over that mark, with your hand and the standing cautery straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you bring it to the bone; or carry it with a different tool, if you have not brought it together with it at first all the way to the bone.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the exit of the intestine at the time of your cauterization, so that you do not burn it, and that there may not come through it upon the weak either death or great evil.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not obtain with a cautery an opening of the bone, your operation does not help.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery for infants be fine, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care with the remaining ointment until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the sick person lie on their back for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you give him nourishment in accordance with the length of time of his healing, which will soothe his belly so that it does not leave the intestine at the time of defecation and evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to rise after forty days, then administer a well-made bandage, and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should avoid labor and overeating of food and drink and loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this regimen is used, it heals with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I shall say the cure of ruptures with an incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When ruptures occur in the rest of the abdomen and are beginning, and you wish that they not increase, then cauterize the rupture of it with a round cautery according to its size: and let that which is burned from then be like one-third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for him as we have said: and nothing else shall be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some first said that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it has been marked with encaustic wax, and a line is placed which is across the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a cautery closed.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But a cautery is first easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the manner of cauterization in pains due to a fall, or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in certain limbs by chance, or by blow pain; and that pain perseveres for a long time, and it does not help in it healing with medicines: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with a pointed cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	Let the cautery of every member be according to the size of it, and its ability, and its weakness, and its power, and the location of the twisting, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed from the first cautery, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then repeat over the same cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because it is customary for these pains to shift from one limb to the one next to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary that you follow them with a cautery until the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the manner of cauterization in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leper sometimes are helped with cautery and great help.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy, which comes from the rotting of phlegm and black bile: when therefore you wish to cauterize it, consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore leprosy is ineipiciens, and you have treated it with what we said in the division, and it has not descended, nor stood; and fear that over the infirm body corruption will encompass the whole complexion of him: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head known, and a second below towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two above the two horns, and one behind the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And last your hand with the cautery briefly, until it makes a small impression in its bone, and the crusts are loosened from it, that the emission of thick vapors may be relieved from it, and cauterize also the spleen with the cautery, as has been said before.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If leprosy has already spread over the infirm person and appears manifestly, then it is necessary to cauterize with these cautery instruments, which we have said in the beginning, and cauterize on the end of the nose, and two cauteries on the two cheekbones, and two cauteries on the vertebrae of the neck, and six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large one over the hip joints near the base of the tail and one above it, in the very middle: and two over the thighs; namely, over each thigh with one, and two over the knees; one over each knee, and two over the shoulders, and two over the forearms, and two over the tendernesses of his chest: and cauterize him over every joint, from the joints of his hands and feet: and cauterize over every heel of his feet, and knuckles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves that are above the heel bone, lest you burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery on the bone of the breastbone, and another on the bone of the stomach, and another on the rib.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add cautery, it is more helpful, and more efficacious.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick person does not find pain in cautery as the healthy do, because his body is already numbed.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that cauteries be of magnitude and size according to members and joints; according to what preceded from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care with a cautery from flour of herb with honey, and the rest of the cure, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the manner of cauterizing in a stupor.
Caput L.	Head L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a certain limb is numbed, and it is treated with medicines, and oils, and plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize that numbed limb with cauteries, according to what the size of the limb deserves, or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery be driven into the thickness of the skin a little.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes it is cauterized to some kind of numbness that happens to the hand and foot, in the shoulder blades of the back at the exit of the nerves that move that limb: and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But he should not presume upon it, unless he is wise in the anatomy of the members, and the egress of moving nerves from the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On the method of cauterization in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter LXI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras becomes antiquated and does not agree in it with anything from the ingenuities of medicine: then cauterize upon it itself with a deep cautery for a little while, according to the quantity of thickness of skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with flour of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and arnoglossae leaves, and dove's blood, and kingfisher blood: let one part be taken from each: mix all these together, and spread them on cloth, and adhere them to the place until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the manner of cauterizing in cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter LI.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When a cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	The wise men said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	To me it does not seem right: because I fear that it will become an ulcer: and I have already seen this several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around it with a circle, as we have said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the manner of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter Fifty-Third.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess and it is slow to ripen, either because of the excess pus forming it, or because of the age of the patient, when he is decrepit with little blood, or because of time, and a desire to hasten the ripening of the abscess, then cauterize around it with small cauteries, puncturing many times.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let it go.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it itself will hasten with maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If, however, you wish to make a perforation with a cautery, then set the cautery on fire, which has this shape.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And lay him in the middle of Abulcati, until he penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be from what follows weak, so that it may lessen the course of purges.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the manner of cauterizing a bad corrosive wound.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Consumption is nothing but corruption in a moving member, and it consumes itself, like fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you see corrosion in a place which can tolerate cauterization with fire, then cauterize it with fire, much cauterium, small and large curettes, according to what is convenient for the place in which the corrosion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from every part until you eradicate the whole corruption, and nothing of it remains at all.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let him be dismissed for three days, and put on the places cauterized sulfur rubbed with oil, until all scabs are eradicated and all corruption is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for him with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days flesh is born with a healthy birth, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not, then apply the cautery again over that which remains from the corrupt places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And sometimes it is treated with a sharp medicine when corroding.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it rises in place of cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Nevertheless, a cautery with fire is quicker healing; and I indeed have already said cauterization of it with sharp medicine in division: therefore receive it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterization in the nails and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This pain often occurs in the lower parts of the feet; it is a large, thick mass that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed there is a cauterization in these things according to two modes: cauterization with fire, and cauterization with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As much as it is with fire, the cautery should be like a concave beak of a raven's feather; which is to be made from iron, according to the quantity that it contains nail from every part; and have a fine edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place it ignited upon a stick.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then roll the hand with a cautery around the nail until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail: and let it go for three days until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply a poultice of crushed willow bark with salt, and leave the poultice on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	It will be removed from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with ointment of flesh generation, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted, and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then administer to them cauterium with hot water: and it is, as you shall take a tube from copper, or iron, or from the wing of a bird: and place it over a spike, or an altlul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small quantity of hot water into the tube: hold your hand and turn it with pressure from your hand for a short time, so that the edge of the tube is pressed against the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail. And let the patient wait for about an hour after the application of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for the claw is removed with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Thus do with these one after another until you come upon all who are in the body from among them.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are removed, with what produces flesh from ointment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterization in trembling.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When someone has trembling from cold in a nerve, or from quartan fever, or otherwise: then it is necessary that you cauterize him with four cauteries, or five on the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra with cautery, and in his chest with cautery, and on his stomach with cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For tremor rests with the olive cautery and health hastens in the case of coldness of ailment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the method of cauterizing Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes foul matter, that is, pustules, are expelled from the body of Albathir, which are made from corrupt coarse materials.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, first of all, when they appear, it is necessary to cauterize the entire head of the boil with a fine cautery and myrtle wood, whose end has been set alight with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long birthwort.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lentil-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes the adhesions are cauterized at the beginning of their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase; and the superfluity breaking them, they heal from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	Nevertheless, it should be done after evacuation with venesection.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the manner of cauterization for blood flow from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many times blood flow occurs from an artery which has been cut at a wound, either externally or at the incision of a boil, or cautery of a limb, and similar things: and it becomes difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.
