Then cut the residue at the root of the lacrimal with a fine spatula, or with small forceps: and let go the natural flesh of the lacrimal, so that there does not happen from the incision of it a continuous flow of tears.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes a nail is extended with a hook, or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it shall be scraped with a spatula of moderate shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful, lest the spatula touch the corneal tunic and a rupture occur in it, and the pupil be pierced.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, put something of salt ground up, or from sifting made of zinia, into the eye and let it be until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary until he is healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the claw is not nerve-bearing and you cannot introduce a needle into it, nor does a hook fasten in it, then this kind of claw is cured many times with medicines, and heals as I have told in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to cut it, then open the eye of the sick person, and take a spatula subtle, gentle, of weak sharpness, according to this form.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And with a subtle shaving shave the area from above.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thin and breaks apart, and a razor imprint is made upon it, then distill from your hour into the eye an extract made from ziniar, or from red sief, or from ground salt: and cover the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then iterate over the same operation until the whole of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless it is contrary for you in the eye a hot abscess: then indeed dismiss that, and take care of the abscess, until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on it with reason until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	If the prominence of the lacrimal flesh harms the eye greatly, it should be suspended with a hook and a part of it incised; and do not make the incision to the end so that the flow of tears does not occur.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then a drop of wine (or made from zinc) in the tear sac, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On the incision of Alguardenic, and flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes in some human eyes there is born flesh red in color, composed or superimposed, until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or tightens over the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outward: and it resembles the stalk of a rose.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation in this also is that the sick person put his head in your bosom.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and collect that flesh whole with suitable hooks to it: and hold it with one forceps, or tongs.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first until the whole of it is finished with a cutting instrument.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And guard your eye so that you do not wound it during the operation: and let your incision be with the same thing which you cut with, or with a spatula, which we have told of in the incision of the nail: or with small scissors, with which one gathers the asbel, according to what will come its shape after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When therefore the incision is complete, and the whole algoudenici is removed, then fill the eye with salt ground; or distill into it a powder of red and similar to it from corrosive medicines; and place above the eye a cotton ball with the white of egg: so that it may be secured from a hot abscess.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If something from the blade remains and you have a hot blood flow, and fear a hot abscess; then release the eye, and treat it with that which will settle the abscess.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then iterate over it with the operation until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And similarly do with flesh added which happens in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the treatment of every weak eye, whether by natural or accidental way, be performed with iron: and do not put your hand into any of these operations until you see that that member is enduring that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On collecting the style from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	There are red veins that are woven over the eye and prevent the sight from carrying out its function: and they weaken the eye as the days lengthen.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore it is necessary for you first of all to consider if the eye in which there is a Sebel is strong and there is no other pain except Sebel; then collect the Sebel from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is, as you prescribe to the sick person, that he should put his head in your bosom.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one hook, or two according to your judgment: and let the hook be a fine doubled one, according to this form, or let there be two hooks graduated in one body, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those veins with subtlety, and wipe away the blood every hour until you see those veins removed from the eye, and resolved: and beware lest you wound the eye with the edges of the spatula.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in midday before the sun, and be firm in your operation greatly: that you do not cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then distill into the eye a green or red ointment: so that its sharpness corrodes what remains of the scab.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If it is not possible for you to collect the whole thing in that hour, then apply a poultice to the eye with something that will soothe the pain of the eye; and leave it for several days until the pain subsides; and secure it from hot suppuration; then repeat over it in the same way until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of the arrisatus to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Surgeons call a fistula an "Arissati," which they treat with cauterization, or with a sharp burning medicine, according to what has preceded in the narration.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it: unless you find a collection of pus at its birth, and extract the entire moisture which is in it and pus, until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore a bone is discovered, and you see in it corruption, or blackness, then scrape it with an instrument, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called Asperi head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron, and let its head be round like an azir, which is to be marked with the point of a file, or the point of a chisel with a fine point: and put it over the place corrupted in the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll it between your fingers, and you press your hand briefly until you know that the corruption is already scraped away; and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with medicinal dried astringents.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated, and flesh is born in it, and the course of healing is severed: and it remains for forty days, and is not renewed, and does not suppurate, and no accident happens in it: then know that it is now healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no talent in him, unless he reduces the fistula to the nostril opening, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is, as you remove from the bone with an iron instrument, or with a sharp medicine: and when the bone has been exposed, then take a borer according to this form, let its iron tip be triangular: and its wood be pyramidal extended to the end, just as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it over the bone itself: and let it be near the tear duct: and extend your hand away from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then roll your hand with the trephine until it penetrates the bone, and feel that it is yielding; by this you will find air coming out of it when you hold your hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the place with hemostatic and drying medicines, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore flesh is born and the place hardens, then the matter which was poured out to the exterior returns to the nose; therefore it is lighter upon the weak.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of the prominence of the eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes with its entirety, and there is no harm or diminution in vision, then it is necessary to loosen the diseased part; then let him make a bloodletting; afterwards place vents on the neck without scarification, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then put over the eye a liniment made of acacia, and aloe, and frankincense, and sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then tighten the eye from above over the plaster with many pads.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of a few is: that you may take soft cloths, many, and every cloth be doubled out of them over four: make many from these: then place them one upon another, according to the quantity which the Eye needs: then bind upon them with a hard cloth a strong binding.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And again wounds with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the wind-filled [parts], and leave the eye tightly closed day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligature softens again, then it is necessary that it be tightened a great deal; then remove the ligature after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If therefore you see the eye already returning to its white tunic, it is good; and if not, then repeat the plasters, and poultices, and constriction, and fomentations, until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	On the incision of the urinary tunic.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the tunic of the eye, then it protrudes and proceeds outside the eyelids like a grain of wheat, and the appearance of man is defiled because of it, and you wish to cut it: then the operation on it is, according to what I tell: and it is, that you introduce a needle into the root of the eye from the lower to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another needle into which there is a doubled thread from the lacrimal part, and make it penetrate: and let go of the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the place of the double thread, and tie with it the part of the vein on the circumference of the needle: and tighten it very much.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the point and put over the eye wool soaked in albuginea; and let it go until the thread falls with water.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with that which comforts it, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the eye is bound by a circle of cloth from every part until it gives great prominence.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then it is pierced with a fine spatula until it reaches the depth of the eye, and the albuminous moisture is scraped away, and the eye descends, and immediately enters; then it is tightened until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the treatment of dislocations.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment called Alcomnati is nothing else but a pus that gathers in the eye, similar to water descending, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the mode of operation in it is that you make the sick person sit on the prepared seat, or directly.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take the head in your hands from two parts, and move it until you see the stream arrive at the lower parts with your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it is fastened, so that it does not descend, and the opening is closed: and the sick person may see things as he used to see; and if it does not descend below, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If however the descent of the bowels is not prepared with that which we said, then make the sick person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a subtle spatula and find with it above the skin tissue near the continuation of the conjunctiva with the corneal tunic in the circle, until pus comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When he exits, then distill into the eye hot water in which you have mixed honey; or water in which you have already boiled hay and honey; then cure with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water which descends into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	Now we have discussed the kinds of water in division, and which is suitable for piercing, having explained it with words, then take that same thing according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Therefore you must make the sick person sit between your hands, square to the light, near the sun: and tie his healthy eye shut, and bind him firmly; then with your right hand, if the eye in which there is water is the left eye, or with your left hand, if the eye is the right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take with your right hand the almond if the eye is left; or with your left hand, if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the probe near the crown through the thickness of the radius in the apparent conjunctiva of the smaller lacrimal eye; then push the probe with force and you will turn your hand with it until it penetrates into the conjunctiva of the eye, and you feel that the probe has already reached the hollow.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey from the almond to the depth be the measure of the space which is from the pupil to the end of the blackness: and it is the circle of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see it in the pupil itself of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea tunic.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almond until it reaches the place where water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it downwards with one finger after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If therefore water descends, then the infirm person sees it above which he opens his sight immediately, and the almond in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If therefore water should flow down, then put it aside second, except that it may go out from the almond.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When therefore it is set, and does not ascend: then extract the almond with ease: and you revolve your hand gradually.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something of clear salt in water: and wash the eye inside with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place a whole wad of cotton wool or soaked wool steeped in rose oil, and with the membrane of an egg, and tie the eye together with it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, and those of our time, put upon it a mixture of ground cinchona with albumen of egg.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If the eyelid does not obey you at the entrance into the eye because of its hardness, because it is from men, whose eyes are hard indeed: then it is necessary that you take a spatula, which is called Alberid, whose shape this is.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore, perforate with it only that conjunction and not the last of your hand into the hole; and there is nothing but to make a way to the almond place subtle.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almagd, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And in the completion of your work, prepare for the sick person a room well-made, in which he may lie on his back in a dark house: and forbid him from all movements, and from coughing: and put food before him that soothes his nature: and let him not move his head right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the ligature remain according to its arrangement up to the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then solve it in that dark house, and try to experience its sight; and make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament up to the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not proper that he should do this at the hour of healing, or immediately after the incision: indeed, it is necessary that he transfer it elsewhere; because water ascends quickly through vigorous aspect.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however a hot abscess occurs: then it is necessary that you loosen the eye before the seventh day; and correct it with what soothes the abscess, until it is soothed; then loose its vision, and place over its face an oral [potion] which regulates its vision under those few days, itself being in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then he shall go out of the house gradually, and turn in his affairs.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in surgery a student is not excused from seeing often: then indeed he may dare about the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now indeed it has come to us from one of those who are from Al-Rayy, who said that a large hole was made in Al-Rayy, through which water is drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Truly, therefore, I saw no one in your land who has done that; nor did I read it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the kinds from the book, so that he who does not know them may stand upon them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of metal, and let their extremities be triangular with this same fineness, and the tip acute.
Formae magda.	The shapes of wounds.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the treatment of flesh born in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes fleshy growths of a different kind are born in the nose, of which some resemble the legs of many scorpions: and from this there is cancerous flesh, stony, dusky colored: and from this there is also flesh that is soft, not dusky coloured.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In those things which are from these flesh is gentle, not deceitful, nor cancerous, it is necessary that you make the sick person sit between your hands opposite the solid one, and open his nostrils, and throw in a hook to those flesh: then draw them to the outside, and cut what you have grasped from them with a sharp fine spatula on one side, until you know that all the flesh has already been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If something remained of it whose cutting is not possible: then carefully remove that with one fine instrument with ease, until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood governs you, or if a hot abscess occurs, then oppose it with what is necessary. Or if it is from malignant abscesses, then hasten to cauterize it, until the blood is cut off, and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then vinegar, water, or wine is poured into the nose after incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose is opened and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then know that it is already healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that within it is flesh born in the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument does not reach when cut.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore, you must insert a linen thread which has some thickness, and many knots in it. And place between every knot the quantity of a finger, or less. And instruct the infirm man, that he may put one end of the thread into the nose with a stick, or as much as is possible to him after he has made himself a similar probe. And draw his scent until it reaches the cavity, and emerges above his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many times indeed boys like this Attomi make similar things in schools: and it is a thing easy for him who wants to.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then put two ends of thread, one end which comes out over the nose, and the other which remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then and with a minister lock of flesh with knots that are on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is already with thread knots.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then extract the thread and place it in the nose after removing the blood clot which you absorbed with the ointment of Egypt: do this for three days or more until the ointment corrodes all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put a lead tube into the nose at the end of the matter for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however it requires treatment that will dry it out, use this.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	To make a cauterizing head, with which oil and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make it of silver or copper: that it be like a small lamp, open like a shell: and its passage similarly.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making a cautery should be full and open: which has a handle at its end, with which you hold it when you heat oil in it, or what you wish from juices, and flowing substances.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the treatment of a nosebleed.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many times a tumor is born at the extremity of the nose, and it grows larger, and increases with days until its appearance becomes foul.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	Therefore, it is necessary that at the beginning of its appearance, one should cut into it and eradicate its roots completely.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place upon the site either a cautery or burning medicine which stands in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If therefore the incision is delayed until it has become enlarged, then consider if it is stony, hard, dusky colored, with few senses; then do not touch it with iron, for it is a cancerous abscess.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many times I have seen those who had a bloody abscess and because of it great evil happened to him who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the abscess is gentle to the touch, not dusky in color, and you see that incision is possible throughout its entirety, then evacuate the sick person, and make an incision into it without fear or trembling: and care for the place with something that dries and constricts, until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, and lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	Know that when a rupture of continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, little is accomplished by operating on it, except in some men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when something of that sort happens to someone, you should consider if it is a wound recent with its blood; and then gather the edges of the wound together with suture; then care for it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the lips of the continuity have already been separated, and each part has been made healthy: then it is necessary that the curette be scraped over the entire part with its sharp edge until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then gather the two lips together with a suture, and tighten them, and pulverize on top of it dragon's blood and ground frankincense: and put above the powders a piece of diaphana plaster, and of some other solidifying plaster: and leave it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then dissolve it itself, and change the medicine: and dismiss it until the threads are cut by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suturing is that you bring together the edges of continuity, either with awls, as we recounted in the suturing of the abdomen: or you bring together the edges with thread, as I have made you know.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the extraction of lip nodes.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people experience abscesses on their inner lips, similar to hard grains of grain, some smaller and some larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary that you convert the lip and bind over every node of it, and suspend it with a hook, and cut it from every part.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the incision with crushed zeger, until the blood is stopped.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then it is to be covered with vinegar, and the place where there is clotting is to be cared for with it until the wounds are healed.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On incisions in the flesh above the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many times there is born on the gum flesh which the ancients call an abulus.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore it is necessary that you suspend it with a hook: or hold it with forceps, and cut it at its root, and let the pus run out, or the blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on the rubbed wound site, or other styptic powders, drying ones.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If that flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut into it again and cauterize it: for it does not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On the extraction of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes they gather on the surfaces of the teeth from the inner and outer part, and between the gums, rough, coarse, and sometimes they become blackened, and yellowish, and greenish, until corruption comes from it to the gums, and the teeth become foul because of it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore, you ought to make the infirm sit between your hands, and his head in your bosom, and grind and gnaw, at that which appears to you as bark, and a thing similar to sand: until there remains nothing of them, and similarly do with blackness, and greenness, and yellowness, and others until they are purified.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore that which is in them from the beginning of reason is taken away, it is good: and if not, then repeat upon them the reason on another day, second, and third, until the last study comes to that which you wish.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that a tooth needs razors of various forms and figures: according to how it is prepared for your operation; therefore, the razor with which a tooth is shaved from the lower part is different from the razor with which a tooth is shaved between teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these forms of razors should be prepared for you, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the Extraction of Tooth Pain.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that you treat the tooth of its pain with every skill and delay in its extraction.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is nothing that can replace it when it is removed: because it is a sublime substance: so that when there is no excuse for its removal, then when the sick man is forced to remove it, he must strengthen and make sure of the aching tooth with you.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For often pain deceives the sick person and thinks that it is in a tooth and pulls it out; then the pain does not cease until the bad tooth is pulled out.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have now seen that from the operation of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When therefore a tooth aching is certified to you, then it is necessary that you scarify around the tooth with a spatula, in which there is some virtue, until the gum is loosened from every part; then move it with your fingers, or with slender forceps at first little by little, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the large forceps in that spot and the head of the patient between your knees: which you have already held well so that it is not moved; then pull the tooth according to its straightness so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If therefore it does not emerge, then take some one of those instruments and introduce it under it from every side with facility, and endeavor its motion, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If, however, the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary to fill that hole with cloth; and bind it with the extremity of a fine wire, so that it does not break at the time of your constriction upon it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary that you act with great care when making an incision around the gum from every part very much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And keep your strength, so that you do not break it, and may its part remain, and return over the sick from that evil which is greater pain of his first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware, lest you do what ignorant bloodletters do in their haste and boldness over its removal, besides administering that which we have recounted.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many times indeed they cause great illnesses to happen to men, the more difficult of which are those that break and the roots of them all remain, or some of them; or that they extract it with some bones of the jaw: as we have testified many times this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it shall be covered after its removal with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If it happens that blood flows from places (for this often happens), then smear something from the ziziphus and fill the place with it: and if not, cauterize it if you cannot apply ziziphus.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of the fine forceps used first for moving a tooth should have long handles and short grips, thick so that they do not fold when pressure is applied upon a tooth with them; like you see in thick handles, until when you tighten with them, they do not bend themselves nor fold; short handles, and be made of iron, or of well-crafted brass, straight handles. And at their ends should be teeth, some of which enter into others, and tighten by decent, strong constriction.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes extremities are formed like the beak of a bird called a stork, and they have strong constrictions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the removal of teeth and the extraction of fractured jawbones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When something remains at the site of a broken tooth's removal, then you must place over the customary spot some butter for one or two days until the place softens; then introduce into it an instrument, or forceps: whose ends are similar to the beak of a bird that is called a stork.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape of this is forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Let their extremities be made like a file inward: or like an awl.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If therefore it does not obey you towards the exit with these forceps, then it is necessary that you dig above the root, and uncover the whole flesh, and introduce the instrument which is called the Small Lever, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Let the short end of the limb be rather coarse and not too wet so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root comes out through that, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to help with these other instruments whose shapes are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first triangular extremity, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	Shape of a triangular extremity fine.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument having two branches, whose shape is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools which preceded in the extraction of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also let there be an instrument with this, which is similar to a large hook, of this form, triangular extremity twisted, in which there is something of thickness so that it does not break: and let it be not soaked.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that instruments for the teeth are many: and similarly the rest of the instruments are not counted, and a prudent artificer, subtle in his art, finds for himself the instrument, according to what the operation signifies to him and the pains themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because they are from agricultural implements, for which the ancients did not say what instruments, because of the diversity of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If a bone of the jaw or other bones of the mouth is broken, or if it rots: then examine it in its place with that which is fitting to it from the instruments and forceps which I have said in the extraction of roots, and help with a clamp, whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be something of a size gradually inserted so that it is tightened or held with the bone, and not escape and leak, until the bone emerges; and restore the place with suitable medicines to it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is a small amount of decay in the bone, then scrape away the decay from it, and take care of it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the closing of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, an ugly form is produced: and especially when this happens in women and girls, namely those of the genitals.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore you ought to consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	If a tooth is born after another tooth and does not fit, or it is possible to lock it, nor file it; then eradicate it: and if it is attached with another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, whose shape is this.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is similar to a small beak, and it is made of Indian iron, with a very sharp tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be such that you cut it on many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that another tooth is not moved.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, it is protruding and exposed from its rasping, then scrape it with a rasp from within, whose form is this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let the entire instrument be from India, and the handle of it have many small punctures, like a file with which needles are made: With which one grinds the tooth gradually in many days with ease, so that the tooth is not moved, and falls out; then smooth it, at the end scrape it with certain razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is a tooth that is broken and injures the tongue, then it should be filed down until the roughness of the fracture is removed and it is leveled, smoothed, and does not injure the tongue or corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the binding of teeth with gold wire
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth are shaken and bruised by a blow or accident; and the weak one cannot hold it together when eating so that it does not fall out; and you have treated them with astringent medicines, and the treatment has not been effective; then the ingenuity is in them to be tied together with gold thread; because silver becomes green and rots after days; but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the thread be of medium thickness and coarseness according to the amount it will take between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the suture is, that you take a thread, and insert twice its length between two healthy teeth: then weave with both ends of the thread between the moved teeth, whether one be, or more, until you come with the suture up to the healthy tooth of the other part.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the texture until you reach the part from which you began: and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom, until it is not moved at all: and let your constriction where you tighten the thread be at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not escape.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut the ends of the superfluous thread with scissors: and gather both together, and turn them with a twist: and conceal them between the sound tooth and the moved tooth, so that it does not harm the tongue: then let it be let go as tightly as it remains.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it is loosened, or cut, bind them together with another thread, and it will remain so throughout the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of Teeth, and the figure of the rotation of two sound teeth, and two moved teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one or two teeth return to their places after an injury, and they remain as we have narrated, and this is done only by a skilled and experienced artificer.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a piece of bone from the rib is fitted and shaped like a tooth, and it is put in its place, so that the tooth is fortified and held together, as we have said; and it remains, and serves with it for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On the cutting of the ligament that happens under the tongue and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament which occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which man is born, or accidental, from a wound that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation on it is, that you open the mouth of the infirm person in his head in your bosom, and elevate his tongue; then cut that nerve ligament acrosswise until the tongue be loosed from its restraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is something hard and knotted in it, and it is from the consolidation of a wound, then throw into it a hook, and find it across its width, until you cut the ligament, and the knot is loosened.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And beware lest there be a fissure in the deep flesh, and you cut the artery there, and there occur a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then the wound is to be rinsed with rose water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a linen ligature which the sick man should keep in throughout the night so that it does not harden again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If blood flow should occur, then place a crushed piece of zege over the site.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood overcomes you, then cauterize the place with a rusty cautery which is suitable for it; then care for it with the rest of the cure until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the extraction of a ranula which occurs under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes a tumor occurs under the tongue that resembles a small frog, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function; and perhaps it magnifies so much that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation in this is, that you open the wound of the sick person before the sun: and consider the abscess.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If therefore you see it of a dark color, or black, hard, which does not find the feeling of the sick person; then do not touch it, because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it is inclined to softness, in which there is moisture, then throw into it the hook and cut it with a fine spatula, and free it from every part.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood overcomes you during the hour of your operation, then place crushed ziziphus on it until the blood is stopped; then return to your operation until you have extracted it with its entirety.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it shall be covered with vinegar and salt; and care for it with the rest of the appropriate treatment until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the treatment of an abscess of the two tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes things happen between the throat and godad, that is, glands, which resemble algodad, which happen deforis: and they are named two Amigdalae: which when care with what we said in the division, and do not heal, then consider.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If therefore it is a hard abscess, dusky in color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of ruby color and its root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather let it alone until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either you will pierce it yourself or it will burst open of its own accord.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in color, round, and its root is fine: then it must be cut.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation is this, that you consider before your operation, if its hot abscess has quieted and completed in quiet, or diminished by some diminution: then do so to make the sick man sit facing the sun, and his head be in your bosom: and open his mouth, and let a serving person receive between his hands, and press down his tongue below with an instrument, whose form is this.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or copper, that is as fine as a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When therefore you have laid the tongue aside with it, and an abscess is shown to you, and falls upon it your gaze: then receive a hook, and fix it in the tonsil, and draw it out to the outside as much as you are able, except that you pull along with it something from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with an instrument, whose form follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It is like forceps: however, the extremities of it are curved so that the opening of each one is directly opposite to the other's sharpness; therefore care should be taken that it be made of iron tempered, or wood soaked in alum.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut it with a spatula, whose shape is this.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Be sharp on one side, not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut one tonsil, cut the other following this same type of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, the patient gargles with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If blood flow should occur to him, gargle with water in which the barks of pomegranate trees have been boiled: or myrtle leaves, and similar things from styptics, until the blood flow is stopped; then care for him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes abscesses are born in the throat, other than the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore, cut it according to what I said in the incision of two tonsils equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I myself had treated a woman from an abscess that was formed between her throat, which she drew to the groin, few senses, because it had almost closed her throat; and the woman breathed through a narrow passage, and it had already prevented her eating, and drinking water; and she had already approached death, if she had remained for one day or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had grown so large that it had produced two branches until they emerged above the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I therefore hastened and fixed one of them hooks.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I drew it out, and a large portion was drawn out from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then cut it where it is grasped from the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did that which had proceeded from the other nostril opening.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened his mouth and pressed on his tongue: and afterwards I fixed a hook into the abscess; then I cut away part of it from him, and there came out of it only a little blood: therefore the woman's throat was healed, and she immediately began to drink water, and then she took some food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	Therefore I did not cease to cut into that abscess many times over a long period; and an abscess followed in the place where I cut, until it was prolonged too much and with it that.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore, I devised and cauterized an abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	Therefore I stood after the addition; then I walked from the place, and I did not know what God did with it after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the incision of a boil.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrh descends to the vulva and forms a pus-filled abscess and is long, then it is called perpendicular. And if it is in the lower part large and round, then it is called a vulva.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated as we have said in the division, and the treatment does not help: and you see that the hot abscess has calmed down from it, and is subtle: then it is necessary that you cut into it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which from it is gathered round and does not have length to it, and is bloody or dusky in color, or black, and does not have sensation; then it is necessary that a surgeon make an incision of it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	There is fear over the weak in that.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the measure which I have said, and its length, so that you make the sick person sit facing the sun: and press his tongue with the instrument, of which the foregoing account has been made; then fix the hook in the uvula, and draw it down: and cut it with one of the two instruments which I have said in the incision of the two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut from it except what is added above the natural term without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	If you cut from that more deeply,  you will injure the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use that which we have narrated concerning the incision of the two tonsils: and take care of it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the patient fears the incision: then it is necessary that you use ingenuity in cauterization of him without fear and trembling.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the way of cautery on it is not except with sharp water and it is that you put the head of the sick person into your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press down the tongue of him with the instrument that we said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and mix it with lime that is not extinguished, and put it in this instrument, neither thick nor thin, and fill its cavity with it, whose form is this.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the extremity where medicine is placed be concave, like the cavity of a snail's shell.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with medicine on the wound itself: and let the sick person lie on his side so that saliva from his mouth runs inward from the medicine, so that it does not descend into his throat and harm him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you will from the first apply it upon the wound with a quantity of half an hour, until you see it already darkened and the inflammation calmed by medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to receive a bandage and wrap it over the end of the radius bone, and fill the bandage with medicine, and introduce the radius bone with the bandage into a tube from above, until the bandage adheres to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times until you achieve what you desire from the cauterization of the vein.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it be left alone: for it hardens and falls off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you wish to repeat the medicine, repeat it: and after cauterization wipe around the wound with a cloth dipped in butter, and cleanse it with that which is around it from the medicine: and cover it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And it is treated externally with compresses, and internally with gargles, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This kind of treatment therefore is more healthful by cutting and farther from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes a wound is treated even with that which is more subtle than cautery and incision: for it is treated with fumigation, according to this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take a cloth and hyssop and oregano and rue and sage and chamomile and wormwood, and similar herbs: and gather all these, or some of them, in a pot, and let them be submerged with vinegar, and let them boil: and the pot should be lined with clay properly: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which an instrument is placed hollow according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made from silver or copper, and let the end, in which is the grain, be introduced into the bone of the infirm person until vapor ascends to the tube above the cannula, until the tube becomes much darkened.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times until it stops.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, lest you make this cure at the beginning of the arrival of an abscess.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Generally he adds this in an abscess: and it ought not to be done unless at the time of the subsidence of its heat.
