Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If this instrument is not present to you, then take a tube and put cork at its end so that the bone of the infirm does not burn; because cork prevents steam from burning the bone; and this is from good care with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of splinters and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times something adheres to the throat, either a fish bone or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore it is necessary that you remove what appears from them above which falls the sight, after pressing the tongue with an instrument near the sun, and it is declared to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary that you make a vomiting weak before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps indeed the thing joined will emerge through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Let the sick person swallow a piece of breadcrumb, or lettuce root, or a mouthful of dry bread; or take a piece of dried marine sponge soft: and bind it with thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it comes to the place where the spines or bone are, and it is drawn out, then it issues forth.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with that which we said: then use an instrument of lead according to this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius somewhat, and at the end of it there should be a curvature, so that it may enter its throat with ease; and let itself have its head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis, so that he does not get a cough, and drive it in with his mouth, or spine, or introduce himself with his own hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Truly it is better if the infirm one inserts, that is, because of his knowledge of the place of the thing annexed: and he pushes down or draws his hand with an instrument up, the whole thing according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it emerges.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of Leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with that which I said in the division from healing with medicines, and it does not help, then consider in the throat of the sick one in front of the sun, or in the sun after pressing his tongue with the instrument that I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon a leech, remove it with a small hook, or with a thin stick carefully.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with these things: then take a concave tube, and insert it into the throat of the sick person up to near the gullet: then insert into the concavity of the tube iron ignited with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the sick person abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full mouthful of cold water, and open his mouth in it: and put his mouth into it, and do not swallow anything from it: and move the water every hour with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For when a leech feels water, it immediately falls.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not come out as we have narrated, then fumigate the sick person with cinders, or with asa and the instrument which I have narrated in the fumigation of the vulva.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that many times because it will fall.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is, to take a pot, in which are live plums with fire: and let the pot be covered with a cover, in the middle of which there is a hole: and let the extremity of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw in the fumigation, and let the sick person put their mouth at the end of the tube, and close their mouth so that the fumigation does not go out until you know that the fumigation has already reached the bloodsucker.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall off.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the weak person endure thirst, and eat salty food, and other things, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that he go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which bloodsucker is extracted from the throat, when it falls upon it itself.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: unless because it has this curve that goes into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a bird called a stork, in which there is the roughness of a file: when it seizes something, it does not let go of it at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of abscesses, and their incision, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of abscesses, of many modes, according to how their remembrance comes, namely one and one in this book: and they are diverse in the piercing of them, and in the cutting of them from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is of the kind of abscesses within itself, and that which it contains from moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is because of the places where it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess occurring in the head is different from an abscess occurring in the anus: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place is different from an abscess occurring in the joints: and to each of these belongs its own judgment from the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from abscesses there are some which ought not to be pierced, except after the ripening of the pus within them, and the completion of it: and there are also some which ought to be pierced while they are raw, and do not ripen according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like boils that are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess when it happens near a joint and is prolonged to be until it rots what is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: therefore it is a closer cause of contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess in the main limb: for if you delay its piercing until it matures, it will harm either it or through that member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is near the anus, pierce it immaturely: and let it not be pierced if it is a raw abscess, not completely digested, except if it is near the anus so that it does not rot deeply, and lengthens to the interior of the anus, and becomes a fistula, or becomes at its end what does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary for you to know the hour of perforation of an abscess, which has matured according to its course: and it is in the sedation of pain, the recession of fever, and the diminution of redness, and pulse, and the sharpness of the head of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower part of the abscess and the more prominent eminence: and let the perforation be deep in length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of the arms, and tendons, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflex.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those which are reflected, go with a piercing according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When a boil is in fleshy places, it is better that you release its opening until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there is much dirt and filth, and perhaps the lips of it and its depth will endure.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are pierced according to the width of the body as necessity demands; or according to what the limb needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer in small abscesses a small perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation; or many sections according to the similarity of the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And they are from abscesses, in which it is necessary that the skin be concaved; and it should be cut when it has already been made like a cloth, and has come to an end, that which has already died: such as what happens in many, that it swells, and with buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among these are those which are cut with a cutting instrument having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And of these there is one which occurs like a myrtle leaf in figure.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an inguinal abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And of these there are those in which a round incision is administered, and a lunar incision: and similar incisions to these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	For that one who does not have a head, such as superficial ulcers and boils, it is necessary that he be pierced with a superficial perforation, or only leveled.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when an abscess is large and has already collected much pus, and you pierce it, that you do not hurry and extract all the pus in that hour; rather, extract a part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then the pus should be left alone until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the gradation, until it emerges: especially if he is weak of virtue, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old man decrepit: for the animal spirit is much dissolved from the animal with the emission of humors: and perhaps the weak one dies, and you do not perceive.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, pay great heed to this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated it, through which you perforate the abscesses, it is necessary that you cleanse the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound is of a small abscess, or is a flat incision, then administer a lint made from linen, or old cloth.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if it is a large abscess, and there are many fissures of the opening, then it is necessary that you introduce into each fissure liniment, until they reach each other.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in an abscess you have cut away a part of the skin, or in the surrounding area scooped it out; then it is necessary that you fill it with old dung, or as when it is covered with cloth, or shaved linen wool without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it out, and take care of it with what is necessary from ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If blood should flow during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after having soaked a cloth in them: and place it over the location of the bleeding many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If however the flow of blood persisted, then it is necessary that you administer a regimen and treatment and powders which I have recounted in many places in this our book, and from the division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in wintertime, and the place of the abscess is among many nerves, then it is necessary that you pour warm pills with wine and oil, and place them over the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it be in summer, and the places are fleshy: then it is necessary that you place poultices soaked in water, and oil, or him with wine and oil, and the whole thing cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then it is necessary that you loosen the abscess and cleanse it, and administer to it what is fitting for its cure, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the knowledge of the treatment of abscesses universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method of distinction, I have already said about every abscess, how the way is to its cure individually and separately.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of boils that occur in the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XL I .
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the scalp skin, and they are of the kind of boils, which contain sacs, like little pouches made from a hen's gizzard.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of these some are fatty; and of these some contain moisture similar to clay; and of these some contain moisture similar to gruel and porridge: and the like, and of these there are also those which are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting of all, and their extraction there is no fear, as long as in their cutting it does not oppose the artery.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on their incision is that you should explore it with an instrument whose form comes after these, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	If it contains moisture, then dry it out by cutting it lengthwise with a shallow incision: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with a cut from line b to line g. When therefore the moisture is evacuated, then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture, and do not let anything whatever escape from it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many times indeed it returns, if anything remains of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse a sponge in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will eat away what remains from the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then again pass over the same tumor with the Egyptian knife second and third, and if it does not digest with that, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then take care of the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If it contains a fleshy node, then cut it according to this form, with the incision shaped like a cross: and throw hooks between the edges of the incision, and scrape it from every part: and endeavor your strength in extracting the tunic that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If an artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you after this.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in an abscess, if it is stony, from incision, and cure the same, according to what we said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And incision over a stony abscess is easier; because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses that are in the head in some men, with which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Because I cut into an abscess on the head of an elderly woman and found the abscess like a hard and solid stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; and if someone struck it with something thrown, it would wound that thing.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other boils that occur on the head, besides those which occur in the heads of children and at the roots of the ears, the section of all of them should be a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or place the perforation of them always from the lower part of them, so that the flow of healing may be relieved downward.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for him as is fitting from healing.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the cutting away of strictures in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck, and under the arms, and in the groin: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those things that happen to them in the neck are some one thing and many: and they arise from each other: and every Strophula from them is inside its own tunic, just as it is in nodes and boils of the head, just as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these Strophulas.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these there are stones: and from these there are those that contain moistures: and from these there are malignant ones, which do not obey healing.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that which therefore you see of good disposition in touch, whose manifest color is near to the skin, and moves to every part, and is not joined with nerves of the neck, nor with guidegi, nor with artery, nor is it deep: it is necessary that you cut it with a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body from line b to line g, and scrape it from every side: and extend the two lips of skin with a hook, or with many hooks, if you need them, as we have said in abscesses of the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is a precaution, so that vein or nerve may not be injured.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the spatula not be too sharp: so that it does not add your hand with the incision, or disturb the sick one, and you cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you cut a vein or artery, or if it prevents you from operating, then put crushed zeigee or some powders that stop bleeding into the wound, and bind the wound, and let it be until the sharpness of the abscess has subsided, and the wound has softened: or until it begins to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is severed with a knife, therefore return to your operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then with your index finger examine if anything remains of the other small strophulis; therefore, cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If the great vein is in the root of a strangulated hernia, then it is necessary that you do not cut the hernia from its root: rather, it is necessary that you tie it with a doubled strong thread, and let it go until it falls by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound on the belly, which you have already submerged in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it itself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole Strophula is cut, then it is necessary to join the two lips of the wound, and itself immediately after you see that there remains no superfluity at all.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there remains an excess because of the size of the Strophula, then it is necessary to extend [it] to cut its root and remove it; and administer the suture which we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what contains moisture from the Strophuli, perforate it with a superficial perforation: so that the place of its maturity appears to you: and place the perforation below that which follows in the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation a liniment with ointment, and similar things, so that it corrodes what remains from the corruption, until when you see the wound already cleansed: then take care of it with an ointment that generates flesh, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the incision of the epiglottis due to an abscess inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said this incision is in the Epiglottis, and I did not see anyone in our land who has made it: and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those having a synanchia, it is necessary that the section of the Epiglottis be made; when no help is given by it; because all veins and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or at both tonsils, when there is no pain in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the Epiglottis to avoid the destruction which is done from before-mentioned preparation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to cut the epiglottis, it must be cut under three or four circles of the epiglottis with a small incision across its width, in that which is between the two circles by the quantity that the section should be in the soft tissue, not in cartilage: and this place is convenient for the section because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are distant.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then he ought to extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he finds the skin until he comes to the channel: he cuts the vessels of blood if he sees anything from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the fistula as we have said; and it is signified over the incision of the channel from the phlegm that flows out of it, with that which is broken up, and the cutting away of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the open wound be left for a while.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour is removed in which the foreclosure is feared, gather together the two lips of the skin wound, and sew its own alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines which cause flesh to grow, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discourse which we narrated, is not an exposition, unless they see that some of these abscesses has already opened the throat of the sick person: and the patient has been raised above death, and wishes to be intersected by his breath: They go to cut the epiglottis, so that the sick person may breathe over the place of the wound with some respiration, and be saved from death: and for this reason they ordered the open wound to be left alone until the malice of the illness is consumed, and its malice is three days, and as such: then therefore they ordered it to be sutured and cared for until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw with my own eyes, is that a maidservant took a knife and put it into her throat, and it struck the part of the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called upon to treat him, and I found him moaning, as is the moaning of a dead man.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore examined the wound and found blood that had come out of the wound a little.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore I was confused that she had not cut away the vein, nor had guided it; and wind was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore I attended to his wound and cared for it until it was healed; and nothing happened to the girl except a hoarseness in her voice; and she returned after days to better disposition of herself.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say: that there is no fear in the incision of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the incision of a groin hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess called Hernia gutturis, is a large abscess, according to the color of the body: and it is much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	It is not natural certain talent.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	An accident is according to two modes: one of which is like swollen knots.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And another method is similar to an abscess which occurs from ligation of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it ought not to be presumed upon with a knife unless in what is small; and you prove it, and investigate it with the probe.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a fatty lump and is not suspended with any veins: then cut it as nodes are cut: and remove it with what it contains from the cyst, if it is in a cyst; and if not, then examine the whole of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place as much as is necessary until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On cutting open swellings called Nodes.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodules, and I have already said all their kinds in the division: and it is necessary that I tell here the difference between a Node and an Fistula: when there is doubt making.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	Therefore I say, that when the heat and fever and violent pains have subsided until the boiling of excess is calmed and putrefaction is complete, then indeed the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When a knot is present there is no heat, nor fever, nor pain, and it contains them in its own bag called sifachin which corresponds to the color of the body. And its beginning is like a chickpea, and it becomes like a batecha, and it is greater or lesser.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fat: or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of humidity are many, according to what I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to the treatment of a Node, you must examine it, and inquire into it first with the instrument that is called an Intromissor, according to what will come its form in the chapter that is after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way to investigate abscesses and all kinds of knots is that you take this instrument and insert it into the moister place which you find in the abscess; and you revolve your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has already pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then your last hand according to the measure of the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw what was inserted, and consider what comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore a running humidity occurs, whatever its color may be; then dry it with a superficial incision, according to what I have said in the rest of the abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if humidity does not exit in the place of introduction, then you know that it is fat: therefore, make a cut over it having the form of a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you; and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from every part with ease; and guard the cyst if you can on it, so that you may extract it whole with the knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the bladder bursts during the operation, and it is not possible to remove the whole thing intact, since this happens often, then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If anything remains from it, whether a little or a lot, a Node returns according to the most.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it conquers you, and there remains little from it, then fill the wound at its completion with some sharp corrosive powders; and bind the wound, and place above it what sits pus hot, and care for it with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore the knot is large, then sew its two lips together, and take care of it as with that which is incarnate.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however the pulsating or non-pulsating vein is opposite to you, then hasten and fill the place with crushed zegi, and loosen it for two or three days, until the wound putrefies and the boiling of blood rests; then return to cutting that which remains from the Knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	On instruments used for incision and piercing of the mouth.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are forms of intromittors, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From these there is a great one, and from these there is a medium one, and from these there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let pointed instruments of square ends be made from iron, so that they hasten entry into an abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experiences, and no, that is, piercing: and one of them is named beris, that is, piercing: and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these there is a large, and a medium, and a small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	It is necessary that these abscesses, and openings, and fistulas, and buboes be investigated by what is between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And for others are made round, smooth, blunt, like large needles which they insert under the buttocks, from citron, or copper, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better ones are made from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also made with black lead, which is suitable for experiencing fistulas, whose concavity is reflections, so that they are reflected with their softness with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because some are long, some medium, and some short, according to the quantity of the width and constriction of it.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of hooks, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because these are simple ones, that is, those which have one care: and they are three kinds as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And of these are blind pouches, and there are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And of these there are hooks having two curves, and there are three kinds: and of these there are hooks having three curves, and there are three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the shapes of scalpels, with which knots and abscesses are cut and scraped; and there are three kinds: because among them is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	The ends of those which are cut are sharp, the other ends are not sharp: and they are not put thus, unless that help may be given to them in the scraping of Tumors at the fear of incision of a vein, or nerve: and that the weak may be healed by them, and find somewhat of tranquility from burning as he finds in the scraping of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magdala, and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of metal and are similar to a distilling apparatus, with which alcohol is made; and at the wide end there is a point hidden by a spatula; and through it it runs inwards and outwards when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of splints which are hidden between the fingers at the perforation of an abscess; and the sick do not perceive them; and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Wounds of the winds with which blood flow is cut off; and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of copper, or citron, round, of short length, as you see: and let them be fine.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of Winds be with you large and small, so that you may cut blood by them with speed when necessity requires, and then when medicine is not present to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them for cutting blood in every place of the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as the hamstrings of the leg, and hip, and the wounds of the arms, and nipples, and belly, and groin, and the like of these, from fleshy, moist incisions.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they make small instruments from these similar to the cortices of a fist, according to their shape: with which blood is cut when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of the nipples of humans which are like the nipples of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the nipples of certain men swell during sleep (that is, when they begin to dream) until they resemble the nipples of women, and they remain festering with pus.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	He who shuns this, let him cut above the nipples with a lunar section, according to this form from line b to line g. Then flay the entire fatness.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill the wound with medicinal plaster.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with suture, and care for it until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If the nipple inclines downwards and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that two incisions similar in shape to a crescent moon be made on its two upper sides, each one containing the other at the edges of both, until there is a larger line enclosing the smaller, according to this form from line b. to line g. Afterwards, scrape the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and administer what we have said about sutures and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not deem it necessary to make an incision of it, because of the restlessness of the sick man, or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with a poultice submerged in corrosive ointment, and leave it, until it corrodes what remains of the fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On perforating an abscess that occurs under the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur under the nipple are of the kind of hard boils, which contain cysts, and from these there are those which contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those which contain humidities, ought to be cut with a lunar section, according to this form, from line b. to line g. When therefore the whole that is in the abscess is evacuated of blood, then fill it with cotto vetri, and dismiss it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the tumor, and treat it with an appropriate ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If it is an abscess from the type of knots of Strophulus, then cut over it, as we said in the section on cutting over Strophulus equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If the wound extends so that it discharges pus, then administer a cautery to it, according to what we have said previously.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs because of an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is torn and the skin above it is sutured, often many times a boil occurs from there, and similarly with veins, so that a boil and swelling occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and inflammation are due to artery and vein are: because when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long, gathered deep in the body: and when you push on the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there were a scraping sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is for the vein, is round on the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And a section above this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and groins, and neck, and in many places of the body: and it is very great.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary that his care be cured with iron, and what from those also is at the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary that it be cured.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, upon that which is from them through the inflation of the opening of the Artery, make a cut in the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, afterwards the Artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is uncovered.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert under it a needle, and make it penetrate to the other side, and bind the Artery with a doubled thread in two places, according to what I have taught you in the extraction of the two Arteries which are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place which is between two ligaments with a lancet, until all the blood that is in it comes out and the abscess is loosened.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a treatment that produces pus until the ligaments fall away; afterward care for it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an abscess due to the cutting of a vein, then you should hold with your hand as much as possible of the abscess with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a needle under the place which you have held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and let there be in it a thread double, until you withdraw it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the ligature with the abscess itself with a good ligature; according to what I told you about the ligature of the uterus, from two parts with two ends of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you fear that the thread being removed will cause trouble, then introduce another needle with a different thread under the entire abscess at the incision; press and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry up the abscess in its middle until it discharges what is within; then cut away the excess skin and release what was bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place over that little bit which you have submerged in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer treatment, which is done with lead and ointment, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On an abscess that occurs from a twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in an artery and vein, so it also occurs in a nerve; which happens to them through percussion, or from excessive labor, and the like: and it is most common in those places of the assistants, or the heel, and in every place where joints move: and it is a serious abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body, and it is found in many positions without pain: and when it is squeezed with force, it feels like a stupor in it, as if weak.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess collected deep in the body, but it is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go to the anterior parts, nor forward or backward to the posterior parts.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, what is in the joints from these things, it ought not to be invaded with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps contraction may occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that which is in the head, or on the forehead, cut the skin with a knife.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore the abscess is small, then hold it with forceps and cut it away from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and scrape it; then remove it, and gather the wound together with suture; and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On cutting an abscess that occurs in the belly.
Caput LI.	Chapter L I.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Certain people experience, many times, in their bellies and in other parts of their bodies, growths which are called Fungalia, because of their similarity to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is slender, and their heads are thick, and their lips are turned inward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is a small part among these: and there is a great part that is highly magnified.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I have indeed seen a man, and in his belly there were two tumors, which were more like mushrooms than other things: there was no difference between them, white, small roots, and their lips were reversed, and they could be found, and moisture ran out of them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore, I cut into it, and I found in one side as much as X and VIII ounces, and in the other side as much as VI ounces. And the operation in cutting them is, that you consider then, if the patient is moist and the color is white, moist, and subtle of root: then cut it with a wide spatula, and have cautery in fire present.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled during its section: therefore if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a weak and timid patient afraid of the cut with iron, then take a lead wire properly made and tie it with it to the athleul. Its method is what we said, and release him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the constriction.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore, you should not stop tightening the lead until it is pressed into the drill and cuts off by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the root be thick, then there is some fear and trembling in its incision, especially because it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless, it is possible to cut its half.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the wound until it is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to cut into that which is dusky in color, with few sensations, and of foul appearance: for this is a cancerous abscess: and I shall come back after this with a remembrance of Cancer.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A protrusion of the umbilicus occurs from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures which are above the belly: and it goes out of it either the large intestine, or the intestine, according to what happens in the other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Either from blood that flows from the Vein, or from the Artery, according to what has been said before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or compressed from windiness in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a fissure of the skin and discharge of pus: then its color is similar to the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and it appears in various locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the protrusion of the intestine, then its location is, with that which we have narrated, of more diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press him with your fingers, he is hidden; then he returns, and perhaps there is a sound with him; and it is much magnified at the entrance of the bath, and labor pain.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is due to moisture, it is soft, then it is not covered when you press it with your hand, nor is a bandage applied, nor added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs the abscess appears black from the  incision.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is due to flesh born: then it is a grave, large, hard abscess and it takes shape according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to windiness, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, that you consider then, if the prominence of the navel is because of blood from the Artery, or Vein, or windiness: then it is necessary that you forbid its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that there is fear and dread, as I have taught you in the chapter, in which I said abscesses because of the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the protrusion of the navel is due to the intestine or a hernia, then it is necessary for you to instruct the patient to hold his breath and stand upright extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with a cauterizing implement around the whole belly button.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie down between your hands upon his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then around with a wide spatula on the circumference of the umbilicus over the place which you have marked with encaustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterward extend the middle of the abscess upward with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him around with a strong thread or silk cord firmly bound: and let the knot of the ligament be well fastened.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the center of the abscess extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find it already captured by a ligament: then extract it with the forceps and introduce your index finger into it, and drive the intestine into the interior of the abdomen: and if you find a tumor, then take it with a hook and cut away its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however, the artery or vein is contrary to you, then wind around it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles and insert two strong threads into them. And insert two needles into the circle you made around the abscess in the shape of a cross, so that they penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then bind the abscess in four places above the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle, and release the place until the extended flesh decays: and falls by itself: or cut it yourself when it becomes soft and decays.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary from ointment until he heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the prominence of the navel is from flesh or moisture, then it must be scooped out like an abscess, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And you shall draw out blood, or moisture, which you find there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for it with that which solidifies the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter Fifty-Third.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already said in the division of the kinds of cancer, and how is the way to its cure with medicines: and beware of it when curing it with iron, so that it may not ulcerate: and we have said about cancer generated in the womb, and beware of its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it; such as cancer that is in the nipple, or in the hip, and those similar ones, from members located to remove the whole of it: especially when it is beginning small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, it becomes old and large, it is not proper that you approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I was not able to heal anyone from it; nor have I seen anyone before me who has succeeded in doing so.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in that case, when it is located as we have said, is, as before, and to free the sick person from black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find the lancet filled with blood plainly.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the weak with preparation, in which it will be spoken of with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw into the tumor hooks that correspond to it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards, hollow out the entire thing with a blade, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, rather express the places, and wipe away the gross blood altogether with your hand, or with whatever instruments are possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If however a thick flow of blood from an incision in an artery or vein troubles you, then cauterize the vein until the blood is stopped.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as well as the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the Treatment of Hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we narrate in the division of kinds of Hydrops, and how the gathering of water is made: and the signs of every kind, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron, is only a species of asclisis alone; and it does not approach with iron the kind of tympanitis; nor the kind of hypocarchia entirely; for that one is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this type of Hydropsis of the tympanum with medicines, and your medicine has not helped, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If weakness has already come upon the sick person, or if there is another infirmity with him besides dropsy: such as if he has a cough, or diarrhea of the belly, and the like: then beware that you do not treat him with iron: because there is fear of this.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If you see a patient with excessive strength and there is only dropsy accompanying him, and he is neither a boy nor an old man, then the mode of operation in him is that you raise the patient standing between your hands, and the assistant behind him expresses his belly with his hand pushing water to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a grooved knife, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let there be two pointed parts, long, and acute at the end like a spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Nonetheless, let there be something of brevity gradually so that you do not pass through with it at the operation up to the intestines and wound them.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	If a generation of dropsy is from the part of the intestines, then it is necessary that you lengthen with a cut from the navel to a quantity of three fingers, to the lower direct above the breastbone.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If, however, the generation of dropsy is because of liver illness; then let your section be on the left side from the navel three finger widths.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.
