Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If the anus does not obey defecation, then a clyster should be administered to the sick person in which there is a small bite, so that it may wash what is in the anus and obey defecation quickly when the sick person expels himself.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If they are external from the anus, then their condition is light and easy; and it is as if you would take them with your fingernail or hook, and cut them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with that which we have said, until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And if he shuns cutting with iron, then it is necessary that you administer a suture of them according to this method.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a thread wound up, and introduce it into the needle.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw the athil upward and make it penetrate with a point at its root from the other side: and involve the two extremities of the thread, in the lower part of the awl, and let them be laterally placed: and tighten the athil tightly.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and draw out the point.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all aethile and release from them one: and do not let its own, so that it runs out of excess blood.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place a cloth soaked in rose or red oil over the anus, and place it over the anus. And command the sick person to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let it go, until it falls.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore the athelia fall, treat them with ointment, and the rest of treatment, until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	On the care of fissures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many times indeed they happen from drying of excrement and constraint of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When therefore they are ancient and medicine does not avail in them, then it is necessary that you cut with points of a spatula, or with your fingernail, until they become moist, and the upper cortex which prevents them from consolidation be removed from them.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they are consolidated as is proper.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If they do not solidify, then treat them again with greater vigor than before, until they bleed much and are scraped, and then take care of them until they heal.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the treatment of inverted and non-inverted  Almirmar, and Athelil ulcers, and Formicae.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter LXXXII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that Almirmar is nothing but a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to the head of a nail: and it occurs in the whole body, especially in the lower parts of the feet, and fingers: and pain happens from them when walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	Therefore it is necessary that what is around the nail be cut and held with forceps or a hook, and be removed from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for that: and if you wish cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From the armpit there is one small, rough, filtered eminence, round on the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And many times they happen in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its treatment is, that you extend athelil and cut it; or bind it with silk thread; or with hair, until it falls off.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what has been said with fire, or with a sharp medicine; and now the athelil are eradicated, both inverted and not inverted with the instrument which I shall tell you about.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	A bite from an ant is also a small elevation, rough, on the surface of the body, penetrating deep down; and when it finds cold, it feels like an ant bite in it, and happens throughout the body; and most of it happens in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its cure is, that you take a tube from the feather of a goose, or the feather of a strong vulture: and put that tube over the Formica, until it contains a circle of the tube from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then turn your hand with a probe until you cut what is around the ant's form; and place it deep in the flesh, and eradicate the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, make it with a tube of air, or iron, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the tube be drawn up to a height so that the grip on the finger is lessened and its turning made easier.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish to cauterize a  Formica according to what was previously said in the cauterization of Athelil in the chapter on cauterization.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	On the shapes of instruments which are administered to the urethra in affections of the anus, and the loosening of the belly, and colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter LXXXIII.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes a clyster is made of silver, or brass, or cast or hammered copper.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes these instruments are made small and large, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore that which is administered in the care of very young boys, let it be small; and of those whose anuses are weak, or painful, so also their testicles.
Clistere magnum.	Large clyster.
Cistere paruum.	Small bladder.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The tube of it, that is, the upper part in which the uterus is tied, should be wide according to this method: and let there be a distinction so that the uterus can be tied as you see, and its lower end which goes into the anus, should be closed, that is, not open, soft, smooth, gently pulling towards fineness: and on one side of it there should be two holes, and on the other side one hole.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the foramen be according to the thickness of the rays, and a little thicker, and let it be in which medicines are put from the bladder of an animal: or from sheepskin, which is according to the form of a small asophore: whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it shall be pierced with many holes as it is turned, and let the space that is between every hole be the thickness of a finger.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then introduce into those openings a strong thread of raw thread, which is made of ten threads, or about that many, and gather it with it the uterus like an asofratus.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore it is placed in it, let it be tightened at the head with a clyster between two distinguishing constrictions with strong force.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then give a clyster with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circle of the womb here depicted, and the hole.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of cleansing with this, is: that you fill the rectum, or bladder with medicine, which should be heated according to the amount tolerated by the patient: and beware that it is not too hot, or too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient is laid on his back and his legs are raised to the upper part; and beneath him a cushion, that is, skin upon which men lie, or cloth, is placed.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the extremity with oil, or with egg white, or with flaxseed mucilage, or the like.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then introduce it into the anus with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant take the rectum with both his hands and press it forcefully until everything that is in the clyster is evacuated into the intestine.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the clyster and have the patient raise his legs against the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If medicine compels him to an outcome, then let him hold as much as he can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it throughout the whole night, it is more helpful.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If, however, you give him enemas in complaints of belly disease, and his death hastens, then repeat the enemas until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the anus, then a fine, gentle enema should be used, like those with which children are cleaned.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a thin enema for when the skin is tight.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the healing of wounds of the head without fracture of bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter LXXXIV.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the division of the cure of wounds what was convenient for the book, and I will say here the cure of them with hand and with medicines according to complement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore I say, that wounds differ according to the manner in which they are inflicted, and according to the place upon which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things therefore by which wounds are made very often are such as a throw of a stone: or incision with a sword, or knife: or striking with a spear, or wood, or arrow: and similar things from many others.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds that are made according to the location of the body are such as a wound that falls upon the head, or neck, or chest, or belly, or leg; and similar ones from those limbs.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am relating cures of certain wounds, so that I may place that reasoning and rule over the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I begin with simple wounds of the head: for the recollection of compositions will come at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	Therefore, I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs on the head, and there is no bone fracture: consider then, if it is from a stone throw, or something similar, and it has only broken the skin: and the wound is large, and you fear an outcome of hot suppuration: then make haste, and perform cephalic phlebotomy immediately: and do not delay this: and draw out blood according to the quantity of its power: if nothing forbids phlebotomy, especially if the blood that comes out of the wound is little.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the incision be made on the opposite side from the wound.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick one beware of repletion, and wine, and heavy foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If something prevents reduction, then it should be lessened from food, and it should not approach meats, nor wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And put over the wound if it happens to him a hot abscess, apply a decoction infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is astringency.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If you are sure about the hot abscess, then place on the wound, if it is recent with its own blood, and has not yet changed its air, the powder which I shall tell you a little later: and if it has already changed its air, then place upon it some ointment until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If, however, the wound is large, or is from a sword cut, and similar: and its lips do not come together by means of pins, then gather them together with suture, according to what I will say about wounds of the abdomen regarding their sutures.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If now the wound is already discovered from the bone, and hangs, and there is no retention of it, except in a small suspensory: then cut into it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with medicines, and restore in it the hard flesh in the place of skin, and order the sick person to be fed with foods which are thick, such as heads, and cooked wheat, until it is like porridge; and similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the skin rotting, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut out the whole rotten part, and throw it away; then care for it.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If in these wounds there is an artery or vein from which blood flows and it is not cut off by medicines, then investigate above the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find it not cut, then cut it with a spatula, or bind it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity requires when that which we said does not help, then cauterize it until the blood is cut off.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If however these wounds are small, simple, then the matter of them is easy, light: so that you put this powder on them: because it consolidates them before they change in air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	The Method of Incarnate Powder.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of olibanum, two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unburnt chalk: mix all together well and sift it.  Fill the wound with this and bind it tightly with a good bandage until it adheres well to it and clots with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it above with pads and let it go, and do not loosen it while it remains so that it does not come undone.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine is not removed from it until it is healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes it does this alone the plaster, when you do not have frankincense at hand, and dragon's blood also does the same operation in many of the large wounds, when it is convenient to be laid upon them and bound tight, and are fresh wounds with their own blood, which has not been altered by air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	If it has already been altered by some kind of change, especially when it is in the summer time, then there is no intention for this powder to be in position: therefore take care of it with what we have said, so that you put some ointments on it which are digestive; or put poultices on it made from barley flour, made with water and honey, until they emit pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest of the treatment, until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If it happens with a wound and fracture in the bone, and it is small, then remove it with the Gesti: and I will now say the cure of fractures of the head in what will come next.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On Wounds of the Neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter LXXXV.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound occurs in the neck, there is no difference in treatment between it and a wound on the head when it is simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If a vein of the neck or an artery has already been cut: then if it is a nerve, there is no power in it unless it be treated with that which makes staunching vehement, such as ziniar and zegi and things similar.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because they harm the nerves and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not place anything cold at all upon the wound: because the substance of the nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is the most sublime part of the body: and let it be cured by medicines gently, such as chalk washed with sweet water several times infused with oil, or with rose oil, and thyme, when it is also washed with sweet water: and other mineral stones, in this way, and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If however the wound is large, then administer a suture: or constrict its lips with little bits of wool.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If, however, the depth of the wound is great, or a sinus has occurred in the lower part of it, in which pus is already gathered, then pierce it in the more depressed place within it.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery has already been cut in a wound and its blood flow has continued, then separate or dry it out, and tie it up: or cauterize it if necessity requires it.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If however the wound has occurred in the throat, or all of it, and the al-hadege have been saved: then gather together the lips of skin with suture above the tube of the throat, and do not touch the throat, but rather equalize it, and bring it back to its natural form.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten it with a suitable ligature and leave it for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment which contains astringency and drying power, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If the wound has already made an impression on bone, then examine it: and if there are fragments of bone in it, remove them all, or as many as you can.  And what cannot be prepared, let it alone until the wound decays, and its exit is separated and relieved.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the wound is recent, then apply the powder I have described upon it.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If, however, a bone appears in the wound and a fistula is formed, then care for it should be taken with that which is remembered in its chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On a wound in the shoulder blades.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter LXXXVI.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If it is a wound from a lance or knife, and you see its depth, then consider it.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If therefore from a wound there issues windiness, when he gasps from it, then know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and is fresh with its own blood, then you shall not put powder on it from the first hour, nor bind it tightly so that blood is not held in its depth, and returns to the heart, and kills the patient: but place ointment attractant upon it, and loosen it every day twice.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If, however, ointment is not present to you, then place in the opening of the wound old cloth, so that it may draw out that which flows from it of humidities: and make that the sick person sleep upon the wound, so that it may cure what is gathered in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If now three days or more have passed since the wound, and no spasm has occurred in the infirm, nor a bad tremor of the heart, nor stricture in breathing, and you see the rest of its dispositions good: then know that the wound is safe.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore care for it itself and with licenses, and the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If, however, healing is excused, and it always opens then you shall know that a fistula has been made.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore care for it from its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a sword or knife incision, and it is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it with what preceded concerning suture, if it is large; or with powder, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If however he has already made an impression on the bone, and a fragment has fallen out of it: then inquire about the wound, and hasten to extract those fragments, if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If they are not separated, then leave them until the wound has rotted, for extraction will be made easier.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgment of the accidents of wounds in the remaining limbs is in the cure, as we said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	On wounds of the abdomen, and the exit of the intestines, and their protrusion.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	A rupture that happens to the belly, is great, and medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	Therefore sometimes a great quantity of intestine emerges, or a number of intestines.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore, the introduction of them is made, and their suture more difficult and strenuous.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And even a small rupture can be difficult in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore it follows that the reduction is more difficult if you do not hasten in its introduction to its place immediately; because it becomes inflated, opened, and enlarged; therefore the entrance into it becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, a middle disruption is better for ruptures because with it, the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is difficult in these two kinds.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that suture of the vagina is done in four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common sutures are used in the suture of the abdomen and in the suture of other wounds on the body; and two other sutures are proper to other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	Nevertheless, these are more appropriate for stitching up a wound in the abdomen: and I will tell you each one with explanation and declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	Therefore I say, that when a wound is small, and something comes out of it from the intestines, and it becomes difficult to reduce it: then it is because of one of two ways.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the rupture, as we have said; or because there is inflation in the intestine because of the coldness of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When therefore that is so, then it is necessary that you heat it, so that you may submerge a sponge, or a piece of cloth wet in lukewarm water only.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil it in water with squill and cypress and saffron and embrocations with the intestine until the swelling resolves.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes it makes a wine with astringency; and it is better than water alone in resolving swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When therefore you see that the swelling has already resolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which the althea or marshmallow has been boiled.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For that, the entrance is eased with a small thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, his return is excused after this treatment, then find in a small incision, with the instrument by which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first cure is better when it is prepared than when it is cut; and there should not be compulsion to cut after necessity and lack of instrument.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let there be a part of it that is twisted, sharp, and the other part not sharp, and the fine extremity not be with the fineness of Spatula, but rather be somewhat blunt: and it is that which resembles a spatula, as you see.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When therefore a wound is enlarged and enters the intestine, then it is necessary that there be a reduction of it according to its natural form in its own place, if it is possible above it: because it is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When a rupture is wide in the lower part of the abdomen: then it is necessary that you make the sick person lie on his back, and put his legs higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the abdomen, then place its head and chest higher than its lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a rupture in one of the two parts of the belly, then put your attention and your consideration always in this, that the part in which is the wound be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary that you administer it in large wounds, and in medium-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then have a devout assistant present between your hands who will hold the entire rupture with his hand: and bring together its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then uncover from it he who follows the suture something after something: and this is the manner of a common suture of one.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, that you take a needle, or a number of needles according to the quantity of the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the end of the rupture the quantity of the ring finger, that is, of the doctor: and fix one point with an awl, besides which you insert a thread into both extremities of the skin, with both extremities of the fascia that is under the skin from the interior, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have already gathered together two extremities of the skin, and two extremities of the fascia: and there are four rows.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then bind with a double thread around the area of the needle several times from two sides simultaneously, until the two lips of the wound are joined together by a decent gathering.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the thickness of a finger also, and set in them another point; afterward bind it with thread, as you did with the first point.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore, do not cease doing this with it as you need from the awl until you complete the constriction of the whole wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the awls be of medium thickness between coarseness and fineness; for fine awls cut flesh very quickly, and coarse ones are difficult to enter the skin: therefore they ought to be of medium thickness and fineness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be inserted in both extremities of the adjacent skin too much; so that flesh does not quickly cut, and the wound opens before its consolidation, and also do not lengthen with suture, so that the wound is not hindered from consolidation.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the extremity of the needle so that it does not harm the sick person in their sleep; and place small pieces of cloth on every side of them, which hold the extremities of the needles; and leave them until you know that the wound is already healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this kind of suture with needles is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Since one or two or about that many needles suffice for sewing them up.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second kind of suture is common, as it joins the extremities with four sutures: two extremities of skin and two extremities of fascia in one vice, with a needle in which sits an equal thread in fineness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have penetrated with the point these four extremities, withdraw the point from the part where you began, so that the thread may fall from the upper part of the wound: that it may be a suture, as a suture of cloth which is tightened on cloth, and place between each suture the quantity of thickness less than the smallest finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	These stitches men know.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I treated the wound which had happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and the wound was a rupture one palm wide: and about two palms of intestine had come out from the middle intestine, and there was a rupture in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore, after it stood outside the wound for twenty-four hours, I reduced it.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	Therefore, the wound was consolidated in a space which was about fifteen days: and I took care of it, and it healed: and he lived after it for many years, unchanged in his habits.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not be healed.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And it was a miracle that I did not treat it with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where no ointment was found, nor anything from medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	Therefore I placed upon the old ulcer a poultice twice a day, and diligently washed it with water of honey until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I shall speak of two kinds of suture proper according to the account of discourse.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, as you begin with a sharp suture: and insert the point from the outer to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore a needle penetrates the skin and entering the flesh according to the length and width of the whole body: let go the extremity of the sifac on the side in which you introduced the needle, and make it penetrate into the other extremity from the inner part to the outer in the other extremity.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate according to this in the same extremity miraculous from the outside part to the inside: and let go the extremity sifac, which is in this side, and make it penetrate the point into the other extremity from the inside part to the outside: and make it penetrate with penetration your own that you make it penetrate in sifac extremity miraculous, which is in its part, until it penetrates into the whole of it.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from this same side, and sew it with the extremity which is from the opposite side, and extract the point from the skin which has pierced through.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then bring it back into that skin, and suture its end, which is on the other side, with this end marvelously; and draw it out of the skin which is on its part, and make one of them, and the other; and make one after another, until its entire outside according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of this suture is that you sew with sutures of softer skin than these skins; so that you stitch one side of one extremity of the skin and let it go on the other side until you complete it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of suture, which Gale called his own.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This speech of his is narrated so that he would imitate it according to the likeness with which some physicians do this, that they gather all the part to its own part fitting by nature: and they apply the end sifac to its other end, and the end mirach to its other end.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I tell you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you place a pointed knife at the edge of the limb near you from the outside part, and make it penetrate to the inside there: and let go of the two ends of the knife.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the point and make it penetrate from the outer part to the inner in two extremities, that is, on both sides.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn both sides, even make them penetrate from the inside to the outside, into two extreme parts, which are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is a better suture than the common one, and it is a suture whose previous explanation has been given.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also the speech of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the abdomen should be made with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, to introduce into both one thread: and begin with the introduction of a needle, from that which is with you, and make it penetrate to the other side, according to the suture of those who sew skins equally.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when a rupture is in the middle of the belly: then its suture is more difficult than the rest of the places of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of healing a wound is the judgment of other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you find a fresh wound with its blood, before the air alters it: and you reduce the intestine, and your own, and fit it: then place on top powdered charcoal.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already changed the wound: then put on it some ointment which is present to you, until they make pus, and the threads fall away, and the wound be closed up, and healed.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as is the treatment of other wounds until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	If medicines are not present to you, then put upon it immediately, from where it begins to discharge pus, a poultice of old, rotten cloth; and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it is healed.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medication in many cases when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If you fear that a wound may communicate to the principal members in the lesion, then it is necessary that you submerge soft wool in oil tempered with moderate heat, or in rose oil: and place it around the areas which are between the groins, and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or pricks, or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens), then cleanse him with wine, thick, black, lukewarm: especially if the rot has already reached the intestine and made an exit passing through to its hollow cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which is from the large intestine is of easier healing, and that which is from those [parts] is of more difficult healing.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The intestine called the jejunum does not accept healing from a wound that happens in it at all; and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and their size, and because of the subtlety of its body, and proximity of its nature to nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If what comes from the wound is a protrusion, and you find it fresh: reduce it according to your method of reduction, by which you reduce intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If however the space has passed and it is already green or black: then it is necessary that you tie it with a thread above the place which has darkened from it, so that there does not happen a flow of blood.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	In the finger are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and put two hanging ends of thread from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that the traction of it above you may be relieved, and its extraction in case of zirbi, and the discharge of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	A remembrance of a wound that happened in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When rupture occurs in the intestine and is small, it is possible that it may be restored in some people; for I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a lance thrust, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and the wound was old; and a fistula was made, and wind and excrement came out of it.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I made treatment, until I was not confident in his healing: and I did not cease to treat him carefully, until he was healed, and the place was consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the place was already consolidated, I feared for the weak part, lest an evil accident happen to the weak part in his belly; and it did not happen to him from that evil accident.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better dispositions of himself, eating and drinking, and going to the bathroom, and entered the bath, and exercised on his diets.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And now some experimenters have said that when a wound happens in the intestine and is small, then it ought to be bound up according to this method.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, as you receive ants of great heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound, and place a single ant that has an open mouth over the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When therefore he seizes it above and tightens its mouth, cut off its head, for it adheres, and does not separate.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this with an ant after each ant according to the quantity of the whole wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it and sew its wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For these heads remain attached to the intestine until the intestine is nourished and healed, so that no harm is done to the weak person entirely.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible to draw out the intestines even with a fine thread: which has been removed from the animal's intestine, attached to it after it is inserted into the wound.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, so that you receive the extremity of this thread from the gut, and it be much cleaned.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then bind a thread of fine linen wrapped at the end of it.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce that thread into the point and sew with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then bring it back to its break.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this way of suturing with ants and intestine is nothing but according to the way of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound that is large and wide, especially if it is in one of the small intestines, then there is no remedy except subtlety, and its healing is not at all.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the treatment of a Zochen (or possibly Zychemen) and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter LXXXVIII.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound, or abscess when it ages and becomes old, and becomes an ulcer, and does not heal, and always emits pus, and is not cut off: then it is called universally in any member a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed is according to truth a knot filtered, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the concavity of a bird's feather: and because of this some call it Risati, that is, a feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And there are some hours humid, which emits pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps moisture divides in certain hours.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this humidity is much and little, and is thick and subtle.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already stated in the division, when I spoke of wounds, that every ulcer which does not heal and no flesh is born in it, this is not due to anything but one new cause.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these is, or because of the small amount of blood in the body; or because of its evil; or because between itself and above its lips is hard flesh, preventing the birth of flesh; or because it is full of dirt and filth; or because the ulcer on itself is putrid, and the matter that is sent to it is of bad quality; or because the medicine is unsuitable in its treatment; or because the corruption falling in the region is a kind of pestilence; or by the property of the region, as happens in Caesaraugusta: in which difficult digestion of diseases occurs, and the healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because it has one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have now shown all these causes and signs of them, and their cures with medicines in division: and it is necessary here that I make you know the cure of Fistula and Zuken, which is done by way of operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Know therefore that a fistula occurs in all members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For some of these are fistulas that reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or fascia; or to the intestine, or bladder, or to one of the ribs; or to one of the vertebrae of the back, or to one of the joints formed by a composition: such as hands and feet; and from these there are some that reach the proximity of the main member and similar members.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Therefore, those fistulas according to this manner are from difficult diseases to heal, and do not receive treatment, and occupation with them is labor and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If it is from a fistula of which the depth does not reach these places which I have said: and you hope and trust in its cure, and you wish to come to know it, then take a probe made of copper, or iron, if the fistula extends in a straight line, and explore it with it.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, there is a tortuosity in the fistula, then investigate it with a probe of fine lead.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because lead, with the softness of its body, is raised and bent around a twist.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If a fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to feel over it with your finger.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore, a clyster is administered from them through their openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For humidity which you use for douching it enters through other openings and flows out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully inquire in whatever way is possible to you, so that you may know whether there is a bone or a nerve, and whether the fistula's concavity is distant or close: or whether it is one fistula which has many openings, and stand upon all of it with your utmost strength. With your questioning, as you interrogate the sick person, and by finding pain upon compression with your hand over the place, and by similar signs and accidental causes of the abscess.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When therefore you stand upon all these true stations, then go to cure according to confidence: and it is, as you consider then, if there is a Fistula near appearing, or in a healthy place far from the joint, or nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I have told you: then dry the Fistula according to what was said before from my narration, and remove what is in it from filtration, and corrupt flesh, which is born in its opening from flesh, or pus, and similar things: and care for it until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If however a fistula is of great depth and is straight, then it is necessary to cut it deep as far as you are able.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it thoroughly of all its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer a linen cloth rolled up in sharp medicines: and introduce it as far as the cavity of the fistula which you have grasped with iron: do this several times until the sharp medicine corrodes everything that remains in the cavity of the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments that generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal through that, then cauterize it according to what we have narrated.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If therefore the cause of a fistula is bone, and you certify this to yourself; then examine that bone, and dry it according to what I have told you; if nothing prevents you from a vein, or nerve, or principal limb, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore a bone is discovered by you, and there is something of corruption and blackness in it, then scrape it until the whole corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with that which has become incorporated into him, until he is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	If it does not heal, and discharge pus as it did: then you know that you have not come to the complete eradication of corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore diligently cleanse it a second time, and make an exact reason of it, and its purification with your utmost fortitude.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If therefore it heals, it is good: and if not, then know that that corruption is in the deep part of the body, which you have not reached.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	There is therefore no need for you to have ingenuity in it, unless you let nature take care of it.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If a small bone is broken, and it is possible for you, draw it together with fine forceps that are suitable for it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make a very careful traction of them all, and do not let anything escape from them with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If something from the moist things does harm to you, and there is no fear or error in cutting them: then cut those moist things and the flesh if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you do not have the preparation to remove the bones from your hour, then place over the wound that it may rot; and let it be until it has rotted what is around those bones from flesh and moistures.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the wound so that it does not close up.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And tighten the section which you cut in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	If you wish, place on top of it a cloth submerged in sulfur ground with oil; or a cloth submerged in Egyptian ointment; or some ointment of viridarium.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humidities decay and the bones separate from them, the removal of them is eased, and their drawing out.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If it is one large bone, such as the bone of the leg or the bone of the hip, and similar to these, and if that which has become corrupted from it is a large part: then carefully cut away the last part, until the black and corruption are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If however what is in it is corrupted, and the part is large, and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to close it up and cut it entirely until the place where the corruption has arrived: then take care of it until it solidifies.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you a wound which happened to a man in his leg: that you may put it as an example and help to your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man about thirty years of age to whom pain occurred in his leg, caused by something that moved into him from within the body, that is, from the insides, until the matter reached the leg, and it became a large abscess: and there was no external cause for him.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Therefore, time was extended with him in error of physicians, until an abscess was opened, and many materials converged with it.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after treatment had been applied, until the leg was healed and many openings were made in it which all discharged pus and bodily fluids.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore, a multitude of physicians treated him for about two years, and there was no wise man in the art of hands until I was called, and I saw his leg, and the matter that flowed from those openings in great flow: also all the body of the man had become wasted, and its color was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore inserted a probe into one of the openings and it reached the mouth.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings, and found that they communicated with each other from all parts of the thigh.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I therefore proceeded and cut above one of the openings until I discovered the part of the bone: and I found it corrupted: which was already corroded and blackened, and rotten, and perforated until it had penetrated to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	Therefore I have seen what was shown to me, and prepared from a corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I determined that there should not be in the bone except for that corruption, which was cut away and sawed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already removed it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed restoration of the wound with consolidating medicines over a long space.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it is not united.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I examined and found above the bone, second to the first detection, a continuous decay with the bone, and I sawed what appeared to me even from that decay.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it has not been restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore I examined it again and did not cease to cut the bone piece by piece, and attempt its restoration: and it was not restored until I cut out of the bone about one palm's length, and extracted it with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed; and this repetition in his operation and section was not necessary except because of the disposition of weakness of the sick man, and the smallness of his tolerance, and my fear over him about death; for he fell into syncopes every hour from the excess of evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	Therefore he was healed with complete healing: and flesh hard as bone was born in the place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he turned back to his arrangements: and he did no harm whatsoever to him in walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone in the place of the body has already been broken: then it is necessary that you fasten it, according to this manner: and it is: that you take a ligament, and tighten it at the extremity of the prominent bone: and order someone, who extends it upwards: and put another ligament out of wool thicker than the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it upon the flesh which is under the bone: and extend the extremity of it, so that you draw the flesh downward: and you will expose the flesh over the place which you wish to suture, so that it does not wound the flesh with the saw.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood, or a board beneath the bone in a central location; for when you do this, it does not prevent the cutting of rotten flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that there be a lock on the place corrupted for a short time, so that there may not be corruption in the concavity of the bone, and it may not appear in its appearance to the sense, and it may force to the lock itself vice another.
