Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is broken and not protruding, rather its part continues with another part, and the break is in the middle of it, or in a part of it, then cover the flesh from all parts entirely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place the lower stick.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, saw it from the first part, where there is corruption, until the saw continues on the other part: and let the saw be according to the length from the corruption a little, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If corruption is in a joint, cut open the corrupted joint itself, and saw the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If a corruption is in the continuity of two joints, then there is no remedy in it except scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If corruption is in the breast of the hand, or in the breast of the foot: then the matter in it is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But truly you ought to inquire how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And having scraped it and cleaned it according to whatever arrangement you can manage, and with whatever ingenuity you correct it for you: when it does not make opposition to you Vein, or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that saws and cutting instruments for cutting these bones are many, according to the location of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and fineness, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare instruments suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you concerning the kind of instrument with which you will have need when it is with you a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the modes of this art is a testimony to the modes of diseases: for then indeed you will find by yourself that which is suitable for each illness from instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments, which you will place examples upon which you will cut, and a trial which you will try on others.
Forma Serrae.	Shape of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The form of another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This depiction of the saw is made well.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arch be superior, its sharpness from iron; and its handle from boxwood, and let it be pyramidal in form made off-center.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the surgical knife for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this rasp be according to the form of the head of a star-shaped key: and its points be according to the form of the punctures of elischetfegi.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting unless they are rubbed with it, heads of joints, when they rot or a bone is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Form of the Larger Scalpel
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the middle scalpel.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Form of a Broad Scalpel.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of the razor in which there is a concave side.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of another fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of a razor for another curved extremity.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of the razor is small and fine.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of a saw with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form also of a large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a chisel, and its extremity is like a saw: it is used in many places for cutting bone.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of a scalpel which is suitable for its use according to the way it has been perforated from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The extremity of it is triangular, and acute at its extremities.
Fit ex Indi.	It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it is necessary that all things which we have said be done from Razors, and Cutters, and Saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of limbs, and the setting of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either from an external cause, or from an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated that corruption with medicines, and the treatment does not help: and you see the corruption has affected the limb, which is not struck by anything: then it is necessary that you cut into that limb until where the corruption follows, so that the sick man may escape through it from death, or from the evil which is greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this happening is that the limb darkens until it is thought to be burned by fire or rotting after blackness: until that rot reaches what follows that limb, and spreads throughout the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, it is proper with the cutting of it, and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the striking of some venomous ones: such as the scorpion of the sea, and viper, and adder, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore decay or a blow is in the extremity of the finger, then cut the finger, and do not make space for decay, that it may proceed to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root of the finger, and do not leave space for corruption until it takes hold in the arm's focus.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it strikes him there, then cut the arm at the elbow at its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however corruption passes through and you see him about the arm: then there is death of the sick man in that.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And in addition to that from healing, is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do so with the foot, when corruption invades the finger, then cut it at one of the joints: and if it seizes in the arch of the foot, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If corruption has already come above the knee, then there is no remedy except dismissal, and to leave the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way of cutting a limb, or sewing it up is, that you tie one ligament below the place you wish to cut. And tie another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one assistant extend a ligament downwards: and let another assistant extend a ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut, or suture.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth from all parts, and let the saw not touch the healthy place: and may there happen to the wounded one an added lesion and a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If a hemorrhage occurs internally while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly: or put some powders on it that stop blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage, and care for it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man in his foot, this same thing that I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is because a blackness occurred in his foot, when it was burned and assimilated to the burning of fire; and that corruption first occurred in his finger, until it began the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore a man healed himself after he saw that corruption had fallen upon the limb with violence, which he found from the pain and burning of it: and it fell upon him at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption befell his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He then came to me, and I tried to recover that superfluity with what I had placed on his hand from medicines after the purification of his body: and the superfluity was not found, and it began to walk into another finger; until corruption began in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	Therefore he called me to cut his hand: and I was unwilling, hoping for a surplus of his recovery from me: and I also feared about him death at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's virtue was above the wound.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After that, when he despaired of me, he returned to his land: and it came to me about him, because he hurried, and fell with his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not brought forth this narrative, except that it may be an aid regarding that which falls under the genus of this ailment: and that it may be a sign by which it is made known, and according to which it is treated.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the care of sinuses, and the quality of clysters with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a boil occurs in certain fleshy limbs and the space of the boil is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or is perforated, and what is in it of pus comes out, and a hollow place remains as if it were a vessel: and the skin which is above it like a cloth that has already been finely woven: and does not reach the ultimate stage of corruption, nor presses into bone, nor into nerve, nor into ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula: however, if its space is prolonged until corruption presses into any of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is that you cut that skin entirely as it revolves; and especially when it has been smoothed out and made like cloth; and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you hope that it will adhere to the skin, and last corruption does not follow from this; and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then care for it with a clyster, and it is, as you should consider, to the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it is large, and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then cleanse it with an Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and ziniar, taking equal parts, they are gathered in a vessel; and they are boiled over a fire until the medicine boils; and it comes to the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary for you; and dissolve it with water and honey, and administer a clyster into the sinus with it. And bind the opening of it, and let the medicine remain in it for the quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then remove it with expression: do this for so many days until the sinus is purified and the stench is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is given as a suppository with ash water, when this medicine is not present to you; and it is, that you take the ash of willow wood or ash from holly trees; and pour it upon the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then treat it with a suppository, and give a clyster with it, until you are confident that the sinus has been emptied.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine or water of ash, then cleanse him with water and honey to which has been mixed something of crushed zinc.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cleanse it with a clyster of honey and wine mixed together, because the property of honey is to purify and wash; and wine causes the wound to adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times, and you trust that the corruption of the sinus is already removed: then irrigate it with that which makes flesh grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, as you receive from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose oil, and sticking wine: or clysterize it with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the opening of the sinus is narrow, in which a clyster cannula cannot enter: then widen it with a small knife: or put a linen cloth smeared with Egyptian ointment or basil ointment into it, until it widens.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also wide, then gather its lips together with a suture: and release from it as much as can enter a clyster without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which the pus runs is elevated upwards: then dry it in a lower place which is within it, so that the pus may run out of it downwards: because when pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus about lower part of it as you wish; then try to prepare the member with a preparation which will drain pus from it easily as it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try so that nothing of the pus is retained in it at all; and take medicinal substances which are placed over the sign, suitable to what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them upon linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it may communicate the whole of the Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps at the direct opening of the sinus foramen, a little larger than the opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointment soft on another cloth, according to the quantity of the hole: and place it over it in a position far from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of pus from it may be relieved: and do not remove the large cloth unless after some days once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is over the opening of the Sinus is he whom you remove at every hour so that what has gathered there from pus may go out. And so that you know whether that which runs out of it is much or little; or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this again consider the place of the Sinus, whether the lord feels pain in it or not, and whether there is an abscess in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is extended thus, and you see the matter which comes out above the opening of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus is already adhering, or approaching adherence: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, a subtle virus emerges from the sinus after a long time, then do not despair of its adherence, because its healing is approaching, because there are some men who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are some who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If after many days undigested pus exits from the sinus, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its matter is prolonged: then in the drying of the medicines, truly let physicians do that they be moist in their substance and dry in their virtue: such as unguent dyafinicon, when there is added to it superfluity of addition from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last cure which is made, it is that you receive diaconical ointment and dissolve it with rose oil and return over it ancient wine equal in substance to its own.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then make it with him, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now he does something similar to this action, when you do not have dyafinicon ointment at hand, honey, when you have boiled it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take frankincense, and aloes, and myrrh: pound the whole thing, and pulverize it over honey while it is over fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then a linen cloth over the same pad, and tighten it over the sinus: and a linen bandage with honey that you have boiled until it is thick, and dust it over the top, and place it on the pad, and tighten it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with long birthwort and roots of heavenly lily, and lily: and the herb's flour, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use these simple or combined ones, rub them, and also the sieves themselves: and pulverize above honey which I have narrated, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the matter of the sinus prolongs itself and does not heal with this treatment: then know that there is corruption deep within it; or it already makes impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or on the ligaments: then cure it with the treatment of fistulas, according to what has been said before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of a felon and an abrased nail, and the addition of a finger digit, and sectioning.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XCIX.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A panaritium is an abscess that is born under the nail of the finger of the hand, or of the foot: and perhaps it is born in the remaining fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the matter is prolonged and its cure is neglected, and it becomes inflamed with a hot abscess; or it decays and emits pus until it corrodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it destroys it entirely, and perhaps the decay reaches the bone until it has a foul odor; and the extremity of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you treat the flesh, with that which we said in the division, and your treatment does not help: then it is necessary that you cut with a knife all the superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	A heated cautery is very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is sound and the nail is also healthy, and the additions of the empty nail already press the flesh to the insides, and they begin to prick it, and wound it: then it is necessary that you place a thin Radicum under the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and drive it upwards: and cut into that flesh with ease, and place on top of that which remains of flesh from burning medicines, corrosives, until the whole thing is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If corruption has already set into the bone, then it is necessary to cut into that bone and remove it; for it is never cured while the corrupted bone remains in place.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see that decay and corruption are advancing in the finger, then cut it at one of the nodes, according to what has been said before about its recollection.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If it happens that a nail is rubbed or struck and there is severe pain in it, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the fingernail with a sharp spatula, making a transverse section from top to bottom as desired.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard that the cutting does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will cause to happen through it an intense pain on the weak one, and it will be a cause to the birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which allays pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is fleshy throughout: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its nativity is in some nodes of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, he who is born in certain knots of the finger, does not move: and he who is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the section of that which is fleshy from those things is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, that you cut it at its root with a wide Spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	The cure of him whose nativity is at the root of the articulation is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from incisions of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one who is born in the finger at the last of the knots, then it is necessary that you cut first his flesh with a round incision unto the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw with one of those saws suitable to it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	The solidifying together of the fingers, which often happens either from birth, that is, it is born with it, or from the closing of a wound, or burning with fire, and the like.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary that you cut away that consolidation, until the fingers return according to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them strips of linen or cloths soaked in rose oil so that they do not coalesce too quickly, and separate them; or place between them a thin lead sheet until the place has consolidated according to what is necessary.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if it happens that a consolidation occurs with some fingers and palm, then dry that consolidation according to how it is prepared and convenient for the figure of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On the incision of a tumor.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	These are veins that are wrapped up, large and full of superfluous melancholic humors which occur in many parts of the body: and most frequently these happen in the legs, especially in the legs of those who travel and labor, and carry things.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary that you administer an excision of the body from black bile sometimes with a strong excision.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then the surgeon should cut open a vein of the patient.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of them with iron is according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cut and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another way is, that the vein may be lifted up and taken out entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section is as follows.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First soak the leg in hot water a great deal until the thick, foul blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the leg of the infirm from the upper part of his hip, as far as the lower part of the knee with a band.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry out the vein in one place, or two, or three with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and the phlebotomist should first attend to those who are ill.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the nail with care until the amount of blood that you see is sufficient and which the strength of the weak person can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Thereafter bind it: and order him to abstain from foods that produce black bile; and repeat evacuation and phlebotomy, when the veins are full, and this harms the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its elevation is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If the leg is sick and there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce it into the bath: or embrocate it on his leg with hot water, until it turns red and the veins swell: or exercise it vigorously if there is no bath present, until the limb heats up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in a direct vein incision along its length: or at its end at the knee, or in the lower part of it at the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks, and scarify the vein from every part until it appears to the sense: and at its appearance, you see it red to blackness declining.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it comes out of the skin, you see it white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce a probe under it until it is elevated and emerges from the skin; suspend it with a curved hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make another incision nearby the first incision three finger-widths away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with rays as you did, and suspend it with another hook, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then a dry incision, or several incisions, if you need it so.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate and make an incision at its last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the incision which is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have removed it from the incision which is higher, or higher incisions, until when it comes out completely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you to be extracted and lifted: then insert a needle with a strong double thread, and tie it, and extract it: or insert a probe under it: and revolve your hand to every part, until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware that it not happen.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to remove it well, and it will enter over the weak one harm from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have extracted it whole, then place over the wound's location wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil: and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, having a twisting which wraps around its parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness; then it is necessary that you find on every part of its twisting and the locations of its wrapping.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you have lifted the whole thing up; and be careful at your incision upon it that you do not cut a vein or wound; for it will be difficult to lift or remove it from above you.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of incision for healing a wound.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of an inguinal hernia.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not to be cared for like the rest of the hooks, nor does it have a sharp tip, so that it may not wound a vein; and it is of thick flexibility, gentle: because if it were fine, it would wound a vein with its fineness; indeed let its excess thickness be as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Vein of the Leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm lands, such as Al-Jazira and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, hot lands, with little moisture, that is, where no grass grows nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other places of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from putrefaction that happens under the skin, just as it happens inside the bodies of snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's condition is that there is a vehement inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then it is sewn up.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then begins the vein to exit from the place of that incision, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore the extremity appears, then it is necessary that you envelop upon the very same piece of lead, whose weight be from one drachm to two drachms and knot it: and let go the suspended lead from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything issues forth from it to the outside, envelop that in lead and tie a knot in it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged much, then cut a part of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it root and branch before it has entirely come out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh, and causes a boil to occur, and rot in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be gently treated and extracted gradually until it emerges from its last part, and nothing of it remains in the body: and from this vein there exits in some men what is five palms long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to me because a man came out of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If it happens to you during your treatment time: then insert a ray into the hole of it, and perforate it with a long hole, with the body, until all that is in it from matter is evacuated; and administer the putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the healing of abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle joint, or in the foot itself: and it happens to have many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, treat the wound, as we have said in the division, and with that which has been previously stated.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On cutting out worms generated under the skin, and it is called the ailment of cattle.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This ailment is called in our region "Bull's disease" because it happens often to oxen and there is a small worm which is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves throughout the entire body, ascending and descending: and it is shown to the sense during its walking from limb to limb, until it ruptures wherever it ruptures in the skin, and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the rotting of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and serpents, that is, roundworms and pinworms, happen in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when he enters the body and is raised to the head and arrives at the place: then perhaps he opens in it and exits and destroys the eye: and this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Therefore, when you wish to treat him and remove him, then this is done only in his walking and appearance to his sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you bind what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligament constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry it over itself, and remove it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it goes deep into the flesh, and you do not find it, then put over the place a cautery with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And that which is feared more, is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see it having arrived at the head near the eye, then tighten under it the eyebrow with a good constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and remove it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick one use purification of his body, with medicines dissolving bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that produce decay.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the cutting of a wound for illness according to Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XC.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs: then it changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I indeed have already seen him, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was ill with certain pains.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he exposed his arm, and I saw a slight swelling in the vein of the arm's cord.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I had waited for an hour, I saw one swelling move with a worm-like motion, ascending toward its shoulder faster than is possible; like quicksilver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore pain receded from that place, and it was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for an hour, and it ran into the rest of his body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was turning over his whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its transposition from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I truly before that had not seen this illness with my eyes in this way according to this manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Nevertheless I have seen many who find pain to be shifted from limb to limb: and I have not seen it with my own eyes, as I saw it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is anything other than because the woman was from those who have been found with dry veins of the body; therefore, it appears to the sense this alteration by wind.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, the hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and the patient feels that pain: then if it appears to you, as we have said, then tightly grasp above it, and below it quickly: and dry above it, until that windiness has been driven out; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your own eyes, then treat it with an expulsion of the body, and with that which expels winds, and carminates them with foul pills, and pills of sparrow, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their kinds and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is: because among them there are those that have large points, and small ones: and concave, and dull.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from those who have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to limbs in which they fall, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the parts are concave from the main parts, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these limbs, and the signs of death appear to you, which I tell you after, then it is necessary that you avoid the extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then extract it, and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When an arrow falls into the brain and penetrates it, and exits through the foramen above the cerebrum, these are the signs: because violent soda, scotoma, vertigo, redness in the eyes, inflation, redness of the tongue, spasms, and a mixing of the intellect, and vomiting of cholera occur from it.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out of the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And moisture white like a poultice comes out from the wound's place.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it exits from there like a watery consistency of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment, and remove the arrow if it does not exit.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left breast: and he feels as if it is fixed in a hard thing, not in a hollow thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the motion of an arrow is similar to the motion of a pulse: and blood black runs out of the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting spells.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death certainly comes.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow wound to the lung is the outflow of frothy blood from the wound; and the vessels which follow the neck become suppurated, and the color of the sick person changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And expires great spirit, high: and seeks attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow falls into the membrane that is in the chest: then it is near the ribs: and a great sigh is made with violent pain: and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something indigested will emerge from the wound along with food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly, and lodges there, something of feces will come out of the wound, or a piece of the intestine which is already torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope of healing it, nor of extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If a shaft falls into the bladder and urine flows out, and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger over the weak, then you shall know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and spatula, and aid, and dorsal vertebrae, and collarbone, and hip, and leg, and similar parts of the limbs are cured according to various arrangements: when it does not find the artery or nerve; and there is no poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I saw of these arrows, that you may know by this about your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is because a certain man had an arrow fall into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from the other part, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not extract from it except its small end, with which it adheres to its shaft; and it was a large arrow from the arrows of the Turkish bows, with a blunt iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was therefore healed, and no evil accident happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And there was an Arabic arrow, and it is that which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Therefore I followed it upon its own between two guides: and now it was submerged in its throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	Therefore I worked on it until I extracted it: and Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed, and nothing had changed in his condition, I cut above the arrow.  I worked on it and extracted it. He was healed, and no harm befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man who had an arrow wound in his back, and the wound had closed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After that, seven years having passed, a arrow emerged from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow fell into her belly, and the wound was consolidated upon her, and the arrow remained inside her; and nothing of her dispositions was changed, and the woman did not find harm to her in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen in his face: and the wound was consolidated, and remained, not finding much pain in him: and similar things like these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the king's princes, which had fallen into the middle of his nose, and had already declined to the right side a little: and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	Therefore I was called to his care after a gunshot wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Therefore, I found a wound caused by an arrow quite severe.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	Therefore I inquired about it with a fine probe, and I did not feel it: and he himself found a prick and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Therefore, I believed that the puncture was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Therefore, I applied a plaster to the place with a plaster that had attractive and digestive power, confident within myself that the place would suppurate and that there would appear to me the sign of an arrow so that I could cut above it: and it did not happen in the place an accident signifying that the arrow had followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore I treated him diligently with a poultice for many days: and no accident happened, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime: and he remained weak from its extraction for a space of days, until one day he felt the arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	Therefore I placed on that wound a medicine acute and corrosive for many days until it opened; and when I felt it, and sensed the subtle point of the arrow adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the incision of the wound with that sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and about four months passed for me with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into it, and to move it, and it did not obey to exit: then I did not cease to be subtle and ingenious upon it with modes of ingenuity, until on one day I began upon it with forceps properly made, according to what will come in the form of them at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And physicians judge that cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it, and the wound was consolidated, and the sickly man was healed in perfect health: nothing harmed him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you may place that rule and meaning over that which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions are not encompassed with the narrative; nor does that book comprehend it, and a wise artificer compares with little to much; and with what is present to what is absent; and finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descents of foreign things of this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out of members in which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by drawing it out from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or conversely, of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out where it entered, is either an arrow proceeding in fleshy place: and it is drawn and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to removal by the hour in which it falls: then you ought to let it alone for several days, until the flesh that is around it has rotted, and the attraction of it has been lessened, and its exit made easier.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is situated in the bone and does not obey you for its exit, then let it be (released) even for several days; and repeat it with traction and motion every day until it emerges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you at the exit after days, then it is necessary that you perforate around the arrow in the very bone from every part with a fine borer until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already progressed into one ventricle of the brain, and appear from the sick some of those accidents which I have said: then abstain from the traction of the arrow, and let it go, until it may be equal to be its after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if an arrow comes to the shaft, then death does not prolong for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, only in the body of the bone, and does not penetrate to the fascia, and remains weak for several days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents, then ingenuity in the traction of the arrow and its extraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed firmly and does not obey you when you pull on it: then administer a terebellum around the arrow's shaft, as I have told you; then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If now the arrow is already hidden in the place of the body, and is concealed and hidden from sense: then inquire for it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments which are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot remove it because of the wound's constriction and because of the arrow's length deep within; and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then leave it there until the wound is enlarged and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If the ears are those that are held fast, then free the flesh fixed in them from every part, with every means you can, and means, if it cannot be done by evacuation of the flesh in fractures of the ears and their torsion, until it is evacuated.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, wherever it may be, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you make it come out: and with the subtlest last subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and its extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot operate on it within one hour, then release it for several days until what is around it rots.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for if the wound is relieved. But if the blood flow does harm to you, then administer what we said about the cure in its chapter: and guard your virtue from incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the skill in every way that is possible to you for the evacuation of the arrow, and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do when drawing a shaft, that the weak point be according to the figure, according to how it was in the case of the shaft itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more useful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that comes out from the opposite part or something already proceeds from it to the outside: or it makes a hump of the extremity of the arrow by sense from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it prominent: therefore dry it above, and let the section be according to the quantity which they grasp in it with forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for indeed it becomes easy to extract.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is held in bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness until the awl presses into the bone and enlarges itself; then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it be released for some days; then repeat it, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If a piece of wood from an arrow is in it, then drive it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If a stick has fallen and you wish to administer a thrust: then insert into it a concave instrument so that the concavity of it enters the tail of the Arrow: then drive it with the same.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If however the arrow is concave, then drive it in with an instrument entering it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow is therefore lifted by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all the flesh in which the poison is; if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it as is fitting.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is near because you touch it with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of incision of the vein, or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew the wound, if you see it, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of Forceps, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the extremities be like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp upon the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds, great and small and medium, are made of these, according to the quantity of magnitude of the Arrow, and its smallness, and the width of the wound, and its constricting.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Shape of the Concave Implement.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the Impeller for deafness.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is for a deaf limb like the radius, so that its entrance may be relieved into a concave arrow, and it may be driven in with it.
