Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this plunger is concave like a bird's feather; so that the entrance of the arrow into it and its impulse may be lessened.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On Bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XCVI.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins that are commonly bled in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these in the head there are sixteen: two pulsatile Veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbs: and two Arteries, which are in the two temples apparent: and two Veins which are in the two lacrimals of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and the prepared Vein in the middle of the forehead: and the Vein which is in the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guideges, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And the two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are opened by bleeding in the arms, there are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of these is the Cephalic vein, and it is from the sylvian side: and the common people call it the head vein.
Et Fusca.	And Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And there is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch: and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And it is called Basilica, and is placed in the domestic side, and is also called Tilillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it a vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the band of the arm is placed over the vein, and it is that in which bloodletting is performed, and it is that which appears above the thumb at the incision.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Saluatella: and there is a vein which is between the annular and the least; and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of these is that which is under the curvature of the thumb from the sinister side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is Saphena: and its place is at the heel from the inside side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein of Nesse: and its place is at the heel from the side toward the inside.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On incision of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The incision of two veins which are behind the ears is beneficial for old catarrhs, and headaches, and inflammation of the eyes, and old sores of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting is as I have said.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the sick person be shaved; and the back of the head, where there are two veins, be rubbed with a rough cloth with good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak man tightens his neck with a thread until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore seek them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark it with wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a surgical knife, and that one is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the vein in the skin until the phlebotomist comes to the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then elevate your hand with vein and skin to the upper parts, and cut the vein with skin by an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that much: and make blood to exit as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with lint and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now he has come to the beginning of the book, the incision and cauterization of them.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On bloodletting of two arteries at times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arteries which are used in the two times of phlebotomy, one is for a very old headache; and one for bad gout, and one for frequent ophthalmia; and the course of excess discharges acute to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting is as I shall tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak person tightens his neck very much until two veins appear to the sense in a manifest appearance: and are demonstrated the pulse of them under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed with encrustation signs.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then elevate the skin from above with your index finger, and introduce a cutting lancet below, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you have done in the two other veins: and make it flow out blood according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the constriction of the patient, and put your finger upon the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterward place upon the same cushion and pills, and bind it tightly from above with a strong constriction: and let it be until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now has preceded the remembrance of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On incision of the vein of the forehead after cephalic incision.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	A lesion from the incision of the vein of the forehead is after cephalic phlebotomy, for old pains in the face: and for headache, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And its quality of phlebotomy is, according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weakened patient bends his neck with a rope until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the pointed tip that is on the head of the scoop over the vein itself, and strike it above with a comb, or with something else in a similar manner: and let the blood flow according to the amount that you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the perforation of the sick person, and tighten it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not right for a phlebotomy at an acute extremity to be like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather let it be at a blunt extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the lancet be passed across it; because the bone is near, and perhaps the lancet will break when it is fine.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	On bloodletting of the veins in the two lacrimals.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	An ailment of the two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, is to the eye from scabies and redness; and it pains in the eye, and the pains in the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy of them is that the weak person should tighten his neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then let him who is skilled in bleeding make it; and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let a phlebotomy be made transversely along the length a little, with a small, rather narrow lancet, for there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If indeed the lancet is fine in extremity, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make it flow from the blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place over them a pad, and bind them one night, and untie them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On bloodletting of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the veins of the nose is helpful for acute fever and vehement inflammation, and facial pain, such as migraine, and redness that occurs on the face, especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it tightens the weak neck of the patient.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a fine, long lancet, and place it in the middle of his hare, between that which distinguishes the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you apply your hand with a lancet for a short time and make blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it tightly at night alone.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It is restored quickly indeed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On phlebotomy of the veins according to Guy.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The use of phlebotomy according to Guidegi's writings is for the constriction of breath, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholy illnesses, and sores and ulcers that are bad, and corroding, that is, those appearing as herpes.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the patient should be lying down with both arms under his neck with a bandage: and the surgeon should stand over the head of the patient, and the patient should be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then a surgeon makes the vein as long as possible with a wide incision.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then withdraw from the blood a tempered quantity, or according to what you see is necessary for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards loosen the ligament, and tightly bind two veins in the middle section so that the patient will not be weakened.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her rest until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	A wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On Phlebotomy of Veins By Al-bu casis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins of Algeberich are helpful for phlebotomy: because it contributes to the mouthwash, and decay of the gums: and bad ulcers: and bad cracks of the lips, and bad ulcers, also those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of bloodletting is that you make the sick person sit before you and tighten his neck with a band.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn back the lip and look at two veins: one is from the right side of the lip, and the second from its left side: and the demonstration of both is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because on the circumference of them are veins, small and black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore cut both sides with a double incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is doubt about you, and you do not know which of them it is: then attend to the incision of the larger ones, and those more obvious.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do this with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and very much indeed is it customary to do so: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On venesection under the tongue after cephalic venesection.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefit of two veins that are under the tongue from lancing is this: that cephalic phlebotomy is for ailments which are in the throat, and pain of the uvula, and pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that the sick person sits between your hands before the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side a vein, and on the other side a vein: and the color of both slopes towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, cut both veins and guard yourself, so that you will not put your hand at the end in cutting them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under it are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the arm.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are opened with a lancet on the arm are those in which the practice of cutting is customary in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bloodletting is done on them in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with a broad myrtle lancet: or olive tree to the fineness of the slope: or cutting with a knife-shaped lancet, and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Al-Zahrawi is, that which is suitable for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And of these there are broad and subtle kinds, according to the width of the veins and their constriction. The form of a myrtle phlebotomy should be broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is fitting to open veins that are concave, full, coming forward, appearing, thick, and those which contain coarse, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of lesser width and more refined point.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is fitting for bloodletting of veins fine, which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On bloodletting at Basilaca.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica vein, which is one of these three veins for bloodletting, is helpful.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from illnesses that are in the throat and neck, because it follows the chest and belly: and it is fitting for the phlebotomist with the phlebotomy knife to be careful, and to be above fear from it, for under it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs, and adds in puncture of a vein, he incisions that artery, and there occurs the flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary that she be not bled with a sharp lancet: rather let it be cutting with an alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the basilica does not appear with a clear manifestation, then it is necessary that one seeks out another, and transfers it to another, or seeks out another branch of it; or cuts the brachial artery instead of phlebotomizing.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is manifest, and dry it with ananetil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform a bloodletting on him, then before the tightness of the arm, touch the place until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place over the area with a hot iron, then the arm, and cut the vein dry with a curved incision using a  phlebotome Alnesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the percussion fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligature, an inflation in the place which you marked with the encaustic, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rising at venipuncture, like a boy's urine, and it is fine, reddish blood, then know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore hasten and place your finger upon it in a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut (for it is often cut), then bind the arm and release it: and let the patient beware of the movement of it: and be above his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let it not be moved for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If blood does not stop flowing, and it overcomes you, and there is no medicine present at your moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are contracted, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of  bark and grind it fine. Take half of it and bind it over the place where the vein is narrowed with a bandage and poultice until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for the one with him whose predecessor's recollection from the place of dust-cutting flow of blood: and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small place of the wound, and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On Phlebotomy of the Vein called Fusca.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the Fuscae are a help in phlebotomy because they draw blood from the upper part of the head and lower part of the body; because it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the bloodletter that he should be above fear from his phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds in the incision of venesection, and finds a nerve, there occurs in it numbness, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it is not healed completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears many times to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in some people and is subtle and does not appear: then you must place your phlebotomy there, the incision with a sharp knife, and cut the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The vein of the head benefits from bloodletting because it draws blood from the head and brings relief to eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein properly, if you wish, that the phlebotomist prick it with a lancet olive-shaped, or with a myrtle-shaped lancet: because it is the safest of all veins, because there is no artery beneath it, nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Nevertheless, it is fitting for you in phlebotomy to avoid cutting the head of the lizard with the lancet so much, and to seek a softer place: and it does not harm him if it is not found with the first percussion, that it be repeated upon it several times with the lancet.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Yet perhaps a boil may develop in some people when it is not lanced in the first percussion, but this boil does not harm them in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the utility of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its accidents from it, about which you ought to think carefully.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First, therefore, you ought to know that bloodletting is not administered unless for the preservation of health and its perseverance, and caution against the approach of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And let a bloodletting be made in one of the three veins that are in the elbow, namely Cephalic, and Dark, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that venesection be done at the beginning of Spring on an empty stomach, in summer, and autumn, and in winter after a meal, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let a bloodletting be done on the first day, or on the third, after three hours have passed.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting, which is administered in illnesses, does not have a determined hour; but when necessity and convenience call for it, at night or day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And boys should not be bled until they come to fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman shall not be bled, unless from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	The elderly who have passed sixty years should not be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to have a bloodletting for any reason, it is necessary that he cleanse his bowels before the bloodletting with a gentle enema, if there is much retained feces in them: so that the veins during the bloodletting do not draw up putrid superfluities from the intestines which are harmful to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is vomiting from fullness be bled, nor one who is drunk or suffering from drunkenness until that has passed from him.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be avoided again after colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the belly, and multiplication of intercourse, and labor, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in the subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he enters the bath, if nothing prevents him; or he is exercised with some exercise, so that the blood may be made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy of him in his chest, about the third day, as we said: and endeavor that his chest be evacuated on that day from all accidents of evil animals: such as anxiety, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and punishment, and superfluity, and those similar.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make present to his seat things of which use men have grown accustomed from fragrance and scent and excitement and similar things as much as possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the bloodletter should sit on a stool, which is higher than the patient's bed; afterwards he takes out his arm and rubs it with his hand twice, or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tighten the bandage with corrections and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, for when a constriction is unequal, either through an excess in the constriction, then it prevents the course of blood; or in softening, then also it prevents the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after constriction, it is necessary that the surgeon rub his hands together with a cloth until the veins swell and are apparent to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist shall clean the lancet with a little oil, an old one in particular.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of the left hand upon the vein in the place where he wants to perform phlebotomy, carefully so that it does not slip away and the blow is not missed.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because of the veins there is which you find like a fleeing chord among the bloodletters: and from them is that which is full of windiness: and when you place the bloodletter upon it, it contracts under the bloodletter, and the bloodletter is deceived, and does not open the vein: and if he opens it, it is strict: therefore it is necessary that the bloodletter be firm, and be solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should put down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore a vein is opened from one place, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if this does not happen, then repeat the same thing in another place nearby, or above it with haste: if the place does not suppurate.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it is suppurating, or the patient grows weak, then dismiss him on one day, or two days: and let him not tighten a bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it will draw a hot abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Let him not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let a bloodletting be done, if he desires.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the incision is small, or if blood runs subtly and you fear that not the quantity of blood which you wish will leave; then repeat the phlebotomy in the very hole according to straightness, and add a little in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with speed, before the place becomes closed up, for an infected place is in many men at a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see the abscess itself, then you do not go over it at all, for it does not excuse anything to you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something of the oil of feces upon it; because it will lessen the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than the rest of the olive.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the feces of oil in all your bloodletting, where you bleed veins at the stopping of the flow of blood; and they do this with tyriaca alfarach, and sagzena, when it is placed from one of them on the spot.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood is refined and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it happens that a large abscess occurs at the site of phlebotomy, for often this happens, especially to those who are not subjected to phlebotomy except when necessary, or whose vein opening is small, then immediately place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated briefly, over the site; and bind it for one hour: because it will be resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has exited from the vein itself, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something remains in the place after days, some blackness, or greenish color, it does not harm. And if you wish, place upon it something of aloe, or myrrh dissolved, or something from the juice of mint, that is, spearmint, or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And very often indeed abscesses and swellings occur at venesection in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Place therefore your hand upon it, then if you find softness at your compression upon it, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, be careful that you place something upon it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of an artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a poultice for him with that which has astringency so that the place may close.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as well as the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you remove from every man according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color prevailing over blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	If the blood is black, then let it exit until it becomes red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it go out until it becomes fine; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And he who is full, strong, and needs a single bloodletting, let the vein be widened, and the incision should be wide. And in him who is weak, let it be the opposite of this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he removes it with a probe and that the opening be narrow; and better yet which is administered in phlebotomy of the vein is, that there be a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this way of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and healthier than bloodletting across width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to him who is accustomed to faint during bloodletting, it is necessary that he eat before bloodletting bread moistened with a little pomegranate juice, or heated cumin, if it is available; and draw from his blood in three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if he is of a cold constitution, then let him take before the bloodletting bread soaked in syrup of honey, or in syrup of honey flavored with spices, or in aromatic and fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If fainting should occur during bloodletting and the cause is the exit of much blood, then it is necessary that he takes a drink of meat water and a subtle aromatic syrup. And let him use the aroma with algae, and anoint his chest with it. And let him use the rest which we said in the division in the chapter on syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wants to bleed his arm and release his blood the second time: he who has a phlebotomy for the sake of great evacuation, and whose strength is weak, must let his blood out gradually by the amount of strength over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	He who wishes to open his arm and let out his blood a second time, and his body is strong, then let him do this after seven hours, or nine from his first incision.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	He who wishes to draw blood from his body to the opposite part from which it inclines: it is necessary that he be bled on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In the body which has a great deal of blood now heated and sharpened, and causing fever to occur: it is necessary that the blood should exit from it in one vein, and a large quantity be extracted: and the opening should be widened until fainting occurs: after you have carefully observed all the conditions of phlebotomy: and so that you place your hand over his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death may not occur instead of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Often indeed it happens when the bloodletter does not know, and negligence falls.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you wish to loosen the arm and loosen the blood second, with the opening of the vein already closed, and let the blood flow out be difficult, that one should apply excessive force upon it, and it is quickly extended.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a great evil, indeed let it be put aside until it is lanced a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with the sharpness of a lancet what has clotted from blood at the opening of the vein, and put something salt dissolved in water on top of it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place upon it something of tyriaca alfaroch, or sagzenea, and place it with a gentle compression, until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If however a vein has already become part of an abscess, then release it, and do not hold it until the abscess sits.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity compels to let blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either the phlebotomist should cut him above that place, or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is cut at the place of Fucus and Basilica, when they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the sick person should insert his hand into hot water until the vein becomes red and appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it shall be bound over itself with a ligament with moderate constriction in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the incision of the vein according to transverse section gradually, not laterally, nor lengthwise: and let the opening be wide, and let your incision of the vein be such that it cuts above the joint of the hand a little.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If he prevents the outflow of blood, then repeatedly put your hand in hot water and let the blood flow into the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If, however, you are on summer days, then you are excused from the repetition of hands in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed very much the course of blood is placed in warm water in time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And bloodletting of this vein is healthier than all veins, because under this vein there is no pulsating nor nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of Saluatella's right hand is good for ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that you should tie up the vein with a bandage or your hand after you have introduced it into warm water until the vein swells and is demonstrated to the sense very much.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomist cuts across it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful, lest you cut with your hand as you use a lancet.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under it are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then apply your hand to warm water and let blood flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	If you do not repeat it in hot water, blood clots at the opening of the vein and is prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you shall have extracted from the blood the quantity of necessity, then put upon the vein oil and salt: that it may not solidify quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly it is necessary that you do with every branch tight.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The wound from the left-hand vein is: because it is connected to spleen sickness; and similarly do you act in its phlebotomy, just as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The benefit of cutting the saphenous veins is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as pains of the womb, and retention of menstruation, and infirmities of the kidneys, and ulcers of the hips and legs old, and similar kinds of ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick person puts his foot into warm water and makes friction above it until the veins are full, and ties above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed the vein is situated near the heel, appearing towards the thumb: and they branch out from it on the face of the foot many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, let the phlebotomist make the incision in the larger branch of it, or near the heel in its collection, because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If he incisions her on the sole of the foot, then carefully avoid the nerves which are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your incision for phlebotomy as if you wish to cut it transversely, and let the lancet be Nisil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the exit of blood is prevented, then bathe his foot repeatedly in warm water: and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the bloodletter errs in the first attempt, then return with phlebotomy to the upper parts for a short time, for the location is safe, and you do not fear evil from it, when you avoid the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the calcaneum from the left side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the treatment of this vein-cutting is for pain in the hip, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that he enters the bath and hastens: and he tightens his leg from the side of the buttock to above the heel four fingers' width, with a fine long bandage: for it does not appear otherwise because of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then the phlebotomist it according to whatever ingenuity is to you possible, or according to the transverse section: and it is better, either that you cut it with incision, or you sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place indeed is safer, and it itself is hidden deep in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the sense: then the phlebotomist should take some branch of it, and it is the one that appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear: and beware of the nerves, and make it run from the blood as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then solve the stricture and place leather over the site of the incision and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly indeed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Blooding and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Instruments are made from horns, and from bronze, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventosaion is performed according to two modes.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With incision and bloodletting, and another is ventilation without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this blowing which is without incision, is according to two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And there are fourteen places in the body which are treated with cupping and scarification and bloodletting.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and ventosae Alhagdahim, and they are two plates of the neck from two parts simultaneously: and ventosae menti, and it is under the jaw in the lower mouth: and ventosae of two spatulas: and ventosae Alachosos above the end of the tail: and ventosae of two focilium, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and ventosae of two legs: and ventosae of two tails.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed ventosaion does not draw blood from the small veins scattered in flesh, and therefore there is no loss of strength from them, as there is in the case of phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not necessary to administer pessaries with or without fire in any illness that arises from repletion, until the whole body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity requires ventosaion from illness, or because of custom, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and at any time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is, because it happens to some men that when blood multiplies in them until the need arises for its removal by venesection, they find heaviness and pressure in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them is he who has found a swelling and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And of these is one who has found itching in his face and forehead, and darkness, and blurring in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is one who digs a place for his ventilation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And of these there is one who finds a taste of blood in his mouth: or his tongue becomes ulcerated and discharges blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see in their sleep blood and redness, and slain and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something of these things, and properly if it is in the third week of the month: we then prescribe that ventilation should be done, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	A wound of the neck's windpipe is, because it brings together to the heaviness in the head, and that which pours out to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	And it is necessary that this be after evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is a suction cup in the place of cephalic venesection.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted to use it by one who has a cold constitution, or who has a cold.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it inflicts great harm upon him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this, it is not necessary that they should use these things, the elderly, and those whose head are afflicted with cold pains.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever is diligent about it, oblivion is generated upon him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason it is necessary that you instruct the Ventilator to lay his hand with a somewhat windy lower, fearing from the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Bloodletting or Alkehel is done in the place of Fuscae phlebotomy and Basilicae phlebotomy, and for this reason it relieves asthma, and constriction of breath, and instruments fissure of breath, and cough, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the Alkehel be driven by a suction cup for a short time, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Bloodletting, however, of the alhagdahim relieves headaches caused by accidents, and ophthalmia, and migraine, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in place of phlebotomy at the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Aspirator so that he does not press his hand when making a cut, lest he hit an artery and there be a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The suctioning under the chin, helps with alcohol in the mouth, and for gum disease, and similar ailments that are in the mouth; and it takes place in the place of phlebotomy elsewhere, which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The inflation of spatulas is helpful for cauterization, which is done by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The suction of the interior parts with two foci helps the phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilicae, and Fuscae, and Cephalicae: because it draws blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins draw from other thicker veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Ventosa to not proceed too far in the scarification; for the place is laid bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The suction cup, when applied over boils, helps with hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Ventor (Suction Pump) to be large and made of metal; because the place needs strong suction, and perhaps finer Suction Pumps break. And let it be scraped with a deep incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Leeches on the legs reduce by manifest decrease because they draw blood from the whole body, and contribute to old pains in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder: they cause menstruation, and contribute to both pain and shortness of breath: and they stand in the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and of the groin.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Nevertheless, they weaken the body greatly, and cause syncope to happen in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the healing of the windpipes is close to the healing of the two leg winds.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the placement of the vents is that you place the vent first empty, and draw (with) a moderate suction: and do not prolong the position of the vents, but place them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place with equal arrival: and do not cease to repeat this and continue, until you see the place already red and swollen, and the redness of blood appears: then therefore scarify, and repeat suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is of men tender flesh, rare pores, it is necessary that he scarify him once, no more: that the place be not ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And tell the Ventusator to enlarge the incision and make it only slightly deep: and temper the suction in ease, and speed, and his own movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickening in the blood, then it is necessary to scarify it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision indeed there is opened a way to subtle bloodletting and its moistening; and in the second indeed, examination of delicate extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is foul indeed, then let a third scraping be made, so that it may reach its end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And lastly, when we wish to draw blood gradually, or a little, one incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to make an extraction of blood, we shall scarify many times with a multiple scarification.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary that it be scarified with a deep incision; and the equal limit in the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What thing ought to be administered from oils at the positioning of Winds, and what should a Wind-stopper beware of.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case, whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and its pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint the places with Ventosare with open, soothing, resolving oils: if it is in summer time, such as alkeiri oil, or violet oil, or almond oil, or gourd seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in wintertime, then oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomile, or syrup: and similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If, however, the surplus is coarse and cold, then the oil should be bitter almond, or balm oil, or white oil, or anise oil: and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If a large incision is to be made in the tender flesh, it must be prohibited from oil, and this place must be washed after the operation with rose water, or cold water, or solar water, or water of cucumber, or water of purslane, and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of much moisture, wash wounds with vinegar, or myrtle water, and sumach, and the like.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	If these superfluities are coarse, he should wash his windy parts with old wine, or with wormwood water, or an infusion of anise or chamomile: and the like.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that ventilation be avoided in the bath, or in the vestige of the bath, indeed it is necessary that it be administered after exiting the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for someone to sleep after venesection.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is that which ought to be regulated before venesection, namely phlebotomy?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after this it is necessary to consider first: then if he be suffering from a wind or phlebotomy and is choleric, and his blood is overwhelmed by sharpness and inflammation; then it is necessary for him to receive cooling things, such as pomegranate juice; and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and secanabin, and iuleb; and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place his food chicks and meats of sheep, and foods cooked with herbs: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if its complexion is cold, it is necessary that it take in drink syrup of honey, or of althea, or asclepion made from seeds: and it should take medium fragrant wine, which is between old and new: and it should be prescribed that it use little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put food for him of chicks, and canebir: and sparrows, that is, small birds: and collared dove chicks as well.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of venesection and phlebotomy be more than food; and it is necessary that in some men in the hours before venesection,  tyriaca alfaroch or medicine of musk, that is to say muscata, or alesselithe be given before venesection: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the main limbs are strengthened and the blood is refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not right that they should take it in a heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On varices without incisions.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Those incisions which are without incision are called evacuations which are placed over the liver, and spleen, and foot, and over the abdomen, navel, and places of the kidneys, and hip joint; because these members do not allow incisions upon themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through these, except for either attachment from a member of blood to a member: such as we place the Ventose upon the nipples in the affliction of nasal blood flow.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to loosen coldness of wind unseen in a member: as when we place a poultice over the belly and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it indeed thins out the limb, and heats it, and removes pain because it dissolves that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed over the kidneys when there is a swelling or stone in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For with the force of its pull it perhaps opens up a wound, or removes a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly he does when it is placed over the liver, and the spleen in case of inflammation in both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventouses are administered with incisions only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they administer tepid water filled in affections of the pleurae: and that is so that it may be filled with a ventouse, and be large, hot water only, or water in which herbs which are suitable have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of a pessary administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be two finger-breadths, according to what we have formed: and let its quantity in depth be half a palm: and let there be on its side, in the place which is about the middle of it, a small hole, according to the quantity which would enter it with a needle: let it be made simultaneously of copper or brass, of gross margin, soft, equal, and smooth: so that it does not injure the limb when it is placed upon it: and let there be in its middle a transverse rod of copper or iron, where a candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this is made wind-filled large, larger than we have narrated, and somewhat less than that, according to the ailments and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For boys and thin people there are other kinds of ventosaes than those for men and those with large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of placing this wind-blown one with fire on the limb is, that you light a torch with fire from linen properly, or a small candle from wax: and place it above the middle of the transverse bar which is in the middle of the wind-blown: so that the fire be kindled about the lower part of the wind-blown, so that the body of the sick person does not burn.
