Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then a finger is to be placed over the limb, and the finger should be over the opening that I have said, until when we hold the windpipe: while we need it, remove the finger, and vapor will emerge over that opening, and the windpipe will immediately loosen.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then apply the fire lick according to its measure, and repeat it if needed.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the Ventous however which is administered in the pain of pleuritis with water, there is no transverse rod, nor hole: and it is not administered unless it is filled with water, and placed upon the limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this suction cup, the larger it is, so that it may take much water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	On the suspension of bloodletting.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter Ninety-Nine.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Leeches are not administered in many cases, except in those members where the position of venesections is not possible, because of their small size, such as the lip, and gums, and similar ones.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in a denuded limb, such as a finger, and nose, and things like them.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: that they be obtained from leeches which are in sweet waters, pure from corruption.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then let them be placed day and night in fresh water until they are famished, and nothing remains in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body shall be evacuated first with phlebotomy and with cupping.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wipe the limb of the infirm until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterwards they are to be placed upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are therefore filled and fall and there is possible suction of the place with a windpipe, then it is more ultimate in healing: and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water it is rubbed and squeezed.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood continues after the application of leeches, and it is still oozing, then place a linen cloth soaked in cold water on top, until the bleeding stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood multiplies, then pulverize upon it  zegi or ground gall, and similar things from styptics, until the bleeding is stopped.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or let half beans, their outer skin removed, be placed over the place: and they be left until the beans adhere to the place, for the blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if repetition of bloodletting is necessary, when possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If leeches are forbidden from suspension, then the place shall be wiped with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Either fix a point (of) an awl in places until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are to be placed, for when they themselves feel something from the blood, they immediately adhere.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When therefore you wish them to fall, pulverize upon them something of crushed aloe, or salt, or ashes: and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A universal discourse on restoration, and dislocation, and cure of torsion, and the like.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This Chapter is also many times necessary in the art of Medicine, and it is the restoration of fractures and dislocations of accidents in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, O Sons, that those who boast about this Chapter are the foolish doctors and the common people, and those who have never looked at the book of ancients or read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And because of this cause, this mode is deprived of sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never found anything good in it whatsoever, and I have not attained from it that which I have attained except because of the length of reading ancient books, and study above understanding them, until I extracted knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then by experience and study throughout my life's length.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you in this Chapter all that contains my knowledge: and above what has passed experiment, after I have abbreviated it for you, and freed it from the occupation of elongation, and abbreviated it at the end of abbreviation, and showed it at the end of declination: and I have formed in it many forms from the forms of instruments which are administered in it, as it is by addition of declination, just as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summaries, and collections from there being fractures of bones, from those whose premiss is necessary before we begin the remembrance of broken limbs, and various ones, each one by itself.
Caput II.	Head II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary, as we say at the beginning of this Chapter, that the greatest discourse and chapters, to the understanding of which the artisan first must be brought to the station over their truth: namely, that you, and those who are ready, may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore, that when it happens to anyone a fracture, or dislocation, or torsion, or fall: then it is necessary, that you hurry first to bleed him, and release him, or both together; if nothing prevents it, such as weakness of strength: or he is one who has happened something of those children, or an old man decrepit: or the time is vehement heat, or vehement cold indeed.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be content with his food, with cold herbs and the flesh of birds and hares: and forbid wine, and coarse meats, and filling oneself from foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until when you are secure from the hot abscess, and do not fear the effusion of matter to the limb: then let the sick person return to his first regimen with which he used to custom.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore a broken bone begins to heal, it is necessary for the sick person to be fed with nourishing foods, much, thick, heavy, containing viscosity: such as food made from boiled wheat with water, and rice, and heads, and feet, and bellies of oxen, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and things similar to these.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this treatment clotting of a fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that fractured bones, when they are in old men who are in the first old age, and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be continued and consolidated according to their own nature always, because of the drying out of their limbs; and those that are consolidated and continued from them are at the end of their softness, like the bones of young children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless nature attaches something like glue to a broken bone from every side, which has thickness, so that it adheres and binds it until they are joined together, and bound together, until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was in the first place, until nothing prevents it from its operations: and because of this cause it is necessary that you put food for the sick with heaviness, viscosity, and thickness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the kinds of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of the limbs; for a fracture of the thigh is different from a fracture of the bone of the head: and a fracture of the bone of the chest is different from a fracture of the bone of the back: and similarly all the other limbs exist diversely one from another: and I have come with remembrance of every kind of fracture laid out in its own chapter distinct from another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And there are various kinds of bone fractures even within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because it is fractured with an arc, besides which stars occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes a fracture of it is made according to the length of the bone: and there are fractures of it stars, that is, splinters, and additions proceeding, as they are in a reed, when it is fitted with a knife to write.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And if it does not proceed: and there is a fracture with a wound and disruption in the head: and there is a small fissure fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And every kind has its own natural talent, or proper instrument in the restoration of it, according to what comes to mind, distinguished in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from that which is known to be a fracture of bone, is its crookedness, and its prominence: and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When therefore there is no apparent twisting in place, nor a sound at your touch when you touch the bone with agitation, nor does the patient find great pain: then there is no fracture there, indeed it is possible that there is a twisting, or a small fissure: therefore it is not necessary that you move it with your hand and compression at all, rather put on top of it medicines of which remembrance comes, after the time that is convenient in place: then the constriction is tightened finely.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is bent and split into two, and besides this abscesses occur in it, nevertheless, all parts are removed from their counterparts: then you must begin at your hour for its rectification, by leveling it before a hot abscess occurs to it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If a hot abscess occurs, then let it alone for several days, until the abscess is quiet.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equal it with whatever means it can by gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that its restoration and its equalization is easier than bones, in which wounds occur often.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it, according to how you will remember it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are splinters in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this limb fractured from two parts, if it is a hand or foot: or with your hand, if the limb is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be such that you place the limb upon a level place, according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the broken limb are extended; then endeavor, that you may return those additions with all skill, and according to whatever way you can in their places. And beware, according to your strength, lest there happens super infirmum through your operation pain, nor injury: and endeavor, according to your strength, that you apply one of the two bones with its companion, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour, that you test and touch him with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different, rectify it, and equalize it by the quantity of your virtue.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of vehement extension and strong compression, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For many times they cause a hot abscess to happen by that operation of theirs, or a contraction in the limb: as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then bind after setting, and a proper operation, and constriction of that limb, and rest, and tranquility: and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him guard himself so that he does not move himself at the hour of his vigils, and in his sleep, and at his revolution, and agitation, and at his excretion, and all his movements with his last virtue.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And that it may prevent (the member) from being placed in a position that follows with pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when he feels pain or injury in the arrangement of a limb's position, then it is necessary to change it to another arrangement from that with which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with it, that its position be equal and straight, so that there does not happen crookedness in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the constriction of the broken limb is, according to what I relate.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that broken limbs are diversified in their smallness, and their magnitude, and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Therefore, those which are small, such as the arm, and finger, and foot, and similar to these, then it is necessary that there be a wrapping of soft cloth, fine.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those which are gross among them, such as the hip and leg, ought to have a wide, tough bandage applied to them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because the broad ligament connects the large limb and binds it on every part with an equal constriction so that it does not enter upon it a stain.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then after your evacuation, begin to apply a suitable liniment to the equation, on soft wool over the place of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the bandage over the place of the fracture itself with three or four wrappings, according to what the limb deserves: and tighten your hand a little with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with him to the upper part from the place of the fracture, and tighten less than was your constriction, which you constricted the broken place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then stretch yourself with the winding from the place of the fracture a little, and soften the stricture gradually, until you grasp a large thing from the healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another strip, and again wrap it over the broken place with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Thereafter go with the wrapping towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be on stricture of involution, and its softening, according to what we said in the first superior involution.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the bandages lint or cloth, with which the curvature of the fracture may be matched, if it has curvature; and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wind a bandage over the wound itself.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Afterwards, equal superpositions of these involuted stars are made centrally, immediately, if there is no inflation in the place, nor a hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If there is inflammation or an abscess in it, then place over it what sits upon that abscess and remove the inflammation, and leave it for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then bind above it the very stars.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the Astrellae be from the middles of broad canes, scraped and wisely shaped; or let them be from wood from which sieves are made, which are made from pine, or geraid, that is, palm branches, or calingi: and let the breadth of every Astrella be according to this form, and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	Nonetheless, the asterisk placed over the very area should be thicker and a little wider than the rest of the asterisks: and the length of the asterisk should be according to what is permissible for the limb in terms of size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tighten over the Astellas with another witta, according to the first tightening.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind above with threads properly, according to what we said about constriction: and let it be, that your constriction be above the place of the fracture more: and the less the constriction, the farther it is from the fracture.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and that they be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	Because if the threads are thick, as I saw from the operation of foolish surgeons who put their threads from twisted hempen cords, it is a great error because the constriction falls with them outside of quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And very fine threads are not suitable again; because you do not attain through the stricture with them what you wish.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not right that there be less than a finger's width between star and star.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If a sick person is injured by the extremities of the stars after constriction in healthy places: then put under them soft cotton or carmine wool until nothing is hurt from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When, however, there is a fracture with a wound, and rupture occurs in the skin, I shall come to it with remembrance of it in the second chapter according to singularity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken limb ought to be bound with splints from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	That is, because when a limb is large, it is not necessary to place stars on top of it, unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security from the event of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the way of plasters which ancients used to restore, which are placed upon a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The Method of a Common Plaster, Shortened for Restoring a Fracture, Suitable for Many Complexions, Especially Women and Children; because it is from that which does not conquer heat, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is, as you take from the flour of the mill, and there is marrow of flour which hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone: and you make it like this, except that sieves it with the membrane of an egg white: and put its preparation not thick, nor subtle.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	One method of poultice for restoring a fracture, dislocation, and torsion.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take  of mass, and laudanum, and acacia, and enula, and mugath; and juice of all, each ʒ X, myrrh, and aloe both, each ʒ V and alethil ʒ XX. Grind all together, sift them, and mix with alethil water; or with egg white, if the patient's condition is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, it restores broken bones quickly, and helps many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	Another mode of plaster which also helps with fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take powdered mugwort, and meal, and white clay, each in quantity of X grains; myrrh, and aloes both in quantity of V grains; acacia VI grains; Armenian bolis XX grains; grind all together with much trituration, and sift them, and make into a paste with water, or egg white: and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	A method for plasters on joints and bones separated from their places, and it soothes pain that happens to them, and a crack in the bone, and a fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take wool fleece and immerse it in vinegar and boiled oil, and place it over the area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good in the calming of a hot abscess; and it expels pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	The Method of a Plaster for Restoring a Broken Bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take leaves of fig tree and leaves of wild poppy; and pound all, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	The method of abbreviated plaster application, administered at the restoration of a broken bone; and when you desire the resolution of the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take the root of althea, and chamomile, and violets' flowers, and herb flour, all one part each: grind everything together, and mix it with wine, if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is heated, then apply it with moistened coriander water, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	A stronger mode of plaster for resolution, than this first one, is used when a hard abscess occurs at the restoration of a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take root of althea, and flaxseed, and balaustiae, and melilot, and tansy, and violet flowers, and chamomile, each one part, grind them all together, and make them with willow water, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	The whole thing according to the heat of the limb, and the quietness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	However Hippocrates did not say in his book that upon the restoration of a broken limb, anything should be placed upon it except for a plaster made from linen and oil: nothing else; and he narrated that it should be a medium between thickness and thinness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen thought it was necessary to place on the broken limb during its restoration things that have dryness of heat, such as myrrh, and aloes and frankincense, and similar things to those which we have narrated.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	A method of a poultice which is applied to injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take mugwort, chickpeas, and human hair cut or feathers of a bird,  and plantain, and salt in equal parts; grind them and sift them, and make a plaster from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity however according to what is proper, when the bandage should remain, then be dissolved, is, that you consider then, if it does not happen to the sick person pain, nor itching, nor is the broken bone moved from its place: then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If it happens to him in the place itching vehement, or unrest pain, or inflation: then hasten, and solve in an hour him, and remove the plaster from him: and take a soft cloth, or a soft sea sponge, humid: and submerge it in tepid water, and wash with it the place, until itching calms down, and sits the pain.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place over it a cloth soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night one, until you are secure from the hot abscess, and the swelling of the limb rests, and its pain is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then bring him back again to the slight stricture, and a small plaster; and do not tighten him with your first constriction, and more subtle with him, until he heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, and swelling, and all accidents have been completely removed, and it is no longer painful from plaster or constriction, then treat it again as you did at first, equally well.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing of those things which we have said happens to a limb, then do not unwrap it, unless after three, or four, or five, or seven days.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is released after twenty days, the whole thing, according to what appears to you from the solution of the limb, as we said, until when the fracture adheres and coagulation of flesh approximates upon it: add also then in stricture more than your first stricture altogether: and add also in the increase of the sick person's food, according to what preceded recollection of it.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see that the place of a fracture has already dried up and widened more than is necessary, then know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore, embroider it with warm water at every turn where you have dissolved it, and let it be in all three days, and alleviate the stricture a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Therefore, by this operation nourishment runs to the limb and it is healed quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	That which foolish restorers do from a broken limb with another vice, when it is not restored at first, according to what is right, and restored according to crookedness, is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it were straight, they would have said this in their books, ancients, and operated upon it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I did not see anywhere among them a trace of it, and it is better that it not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	On the making of an accident in the head.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	There are diverse kinds of fractures, and its figures are many; and its causes are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For from a fracture is made which happens by a blow with a sword: and the blow takes away the bone entirely as far as it reaches to the siphac, which is under the bone, just as an ax does in wood: and for this reason this kind of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or if a sword strikes something of the bone and strikes its face, and the incision does not penetrate to its very end: this kind of fracture is called Kalaan, that is, absolute loosening.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a wound of two fractures, either great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from a fracture is, which is crushing, or attrition: and its cause is percussion with a stone, or a fall onto a stone, or things similar to these.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which already approaches the flesh under the bone; or it is on the face of the bone; and is a wound of these two fractures even small, or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And from a fracture is this one, which is hidden in the bone in the fineness of hair: and it is a small crack, and because of this this kind of fracture is named capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these is a fracture, which is made by chance, or by the striking of a stone, and things similar to it, which cause the layer of bone to go into the inside, and concavity is made: as happens to kettles of air, when a blow occurs to them, and part of them goes into the inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And most of all this happens in the heads of damp bones, such as are the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And with all these types of fractures, splints are made separate, and I come with a recollection of the whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these kinds of fractures by detection upon it, and inquiry into them with probes, and removal of corrupted flesh which is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The type called capillary is recognized by this, that it is discovered over the bone, and removed, and smoothed over it with encaustum; for indeed a fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the patient's condition: then if you see from the conditions that signify clearly dangerous symptoms, such as vomiting of bile, and stretching, and loss of intellect, and cutting off of voice, and fainting, and acute fever, and discharge from the eyes, and redness of them, and similar to these in many dispositions, undoubtedly he is not healed: and if you see non-earthly conditions, and hope for salvation: then begin his treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if a wounded person comes to you first when he is wounded, and it happens on cold days, then you must strive for the removal of the bone before the fifteenth day according to all arrangements.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the summer days, then it is necessary that you hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone from the flap spoils and those accidents happen which we narrated.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If a fracture of the bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and it is with small pieces, and attraction: then it is necessary, that you cut the broken part, and rubbed, according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is, as you cut the head of the wounded: and cover over the bone according to any manner possible to you; and according to the figure of the wound, and what is light upon the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it happens to you in the detection of a bone that there is bleeding, or a hot abscess; then oppose it with what is fitting.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is, that you fill the place with cloths soaked in wine, and rose oil: and make the wound rest until the abscess sits, and be secure from blood flow.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin in the cure of bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of two modes.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One way is to cut the jaw with a sharp, straight knife: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then administer another incision after the incisions, a little wider than the previous ones: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then administer also another incision wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is that you have a number of different incisions, some wider than others, and some shorter than others: and let them be at the end of their sharpness, and let them be made of iron or lead: and use ease in striking upon the incision so that it does not strike the head and harm it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the bone is strong and hard: then it is necessary that you perforate around its edge, before you administer the cutting instrument, with boring instruments which are called Trebelles which do not go deep: and they are not named thus, unless because they themselves do not pass through the boundary of the bone to that which is behind it; for Terebellum has a rounded end above that which is below its sharp head, similar to a margin, and a small circle prevents submerging and passing through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it behooves you to take from these terebrums a great number, each one corresponding to the quantity of thickness of the bone, until you have for the present skull all terebrums: whose acute extremities' quantity in length and shortness shall be according to the quantity of thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three kinds of Borers, or Trephines.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of piercing around the broken bone is: that you place the borer over the bone, and turn it with your fingers until you know the bone has been pierced.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then move the terebinth to another place, and put it where it is between every hole the quantity of thickness of a radius, or about that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with the Incisors which is between every foramen out of bone: and make it more delicately than you can over it from the end of levity, as we have said, until you eradicate the bone, or with your hand, or with some other of certain instruments which you have prepared for it: such as tenaculae, and fine forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary that you carefully avoid letting the terebrum or scalpel touch anything from the sheepskin.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you surround the bone by perforating it, and having separated it from the soft tissue if it has been continuous with it, and having extracted it, it is necessary that you smooth, and make equal the extremity of it which remains in the bone with another similar instrument incisor.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	Nevertheless, it ought to be thin and subtle more than other scalpels.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If anything remains of the small bones, and bandages: then take those with ease, with what you have among your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the wound after that with ointments and what we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another mode of operation is easy, far from fear: which Galen said, and praised him with great praise: and this is his word.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first of all, to begin to uncover the part of the bone from the place in which the fracture is more violent and more evident: until when you have uncovered that part, and placed under it the extremity of this lenticular Incisor, whose this is the form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lens-shaped part, it does not strike anything gently: and the pointed part of it, cutting into two sides of itself lengthwise, as you see: so that the lens-shaped part rests against the sphenoid bone, its sharp face incident upon the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike upon the incision with one side of a small hammer until you cut through the entire bone with ease, as it turns; and be secure from the cloth that no mishap will occur in it which you should fear at all.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the surgeon were not more foolish than men, and less ignorant of this, and were not asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the flesh in some places, he would cut it off from there with the pointed end of a lenticular knife, and free it from there with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It can be removed from him without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the bone fracture does not penetrate to the subcutaneous tissue, and what is cut off from the bone is its surface, and there remain in it roughness and subtle chips: then it is necessary that you scrape that roughness, and eradicate those chips with fine razors of which you have prepared a number of different sizes, so that it will be possible for you to administer them in every suitable place, and make them straighter, according to what the operation leads you to, and the broken bone, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you administer in your cutting, where in first rays of bone, wider those of razors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease doing this according to continuity, until you come to administering finer and more subtle of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In every small fissure or capillary fracture, one must administer care according to that which leads to its straightening.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And there is a thing that is not hidden from everyone who studies this art, and it stands upon what we have written and shown in major fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	If however the subcutaneous tissue is exposed and remains when you eradicate the bone, then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the quantity of the wound, and submerge it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another doubled or tripled cloth and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and do this as easily as you can so that it does not chafe it.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer above this wide ligament: and do not tighten it unless by the quantity which holds the wound only: and release it with this care on one day, or two days, until you are certain about the absence of a hot abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it and administer after that medicines with which there is superfluous dryness; such as lily roots, and herb flour, and frankincense powder, and asarabacca, and things similar to these: and let it be, so that you make a powder out of these medicines, which is powdered over the wound like those that are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer in it all medicine of its property that it may cleanse and not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And care according to your skill, so that the wound in your treatment may be clean; and let there not be in it filth of ointment, nor uncleanness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Do not allow the virus to gather in it at all; for when the virus gathers above the brain's padding, it spoils and putsrefies it, and a great evil happens to the sick after that. And this happens in the head's siphac, when it is cleansed from it os, especially when care of it is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider, if misfortunes of the kind we have said happen to the sick person, know that it is undoubtedly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur, unless from the medicine which is placed upon it, and it is in the virtue of that medicine, to make that blackness: then it is necessary, that you take one part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and linen cloth with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it on a sieve: afterwards care for it with appropriate kinds of treatment until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the parts of the nose are not broken except the two upper ones together, or one of them; because the lower part is cartilaginous and does not break, and it happens to it only attrition, and twisting, and things like these.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then it is necessary that you introduce a small finger into the nostril opening and equalize that fracture with your index finger and thumb until the nose returns to its natural shape; and let this be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware lest through your operation that pain befalls the weak.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger cannot reach it, then it is necessary to level it with the end of the radius, where there is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If a fracture is in two parts, then make a likeness of it; and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day at rest of the hot abscess.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce into the extremity of the Nose a liniment made from linen cloth, if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two ligatures if the fracture is in two parts: and let the ligature be of such thickness as to fill the nostril opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said that they should be infused with linen in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	It does not appear to me, indeed it ought not, that licinium should be poured into the albuginea, after being mixed with mill powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then dismiss the splint until the bone is firm and the cartilage hardens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nostril in place of a splint, after it has been wrapped with a soft cloth: and it is done so that it holds the fracture of the nose more firmly, and so that the sick person is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this thing is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do this; and if you wish, do that other thing.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If it happens that the nose again becomes hot during the operation of a boil, apply a plaster to the nose with cauterium, or with cotton wool soaked in rose oil, or a small amount of dyacylon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If a hot abscess does not occur, then it is necessary to cover it with a plaster made of sesame meal and the powder of frankincense mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place a soft wad on top of it, and do not apply anything at all to the nose.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If the bones of the nose are broken in a small fracture or splintered, then it is necessary to cut over them and remove them with instruments which are suitable for this purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then suture the incision, and treat it with what is becoming, that it may become flesh and consolidate from suitable plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary to cure it with linens: and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	On the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken, and the fracture is not with a wound, then look if it is only a break on the outside, and does not break in two, and is curved inwards: then its knowledge is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if there is a fracture in the right part, you must insert your left index finger into the bone of the injured: similarly, if the fracture is in the left jawbone, then introduce the index of your right hand: and drive with it the prominence of the fracture inward with ease to the outside with your other hand from the inner part of the bone centrally, and with it equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jawbone has already been separated into two parts, then it is necessary for you to administer extension from both parts, according to the straightness; until it is possible to equalize it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If a tooth has been shaken or broken, then bind those of which you hope will remain with a thread of gold, or silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a splint over the broken jawbone.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place upon that doubled cloth, and place above the cloth a large splint made centrally: or a piece of sole leather equal in length to the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it above, according to how the bandage is prepared for you, and it is fitting that its application should be made until it is destroyed: and order the sick person, that he may have peace and quiet: and put food of his intake soft.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If, however, you estimate that something is changing in form in some way: then hasten, and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been altered from it, and apply a plaster to it from ground powder, with albuginea or with sesame flour, after you have removed the caper. And place wool on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While therefore that plaster remains attached to it, and the arrangement of the bone does not change, let him release it, so that he may not loosen it, until it is healed: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is often set in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If meanwhile a hot abscess occurs, then administer that which we have said many times for its suppression, until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	Now the fragment is separated from the bone, or from the saw: then be more careful in this, so that you may remove those fragments of the saw with that which is convenient to you in their removal from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If however the opening of the wound is narrow, then widen it with a surgical knife according to the quantity of necessity.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed all the scabs and there is nothing left of them, then close the wound opening if it is wide; and if not, place over it from cloths which are suitable for it, and cover it until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the collarbone when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The collarbone is broken most frequently from the front part from the side of the shoulder, and its fracture occurs according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or else it is broken and separated into two, besides which things may happen in it; and it is easier to restore it.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or so it happens in bone fractures; and it is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or so, which is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation on it when there is a fracture without a wound is, that you have two assistants present, so that one of them holds the instrument that follows the fractured fragment, and the other extends the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalize the fracture with your fingers until it forms its proper shape, so that there is neither prominence nor concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If the indiges extends more, then it is necessary that you place under the patient's sphere a piece of cloth, or wool: and let its size be according to the quantity of your necessity: and extend, and elevate the furculum, and constrict the sphere with your hand, until the fracture is equal, as is necessary.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you are unable to draw the extremity of the clavicle outwards because it has reached deep inside, then it is necessary for the patient to lie on their neck and place a pillow medium in size under their shoulder. Have an assistant press the patient's shoulder downwards until the clavicle that is in the depths is raised upwards. Then straighten the fracture and align it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a splinter from the clavicle, and it moves: then it is necessary that you find it above it, and extract that splinter with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is held in the bone, then devise an incision into it with one of the Incisors that you have prepared for it, after you have placed under the Furcula the instrument which saves sifach; and it is an instrument out of wood, or out of iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is similar to a drinking horn that has no concave shape.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And let its width be according to that which you require it from the magnitude of the bone, and its smallness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	The length of it also according to what is possible for you to the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it should have two extremities, as you see; and one extremity be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, the wound that you opened when you extracted the bone fragment is wide and you fear an abscess from heat, then bring together the two edges of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the rupture is small, or a hot abscess threatens: then fill the wound with pads and lint according to the size of the wound's cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot abscess occurs, then pour linen dipped in rose oil, vinegar, and wine onto it and place it on top.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	A stricture of bone when it is without a wound and without a section, is, as you put upon the bone a plaster made from mill flour with the white of egg.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft plug upon it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under its [titillicum], if it does not fit.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a hemamat, that is, a wheel which the Saracens hold, which should be long quite a bit; and let its width be that of one palm, or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a small doubled pad over the cotton and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a star from a fine board, whose width is three fingers, and in length likewise.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that cloth with a star in the place of the splints which falls over the fracture and place.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place a splint on the fracture as it revolves, and wrap it over its neck, and under its healthy collarbone, and under its injured collarbone: and reduce it over all parts, and how you see that constriction holds the fracture, constricting properly: and this is what is not hidden from you, and the whole, so that it is not removed star from above the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason it is necessary that you look at the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever therefore the ligament is softened, and you see the starlet already being removed: then straighten it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the sleep of the patient upon his back, and place under his pillow near his sleep a small cushion at night, so that when he is lifted it may aid him from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, a fracture of the clavicle is raised by elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Either bind the arm to the neck of the person: and do not loosen the bandage unless an accident happens in the place from itching, or from a boil, up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the dressing, if you see its face suitable for it.
