Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When therefore dislocation happens to anyone, then it is necessary to hasten to its restoration: and do not delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place will become a boil, and perhaps with it a reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, it is not necessary that it be moved or extended during the hour of its suppuration.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For often it causes spasms and painful pains.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this happens, then it is necessary that you hasten to bloodletting of the sick man.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it shall be left alone until the abscess rests.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb will be sutured with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And every limb is cured with that which comes to its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have indeed arranged the chapters on dislocation, also as before with respect to fracture, from the upper part of the body to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	On the treatment of a dislocated lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	Two jaws are rarely dislocated.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And dislocation of both occurs according to one of two modes.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are removed from their places with slight removal and softened for a short time.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated by dislocation, whole and complete, until they are softened to the part of the chest, until the saliva of the sick runs and he is not able to hold it, nor can he close his mouth, and his tongue is entangled with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When the dislocation is small, it returns to many positions by itself with little effort.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If it is a complete, entire dislocation, then it is necessary that reduction be administered quickly, and it should not be delayed at all: and let the minister hold the head of the sick person, and let the physician insert his thumb into one side of the jawbone's root between its bones, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he may insert two thumbs at once, if the dislocation is from two parts.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hand be outside, with which he may equal it.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the sick person to cleanse his jaws and finish them for eating on every part.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician sets the jaw and pushes the jaw until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If the reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are involved, then administer an evaporation with hot water and oil until easy reduction of both is achieved.  Do not delay the reduction of both at all, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When therefore they return and become equal, and the bone of the infirm is closed, and are not softened: then put above them small cakes of cloth, with cerate which is made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it is bound with ease with soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the sleep of the sick person be upon his back: and his head should stand between two pillows, so that he does not move it to the right or left: nor try, or be compelled to chew anything: indeed put his food in a gentle broth, until when the pains are removed, and the jaw is knotted: then eat what he wants, and administer it with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He shall not toil upon the operation of his mouth at eating and drinking, and speaking, until the jawbone is knit together, and has healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of the two jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at some time and do not return to their places, then often fevers and persistent inflammation occur, and perhaps the patient's belly loosens, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When therefore you see this: then know that it is destruction, and many times he who has this dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the clavicle and the extremity of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collarbone indeed does not dislocate from the inside, because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated to the outside: and that is made known to the sense.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is, that he lie down sick on his back, and extend his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then bind the place with your palm firmly, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place over the same dressing, and pillows, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities which follow the elbow and continue with it, are not dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is dislocated on some day, then it is necessary that it be reduced and made equal according to what we have said, and which has been prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place over the same plasters and pellets and constriction.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the sick person to adhere to tranquility and quiet until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same treatment the extremity of the Humerus is reduced when it is also separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On the reduction of a shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the humerus is not dislocated unless in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of these is that it be dislocated to the part of the thigh towards the lower region.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is, that it be displaced to the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper part of the humerus: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated posteriorly, because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated anteriorly, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is most often displaced and moves downwards towards the groin, especially in those whose flesh is little.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it goes out quickly and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those, however, whose flesh is much, there exists the opposite, namely that it comes out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people a blow, or a fall, and the humerus becomes inflamed with a hot abscess, and it is thought because of this, that it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, you ought to test it until you stand upon its certainty, and then proceed in its cure.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is known that dislocation is when there is a pulling downward of the shoulder; and distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a sound shoulder.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you find among them a manifest diversity, and you find in the head of the Humerus concavity, and under the little one at touch the head of the humerus as if it were an egg: and the weak cannot reduce his hand to his ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest, or upwards: then you find a manifest touch, and it is not hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy when it is recent, or when the boy is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is, that the minister raises his hand upwards.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under its edge, and raise the joint with strength upward to its place: and the assistant will lift his hand and extend it upward.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he places it lower, for he himself returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If however it does not return by that which we have said, and there are many days from the time when the dislocation occurred: then it is necessary that the sick person bathe in hot water, and an embrocation be given which softens and soothes, as if roots of althea, fenugreek, and melilot were decocted in water, and be administered.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the patient is laid on his back: and under his chest a sphere and wool are placed, which is equal between softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician places his heel on the sphere and raises the shoulder with strength, and pulls the hand of the infirm to the lower part.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another assistant shall hold the head of the patient, so that it is not moved downwards: for indeed it returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this method: and it is, that you make present a man who is longer than the sick one, and stand on the side, and introduce his shoulder under the arm of the sick one: and elevate his arm upwards until the sick one is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another assistant shall draw the hand of the infirm to his lower belly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If, however, the weak person is light: then it is necessary that something else be hung with him, so that he may weigh down. For dislocation immediately returns.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is reduced also according to another way: and it is, as if one were to fix in the earth a long piece of wood, whose head be round in shape: like the sleeve of a mourner's robe: that it be not coarse, nor fine.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then soft cloths should be placed under the patient after they have been placed above the head of the wood: and the patient should stand according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then the hand of him shall be extended to the lower part on the other side, and the body shall be extended from the other side with force: for the joint returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its reduction is difficult through all that we have said, then use this treatment: and it is, to take a piece of wood whose length is the quantity of two arms, and its width is the quantity of four fingers, and its thickness is the quantity of two fingers: which has a rounded head, so that the entrance of it into the deep titillus may be eased, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft cloths are bound over the rounded head so that it does not harm the weak wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then a plank should be placed under the patient's arm, so that the hand or arm can be extended over the wood up to the lower part: and the wood is fastened over the assistant and arm and extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then the arm is placed upon the step of the ladder across its width, and the hand is extended downwards, and the rest of the body is suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The junction then enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When therefore the entrance is completed according to whichever way is possible: then it ought to be, that you place under the titillinum a sphere equal in quantity out of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place a prepared plaster made from ground flour with frankincense and egg white over the entire shoulder, as it is turned upwards.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then bind with a strip of linen under the bandage; and roll the band above the plaster; and attach its hand to its neck, and let it go, and do not move its hand for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary that little food be given to the sick person until the limb is restored; because it is more rapid to its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger one is to be placed after seven days, or five, and it is taken out with motion.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If therefore it is strengthened and not softened, then it is already healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If a joint is dislocated many times, because of the humidity that happens to it, or because of another cause: then it is necessary that cautery be administered to it with three holes, according to what was said before in the chapter on cautery.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If all of this is done, and the ligament is loosened after seven days, and the joint does not hold together, and the plaster is reapplied and tightened repeatedly over it, and it does not hold firm, and falls off, and it cannot be elevated to a higher position: then know that the nerves which are to the head of the humerus, have already been cut or stretched or softened: and know that the joint will never heal in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	As for a dislocation that occurs towards the chest and nipple, or to the rear, reduction is carried out with impulse and extension with hands; until it returns, and the rest of the constriction and care are administered until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If it happens after healing that there is heaviness in the limb and slowness in its movement, then let the sick person use a bath many times, until that heaviness is lessened and it returns to its first nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	On the treatment of elbow dislocation.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty, and similarly it returns with difficulty; and indeed it is dislocated to all parts, and especially to the anterior or posterior.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you: because it falls under sight and touch, according to whatever form it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join a dislocated limb with a healthy one, it will be made manifest to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint is concave and cannot flex the arm, nor touch its own shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you hasten, and reduce the dislocation immediately, before a hot abscess occurs to it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if a hot abscess happens to him, its reduction is difficult; and perhaps it does not heal at all, especially when it is towards the rear.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For it is worse than all kinds of dislocations, and of more violent pain; and often death descends with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it when it is one of those things that can be reduced, is, that the hand of him be extended with two hands: and his arm be expanded, and the hands of the physician be above the elbow and below it, and he himself impels the joint with the thumbs of his hands together, or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or if the dislocation is to the front, then it returns so that it doubles its hand with its own hand until it strikes with the root of its palm the elbow which is dislocated.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a violent and strong extension; and let two servants extend the arm, and let two others also hold it, so that it may not move during the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is rolled back to every part after it has been wrapped above the hand with a double length of cloth or a broad bandage.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches a joint with his hand, he should anoint it with oil so that it may be one of those things which help in the lubrication of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then drive the joint with a strong thrust until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after setting it, it is necessary that a plaster be placed upon it which has astringency and drying power with the membrane of an egg; and let the bandage be tightened decently.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm shall be suspended from the neck of the sick person: and let it be released after several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it shall be loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If therefore the joint is fixed in its place, then loosen the ligament from it, and release it.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not well joined, then apply a new plaster and ligament, and leave it for several days until it is tightened.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then dissolve it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If, however, heaviness occurs to him after reduction of the joint, and the position is in motion: then administer humidification in bathing, and gentle friction, and compression, until it straightens, or put on above the hip joint, that is, a fat ram's fleece.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is bandaged, and it is left on it day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove it, and introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When therefore he sweats, then rub the joint with friction tempered.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat upon the same wound with one and then a second and third bath until it softens.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place over it moistened dung of cow, heated with butter, and bind it on top of it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do that several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For it is softened, and returns to its own arrangement.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	On the treatment of dislocations, Al-Zahrawi.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The joints of the hand are often dislocated, that is, the joint between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of its dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Against the other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Nevertheless it is necessary that speed be in the reduction of a dislocation at the hour in which it occurs, before the place becomes suppurating; or else there may happen to it a hot abscess.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of a dislocation in this is, that you place Mahassem’s hands of the weak hand upon a table, and extend the minister's hand: and let the physician put his palm upon the prominence of the joint, and push it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Nevertheless, it is necessary to consider, if the palm has already retreated to the belly of the hand: then let the sick person place the back of his hand on a board at extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is proceeding toward the back of the hand, then let the position of his hand be intrinsically upon the board, that is, the inner part of his hand upon the board, so that the hand of the physician may fall upon that eminence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then bind it with a soothing poultice for the abscess: and dismiss him, and do not repeat this.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	If he does not tolerate it, and you are unable to reduce it after days have passed, but the joint nevertheless remains according to its tortuosity, and it does not harm the patient except that his hand is softened, and cannot grasp anything: then know that the nerves have been severed or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is therefore no skill in it unless it is tightened with a cautery near its edge.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it doesn't matter something.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When therefore Al-Maghassi returns not, then place upon him the plaster which we have recounted.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is bound and left for five days; afterward it is loosened and left again, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If its movement is hindered and something heavy falls upon it, then soften it with warm water and friction several times until it softens.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On the treatment of finger dislocations.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated from any part, or from the palm of the hand, or from its belly: then extend the finger, and drive back the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, and suspend it towards the part to which it is dislocated, and release it for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend him and stretch him until he is equal to straight on that day of his.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore night has come, bind him according to the same account: and do not cease to loosen him in the day: and exercise him with movement: and bind him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for several days until it tightens.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And similarly do this, if it is dislocated to the belly, hand; and bind him to that part itself, and do with him your first operation, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And similarly do this when it is dislocated to the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the treatment of a dislocation of the lumbar vertebrae.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to someone that there is dislocation of the spine of the back or neck, complete, or many vertebrae are removed from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death hastens the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the stool of the sick person comes out without his will, and he cannot hold it; and many times some of his limbs are softened, or two legs of him, or two arms of him, or one of them; or a single hip bone is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed, which is often removed to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	That which is removed toward the rear, is called Gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The cure of this is, as you consider then, if gibbosity happens from childhood: then there is no cure in it, nor is there any healing at all from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	In those things which happen by chance, or blow, or similar events, ancients have already spoken of modes of healing in lengthy speech.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which most does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I myself have now abbreviated from that one, which little excuses itself from much of its proximity to my intention: and in the exposition which I have exposed it, and formed its instrument in a different way from how they showed it and laid it out.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	Therefore I say that in a hunchback which occurs from the front part, there is no remedy or cure.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly in that which is done to both sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from these things, except that which happens on the back properly, as I say: and it is, that the sick person be extended on his face on a level platform near the wall: and that a wet covering be spread under him, so that his chest is not harmed.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight fixed piece of wood is to be placed in the pit in the ground, at the end of the foot, about its head: and another piece of wood about its feet at the other end of the foot: and let the servant hold the wood, and let it not be fastened in the pit.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And another assistant shall hold another.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then wrap above the head of the sick person, and under its hairline a soft, firm bandage: and extend the extremity of the bandage to the wood which is at the head; and bind it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then bind another ligament above its groins, and above its knees, and at its hip joints.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the ligaments and bind them in a piece of wood that is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then let every assistant extend the limb to the part of the wood, and let not two ligatures be removed from their places where they are fixed; however, they shall not be fastened, as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician places his palms upon the vertebra with strength until it returns; or he places a board upon it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he binds his feet upon the table until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If it does not return through this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three cubits.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And the cavity in the wall of which we said was near the infirm, place where the end of the board may enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle board over the Spina.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the physician place his feet upon the other extremity.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And he should bind it well until the joint be contracted and return to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with a lathe which is wrapped with your hand: and it is, as you fix in the earth at the head of the sick person at the farthest foot two beams, whose length shall be the length of one arm: and at his head at the farthest foot two beams.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the length which is between every piece of wood be one palm; and now a hole has been made in every place, through which a rope runs; and let the whole wood be firmly fixed in the earth very much, so that it may not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And a round piece of wood is inserted; and it is a whorl in which the ligament revolves in two holes of two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end is a hole, in which wood is fastened, whose length is a palm with that which turns: and in two other pieces of wood there is similarly that of it.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then bind the ligaments which you have bound in the chest of the sick man to the band that is at his head: and the ligaments which you have bound in his legs to the band that is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then let there be at every lathe a minister, who twists his hand with linen, with which the lathe is turned; and the physician straightens the spine, according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the tourniquet that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the sponge has been returned and the place is leveled, it is necessary to place a dry plaster with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then a plug.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a star made of wood, whose width is three fingers, or thereabouts.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length is the quantity which it takes up of gibbosity, and above the part of the healthy vertebra.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then a bandage is applied with the ligament which we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And let the sick person use fine nourishment until he is healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If some elevation remains in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary that softening and soothing medicines be administered, along with the tablet which we narrated for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now a plate of lead is administered in that.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes there occurs a prominence on the last vertebra of the back: and it is thought to be dislocation through it, and this bone which now protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it ought not be presumed that this medicine should be given to him, for perchance it may happen to cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	On the treatment of a dislocated hip joint.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	Know that the joint of the ankle and the joint of the shoulder never occurs except for a dislocation only; nor does it occur to them as happens to other joints by slight removal and concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the joint of the Ancha is dislocated in four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Which is, because it is displaced forward and backward.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	It is indeed most frequently dislocated towards the interior, and little towards the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment of dislocation inward is: because when you join the sound leg to the unsound, it is longer; and the knee of it is more prominent than that which is sound, and the unsound cannot double its foot at the groin; and there is a place following the groin, an abscess with hot pus, because the head of the hip has already come there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign of him who has a dislocation toward the outside is that those things which are contrary to these happen to him.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of one to whom a dislocation has occurred anteriorly is that he expands the sound leg according to its complement; however, he does not double it without pain which is in the knee: and if he tries to walk, he cannot go forward over it: and his urine is retained, and his groin suppurates, and in walking his foot falls upon his heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of one who has a dislocation to the rear is that he cannot extend his knee, nor can he bend it before he bends his groin: and his leg is also shorter than the other: and his groin is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place of the ilium.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation, however, as you consider it, is, if the dislocation is old, which has already aged with the one having it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer a reduction of it, and it remains according to its disposition: then there is no treatment at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it is not necessary that presumption be made of him entirely.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that case, in which the dislocation is recent, and it belongs to one of the four kinds of dislocation: then hasten to this, so that you will join the joint, and extend it both inwards and outwards, and move it with your right and left hand: for perhaps it will return, and does not need other cure.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If this method does not work, then it is necessary that you prepare a strong assistant, and he should extend the leg from its lower part: either with his hands, or with a bandage, which is tied above the knee: and another assistant should extend his hand from above, so that he may insert his hands under the pubic bone.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he binds with a soft ligament over the root of the hip, and holds the extremity of the other ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let its extension be either from the front part of the groin to the shoulder blade, or from the back part to the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let the extension of all of them be one vice, until the sick person is lifted with his body from the ground and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this kind of extension is a common kind of the four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation returns with what we said, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary to do all kinds of that which I shall say about proper cure.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	When indeed the dislocation is inward, it is necessary that the sick person be laid upon his sound side in reducing it.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he places a ligature over the root of the hip, where it is between the head of the hip and the place which is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upward from the groin region to the higher part of the body, to the clavicle area.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then let another minister take strong arms and reduce the large place of the weak hip, extending it to the outside with vigorous extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For now it returns to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier of cures than the other kinds, in that this member is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If however he excuses himself from you and does not obey you for the entrance with this kind of cure at all: then it is necessary that two feet be bound together along with a strong, soft ligature above two heels and two knees: and let the length of each be four finger widths from its fellow: and let the weak leg be extended more than the other by the quantity of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the sick person should be suspended over the head of a log, which is in the house: and let its length from the earth be the quantity of two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong young man to support the head of the hip: and let another support him who is weak when found: and let another young man push, supporting the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place quickly.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In setting it properly, when a dislocation is external, it is necessary that the sick person lie on a stool, as we have narrated in one with hunchback.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And bind the ligament above his leg, which is weak properly, and above his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two cords are placed, one at his feet, and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a piece of wood is to be placed in the middle of the footbed, firmly fixed: upon which cloths should be wrapped that it may not harm the patient; and let the wood be between his hips so that it may not be pulled down when extended.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then let every assistant extend to his part, and the physician equalize the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he yields to reversion, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place upon the same table, and press it as we said about the prominence, equally.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the sick person lie on his sound side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the leg of the infirm be stretched quickly: and it is according to this same story on a platform: and the physician puts his right hand palm over the groin of the infirm.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he constricts it with the other hand, and with that constriction puts it extended downwards towards the lower part of the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is to the rear: then it is not necessary for the weak one to be extended downwards and raised above the ground: rather, it is necessary for him to be placed upon a hard object, as is fitting, as it also happens if the dislocation of his arm occurs outwards, according to what we said about his lying on two planks: and it is over his face, and the ligaments are extended, according to what we recently said.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that a compress be applied with a board also over the place to which the joint goes out, when reduction is completed as it ought.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return is not hidden from you: and it is, that you extend the two legs of the sick person: and when you see them equal, and the sick person tightens his leg, and expands it without excuse: then know, that now the limb returns, as it ought: then join the two hips, and put a plaster, and bind with an imemati, that is, a wheel: so that it may not move anywhere at all: and the sick person adheres to quiet for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament and the plaster, and compare the leg with the other; then if you see them equal in condition, then know that the dislocation is now firm: therefore discharge the sick person to walk.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see any softening: then return, and apply a dressing to it, and bind it according to your first constriction: and leave it for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then dissolve it and make it slow down in walking on both sides for several days, until it is well fortified.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	On the dislocation of the knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It is dislocated outwards, inwards, and downwards, namely to the rear.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated anteriorly.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	And the sign of its dislocation is, that you bid the sick man apply his leg to his hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If it does not adhere with the hip: then you shall know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all types of dislocation is to make the weak leg straight, so that it may now extend its leg if it can over it, and adhere your back to its face: and place his foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then cause his knee to adhere with your palms, and straight make them between your fingers upon his knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your palm both sides of his knee with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another attendant shall extend his foot until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of recovery is that the leg adheres to the hip with ease, not with effort.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then place a plaster over it and make the leg adhere to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then tie that with a thread for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then loosen it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And let not the sick person walk for several days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	If reduction is refused to you, then administer a strong extension with ligaments, the previous account of which in the treatment of the ankylosis, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	On the treatment of calcaneus dislocation.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	Sometimes the calcaneus is removed by a small incision, and sometimes it is dislocated according to the completeness.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation is made either inwards or outwards.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you see the heel bone swollen, proceeding towards the part to which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment of its removal is easy restoration: and it is, that it be extended with facility with hands, and be made equal, until it return.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the care of it when it is dislocated according to the completion, it is necessary that you make the patient sit straight; and let him hold him strong by the posterior part of his back, in the middle of it.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold his foot with your right hand from the upper part of it, and with your left hand from the lower part of his foot in the place of the heel.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot toward you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with two left stitches.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with the left hand and drive the breast of the foot with the right hand towards the leg without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do that twice, as we have narrated.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then press the chest of the foot toward the leg in a third position, and you pull the thread.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore it returns in one or in two according to this mode, and you see the foot equal, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation upon it; for it itself will return.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If you are prevented from reduction by that which we have narrated: then make the sick person lie on his back on the ground, and fix a small piece of wood firmly on the ground, so that it falls between his hips: and now you have enveloped him with cloth, so that he is not harmed.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the assistant take hold of his hip: afterwards let another assistant extend the foot, either with his hands or with a bandage that is tied above the ankle.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let every attendant extend against the extension of his own comparison: and a pad be standing between the two hips of the infirm holding him, so that the body of him is not drawn down in the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician reduces the dislocation with his hands, and another assistant holds the sound leg downwards.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For a dislocation returns with speed.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When therefore a dislocation returns, and the health of its restoration is declared to you: then place a plaster and a wad, and tightly bind it with ligaments, and tie the foot with a ligament to the leg.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And you ought to be careful or fearful of the nerves which are above the heel bone, so that the ligament is not too strong over them and harms them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let him be dismissed after two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, tighten it; then loosen it on the third or fourth day; and forbid the infirm from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If he attempts to walk before that time, it is not safe unless the dislocation breaks apart above him, and it is corrupted, and does not receive healing afterwards.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If it happens to him that he has a hot abscess, then you must administer to him the same thing which we mentioned before in another place concerning its cure, and an ointment, until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	On dislocation of the toes and their treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that what is dislocated be put back in place with little extension without labor; and indeed this is not difficult, but easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If the dislocation is in some joints of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that the sick person make his foot sit upon a level place of the earth, or upon a board: and he stands as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand, and place your foot upon that which projects from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then press that with your foot with strength until it returns and you see it leveled, and there is no prominence in its place.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under his foot a board which should hold the whole foot, having two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then bind it tightly with a bandage for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it and make him rest from walking for many days until it tightens and is secured by the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	On the kinds of dislocations with a wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from this, and you try its healing and restoration, many times death follows: and for that reason it is not fitting that he should presume to cure it, of this kind, unless he is prudent in the art, long used, merciful, pious, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous: and that he should use in the beginning medicines which calm hot abscesses only: and dismiss the sick by divine judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you hope for salvation from death with gentleness of sickness, and in which appears something of hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, attempt the reduction of it immediately at the beginning of the matter, before a hot abscess occurs.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If therefore the limb returns, according to what we want, then administer a treatment that calms the abscess; and care for the wound with that which is fitting for it from drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If the dislocation is with a fracture and these occur in separated bone fragments, then attempt the removal of them, and do what we said in simple ailments from what precedes regarding their places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And beware according to your strength, and guard yourself from entering the way of fear: according to what my prediction has preceded for you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you with your Creator, and more lasting for your glory, and more healthful for your body among those in your time.
